title: Criminal Law
description: Criminal Law flashcards for bar exam prep

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 001. Actus Reus
cards.backPlain: Actus reus is the physical act (or legally significant omission) required to commit a given crime. It is a required component of every common law crime, along with mens rea. 1. Requirements 1.1 Voluntary physical act: To satisfy the actus reus requirement, the defendant must perform a voluntary physical act, meaning a voluntary bodily movement. 2. Omission as actus reus (failure to act) 2.1 A failure to act can constitute actus reus if: 2.1.1 The defendant had a specific legal duty to act (for example, by statute, contract, special relationship, voluntary assumption of care, or creation of the risk); 2.1.2 The defendant had knowledge of the facts giving rise to the duty; and 2.1.3 It was reasonably possible for the defendant to perform the duty.
cards.frontPrompt: What is actus reus in criminal law, and what are the requirements for an act or omission to satisfy it?
cards.cloze: {{c1::Actus reus}} is the {{c2::physical act (or legally significant omission)}} required to commit a given crime. It is a required component of every common law crime, along with {{c3::mens rea}}. 1. Requirements 1.1 {{c4::Voluntary physical act}}: To satisfy the actus reus requirement, the defendant must perform a voluntary physical act, meaning a {{c5::voluntary bodily movement}}. 2. {{c6::Omission as actus reus}} (failure to act) 2.1 A failure to act can constitute actus reus if: 2.1.1 The defendant had a {{c7::specific legal duty to act}} (for example, by statute, contract, special relationship, voluntary assumption of care, or creation of the risk); 2.1.2 The defendant had {{c8::knowledge of the facts giving rise to the duty}}; and 2.1.3 It was {{c9::reasonably possible}} for the defendant to perform the duty.
cards.easyContent: Actus reus is the voluntary physical act or legally recognized omission required for a crime, and every common law crime needs both actus reus and mens rea.
cards.mediumContent: Actus reus is the physical component of a crime, consisting of a voluntary bodily movement or, in limited cases, a legally significant omission. The act must be voluntary. An omission can substitute for an act only when the defendant has a specific legal duty to act (from statute, contract, relationship, assumption of care, or creating the risk), knows the facts giving rise to that duty, and it is reasonably possible to perform the duty.
cards.hardContent: Actus reus is the external, physical component of a crime: a voluntary bodily movement or, in some situations, a failure to act where the law imposes a duty. Every common law crime requires both actus reus and mens rea. The act element demands a voluntary physical act, meaning a conscious bodily movement. A failure to act can satisfy actus reus only if three conditions are met: (1) the defendant had a specific legal duty to act, arising from sources such as statute, contract, special relationship, voluntary assumption of care, or creating the risk; (2) the defendant had knowledge of the facts giving rise to that duty; and (3) it was reasonably possible for the defendant to perform the duty.
cards.mnemonic: AVAILED: Act, Voluntary, Act or Inaction, Legal Duty.
cards.clozeLite: Actus reus is the {{c1::physical component of a crime}}, requiring a {{c2::voluntary bodily movement}} or a {{c3::legally significant omission}} where there is a {{c4::specific legal duty to act}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 002. Mens Rea
cards.front: Mens Rea – Overview of Common Law Mental States
cards.backPlain: Mens rea is the mental element required at the time a crime is committed. It is a required element of common law crimes, along with actus reus. At common law, the main mental-state categories (or related bases of liability) are: 1. Specific intent – requires a specific objective to commit the crime and must be proven; certain defenses (like mistake of fact and voluntary intoxication) apply. 2. General intent – requires awareness of one’s acts and circumstances; may be inferred from the act, and most crimes fall here. 3. Malice – involves reckless disregard of an obvious risk of a harmful result; used in arson and common law murder. 4. Strict liability – imposes liability with no required mental state for the offense. 5. Vicarious liability – imposes liability on one person based on another’s criminal act, often in employment or business contexts. These categories determine what mental state (if any) the prosecution must prove and which defenses may be available.
cards.frontPrompt: What is mens rea at common law, and what are the main mental-state (or liability) categories that structure it?
cards.cloze: {{c1::Mens rea}} is the mental element required at the time a crime is committed and is a required element of common law crimes, along with {{c2::actus reus}}. At common law, the main mental-state categories (or related bases of liability) are: 1. {{c3::Specific intent}} 2. {{c4::General intent}} 3. {{c5::Malice}} 4. {{c6::Strict liability}} 5. {{c7::Vicarious liability}}. These categories determine what {{c8::mental state the prosecution must prove and what defenses may be available}}.
cards.easyContent: Mens rea is the mental element of a crime, required along with actus reus at common law. The main mental-state or liability categories are specific intent, general intent, malice, strict liability, and vicarious liability.
cards.mediumContent: Mens rea is the mental element required when a crime is committed and, at common law, is paired with actus reus. Common law structures mental state and related liability into five main categories: specific intent, general intent, malice, strict liability (no mens rea required for the offense), and vicarious liability (liability based on another’s act). These categories govern what the prosecution must prove and which defenses may apply.
cards.hardContent: Mens rea is the mental element required at the time a crime is committed and is a required element of common law crimes, along with actus reus. Common law organizes mental states and related liability into five principal categories: 1. Specific intent – a particular objective to bring about the crime, which must be proven and not merely inferred. 2. General intent – awareness of one’s acts and attendant circumstances, often inferred from conduct; most crimes are general intent. 3. Malice – reckless disregard of, or undertaking an obvious risk of, a harmful result; applied to arson and common law murder. 4. Strict liability – no mens rea requirement at all for the offense (e.g., certain statutory rape, regulatory, or morality crimes). 5. Vicarious liability – liability imposed on a person without personal fault for another’s criminal conduct, often in employment or business contexts. This framework dictates the prosecution’s mental-state burden and shapes available defenses (e.g., mistake of fact and voluntary intoxication for specific intent crimes).
cards.mnemonic: SGMSV: Specific, General, Malice, Strict, Vicarious.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into overview (this card) plus four children: (1) specific vs general intent, (2) malice, (3) strict liability, and (4) vicarious liability.
cards.clozeLite: Common law {{c1::mens rea}} is the {{c2::mental element}} paired with {{c3::actus reus}} and is structured into {{c4::specific intent, general intent, malice, strict liability, and vicarious liability}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 003. MPC Mens Rea Standards
cards.backPlain: MBE questions occasionally invoke language from the Model Penal Code (MPC) fault standards. It is important to know these definitions: 1. Purposely (subjective standard) 1.1 A person acts purposely when his conscious objective is to engage in certain conduct or cause a certain result. 2. Knowingly (subjective standard) 2.1 A person acts knowingly when he is aware that his conduct is of a particular nature or knows that his conduct will necessarily or very likely cause a particular result. 3. Recklessly (subjective standard) 3.1 A person acts recklessly when he is aware of a substantial and unjustifiable risk and consciously disregards it. 4. Negligently (objective standard) 4.1 A person acts negligently when he fails to become aware of a substantial and unjustifiable risk. Note: The MBE generally tests common law, unless otherwise instructed. Though the MBE usually tells you which law is applicable, when in doubt, apply common law.
cards.frontPrompt: Under the MPC, how are the four culpable mental states—purposely, knowingly, recklessly, and negligently—defined?
cards.cloze: MBE questions occasionally invoke language from the {{c1::Model Penal Code (MPC)}} fault standards. It is important to know these definitions: 1. {{c2::Purposely}} ({{c3::subjective standard}}) 1.1 A person acts purposely when his {{c4::conscious objective is to engage in certain conduct or cause a certain result}}. 2. {{c5::Knowingly}} ({{c6::subjective standard}}) 2.1 A person acts knowingly when he is {{c7::aware that his conduct is of a particular nature}} or knows that his conduct will {{c8::necessarily or very likely cause a particular result}}. 3. {{c9::Recklessly}} ({{c10::subjective standard}}) 3.1 A person acts recklessly when he is {{c11::aware of a substantial and unjustifiable risk and consciously disregards it}}. 4. {{c12::Negligently}} ({{c13::objective standard}}) 4.1 A person acts negligently when he {{c14::fails to become aware of a substantial and unjustifiable risk}}. {{c15::Note:}} The MBE generally tests {{c16::common law}}, unless otherwise instructed. Though the MBE usually tells you which law is applicable, when in doubt, {{c17::apply common law}}.
cards.easyContent: The MPC defines four mental states: purposely, knowingly, recklessly, and negligently, each based on how aware the actor is of the nature and risks of his conduct.
cards.mediumContent: Under the MPC, a person acts purposely when his conscious objective is to engage in certain conduct or cause a certain result; knowingly when he is aware of the nature of his conduct or that it will necessarily or very likely cause a particular result; recklessly when he is aware of a substantial and unjustifiable risk and consciously disregards it; and negligently when he fails to become aware of a substantial and unjustifiable risk. The MBE usually applies common law unless it specifies MPC.
cards.hardContent: Under the Model Penal Code (MPC), the four culpable mental states are: (1) Purposely (subjective): the actor’s conscious objective is to engage in certain conduct or cause a particular result. (2) Knowingly (subjective): the actor is aware that his conduct is of a particular nature or knows that his conduct will necessarily or very likely cause a particular result. (3) Recklessly (subjective): the actor is aware of a substantial and unjustifiable risk and consciously disregards it. (4) Negligently (objective): the actor fails to become aware of a substantial and unjustifiable risk. On the MBE, common law generally controls unless the question specifies MPC or otherwise indicates.
cards.mnemonic: MPC ladder of blame: "PKRN"—Purpose, Know, Reckless, Negligent.
cards.clozeLite: Under the MPC, {{c1::purposely}} = conscious objective; {{c2::knowingly}} = aware conduct will occur; {{c3::recklessly}} = aware but disregards substantial risk; {{c4::negligently}} = fails to perceive substantial risk.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.topic: Major Crimes and Requisite Mens Rea
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 004. Major Crimes and Requisite Mens Rea
cards.front: Major Crimes and Requisite Mens Rea
cards.frontPrompt: How are major common law crimes categorized by requisite mens rea (general intent, specific intent, malice, and strict liability), and what are the main examples in each category?
cards.backPlain: Major common law crimes are grouped by their requisite mens rea: 1. General intent crimes: Defendant is aware of the actions and any attendant circumstances; intent may be inferred. Examples: battery, rape, kidnapping, and false imprisonment. 2. Specific intent crimes: (FIAT: first-degree murder, inchoate crimes, assault, theft) Defendant has a specific intent or objective to commit the particular crime. Examples: attempt, larceny and robbery, forgery, false pretenses, embezzlement, conspiracy, assault, burglary, first-degree murder, and solicitation. 3. Malice crimes: Involve reckless disregard of, or undertaking an obvious risk from which a harmful result is expected. Examples: common law murder (malice aforethought) and arson. 4. Strict liability crimes: No mens rea element is required. Examples: statutory rape, regulatory crimes, administrative crimes, and morality crimes such as bigamy and polygamy.
cards.cloze: Major common law crimes are grouped by their requisite mens rea: 1. {{c1::General intent crimes}}: Defendant is {{c2::aware of the actions and any attendant circumstances; intent may be inferred}}. Examples: {{c3::battery, rape, kidnapping, and false imprisonment}}. 2. {{c4::Specific intent crimes}} ({{c5::FIAT}}: {{c6::first-degree murder, inchoate crimes, assault, theft}}): Defendant has a {{c7::specific intent or objective to commit the particular crime}}. Examples: {{c8::attempt, larceny and robbery, forgery, false pretenses, embezzlement, conspiracy, assault, burglary, first-degree murder, and solicitation}}. 3. {{c9::Malice crimes}}: Involve {{c10::reckless disregard of, or undertaking an obvious risk from which a harmful result is expected}}. Examples: {{c11::common law murder (malice aforethought) and arson}}. 4. {{c12::Strict liability crimes}}: {{c13::No mens rea element is required}}. Examples: {{c14::statutory rape, regulatory crimes, administrative crimes, and morality crimes such as bigamy and polygamy}}.
cards.easyContent: Major crimes are grouped by mens rea: general intent (awareness of act/circumstances), specific intent (FIAT: first-degree murder, inchoate crimes, assault, theft), malice (reckless disregard of an obvious risk), and strict liability (no mens rea). Each category has its own set of common law examples.
cards.mediumContent: Major common law crimes are organized into four mens rea categories. General intent crimes require awareness of the act and circumstances, and intent may be inferred; examples include battery, rape, kidnapping, and false imprisonment. Specific intent crimes (FIAT: first-degree murder, inchoate crimes, assault, theft) require a specific objective and include attempt, larceny and robbery, forgery, false pretenses, embezzlement, conspiracy, assault, burglary, first-degree murder, and solicitation. Malice crimes require reckless disregard of, or undertaking an obvious risk from which a harmful result is expected, and include common law murder (malice aforethought) and arson. Strict liability crimes, such as statutory rape, regulatory, administrative, and morality crimes like bigamy and polygamy, have no mens rea requirement.
cards.hardContent: Major common law crimes are categorized by requisite mens rea: (1) General intent crimes require that the defendant be aware of his actions and any attendant circumstances; the requisite intent may be inferred from conduct. Crimes in this category include battery, rape, kidnapping, and false imprisonment. (2) Specific intent crimes (remember FIAT: first-degree murder, inchoate crimes, assault, theft) require a specific intent or objective to bring about the prohibited result. Specific intent crimes include attempt, larceny and robbery, forgery, false pretenses, embezzlement, conspiracy, assault, burglary, first-degree murder, and solicitation. (3) Malice crimes require a reckless disregard of, or undertaking an obvious risk from which a harmful result is expected. Common law murder (malice aforethought) and arson are malice crimes. (4) Strict liability crimes have no mens rea requirement; the prosecution need only prove the voluntary act. Statutory rape, regulatory crimes, administrative crimes, and certain morality crimes such as bigamy and polygamy are strict liability offenses.
cards.mnemonic: FIAT for specific intent: First-degree murder, Inchoate, Assault, Theft.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into four children: (1) general intent crimes list, (2) specific intent (FIAT) crimes list, (3) malice crimes, and (4) strict liability crimes.
cards.clozeLite: Major crimes are grouped by mens rea: {{c1::general intent}}, {{c2::specific intent (FIAT)}}, {{c3::malice}}, and {{c4::strict liability}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 005. Concurrence and Causation
cards.backPlain: Criminal liability for result crimes requires both concurrence and causation. 1. Concurrence requirement (temporal relationship) 1.1 The defendant's criminal act and the required mens rea must occur at the same time for the offense charged. 1.2 If the harmful act occurs before the intent forms, there is no concurrence for that offense. 2. Causation requirement (link between conduct and result) 2.1 The defendant’s conduct must be a cause-in-fact (but-for cause, including acts that hasten an inevitable death) and a proximate cause (natural and probable consequence, unless broken by a superseding, unforeseeable intervening act). 2.2 Causation issues most frequently arise in homicide and manslaughter problems on the MBE.
cards.frontPrompt: In criminal law, what are the basic concurrence and causation requirements for result crimes?
cards.cloze: Criminal liability for result crimes requires both {{c1::concurrence}} and {{c2::causation}}. 1. {{c3::Concurrence}}: The defendant's criminal {{c4::act}} and required {{c5::mens rea}} must occur at the same time. 2. {{c6::Causation}}: The defendant’s conduct must be both a {{c7::cause-in-fact}} and a {{c8::proximate cause}} of the result, with liability usually turning on whether any {{c9::intervening act}} is {{c10::foreseeable}} or {{c11::superseding}}.
cards.easyContent: Result crimes require concurrence (the guilty mind and guilty act exist at the same time) and causation (the defendant’s conduct is both a but-for and proximate cause of the result).
cards.mediumContent: For result crimes, the actus reus and mens rea must concur in time, and the defendant’s conduct must both actually cause (but-for, including hastening an inevitable death) and proximately cause (natural and probable consequence, not cut off by a superseding, unforeseeable intervening act) the result. These issues commonly arise in homicide questions.
cards.hardContent: Concurrence requires that the defendant’s criminal act and the specific mens rea for the charged offense exist simultaneously; if the harmful act precedes the formation of intent (e.g., accidentally hitting someone you later decide you wanted to kill), there is no concurrence for that offense. Causation requires both cause-in-fact (but-for cause, including any act that hastens an otherwise inevitable death) and proximate cause (the actual result must be the natural and probable consequence of the defendant’s conduct, and the causal chain remains intact unless broken by a superseding, unforeseeable intervening act). Causation issues arise most frequently in homicide and manslaughter problems.
cards.mnemonic: CAB: Concurrence, Actual cause, Proximate cause.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) concurrence requirement with example, (2) cause-in-fact rules including hastening death, and (3) proximate cause with superseding factors and intervening acts.
cards.clozeLite: Result crimes require {{c1::concurrence}} (actus reus + mens rea together) and {{c2::causation}} ({{c3::but-for}} and {{c4::proximate}} cause of the result).

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 006. Transferred Intent Doctrine
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule 1.1 The defendant may be held liable if he intends the harm caused but causes it to a different victim or object than intended. 1.2 Transferred intent often applies to homicide, battery, and arson. 1.3 Transferred intent does not apply to attempt. 1.4 Defenses and mitigating circumstances may also be transferred. 2. Effect 2.1 Under transferred intent, the defendant is usually charged with two crimes: 2.1.1 Attempt to commit the originally intended crime. 2.1.2 The actual resulting crime. 2.2 Example: The defendant intends to shoot A but kills B instead. The defendant can be charged with the attempted murder of A and the actual murder of B. Merger does not apply because there are different victims.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the transferred intent doctrine in criminal law, to which crimes does it apply, and what is its effect on the defendant’s liability?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::General rule}} 1.1 The defendant may be held liable if he {{c2::intends the harm caused but causes it to a different victim or object than intended}}. 1.2 Transferred intent often applies to {{c3::homicide}}, {{c4::battery}}, and {{c5::arson}}. 1.3 Transferred intent {{c6::does not apply to attempt}}. 1.4 {{c7::Defenses and mitigating circumstances}} may also be transferred. 2. {{c8::Effect}} 2.1 Under transferred intent, the defendant is usually charged with {{c9::two crimes}}: 2.1.1 {{c10::Attempt to commit the originally intended crime}}. 2.1.2 {{c11::The actual resulting crime}}. 2.2 Example: The defendant intends to shoot A but kills B instead. The defendant can be charged with the {{c12::attempted murder of A}} and the {{c13::actual murder of B}}. {{c14::Merger does not apply because there are different victims}}.
cards.easyContent: Transferred intent holds a defendant liable when he intends a particular harm but causes that harm to a different victim or object, typically in homicide, battery, or arson cases.
cards.mediumContent: Under the transferred intent doctrine, if a defendant intends a particular harm but causes that harm to a different victim or object, the intent transfers and he may be held liable as if he had harmed the intended target. It commonly applies to homicide, battery, and arson, but not to attempt. Defenses and mitigating circumstances may also transfer. Typically, the defendant can be charged both with attempt as to the intended victim and with the completed offense against the actual victim, and these do not merge when there are different victims.
cards.hardContent: The transferred intent doctrine provides that when a defendant intends a particular harm but causes that harm to a different victim or object than intended, the intent transfers to the actual result. It frequently applies in offenses such as homicide, battery, and arson, but it does not apply to attempt. Any defenses or mitigating circumstances that would have applied to the intended victim or target also transfer. As a result, the defendant is usually charged with two crimes: (1) attempt to commit the originally intended crime, and (2) the actual resulting crime. For example, if the defendant intends to shoot A but instead kills B, he may be charged with the attempted murder of A and the actual murder of B; merger does not apply because the offenses involve different victims.
cards.mnemonic: Intent FOLLOWS the bullet: From Original to Landed, Liability Often Will Stick.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::transferred intent}}, intent to harm one {{c2::victim or object}} transfers to the {{c3::actual victim}}, commonly in {{c4::homicide, battery, and arson}} but {{c5::not attempt}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 007. Merger
cards.backPlain: Merger in criminal law limits multiple convictions when one offense is essentially part of another. 1. General rule - Under the merger doctrine, two or more offenses may merge, prohibiting the defendant from being convicted of both offenses. - Merger concerns the relationship between either: - An inchoate offense and its completed substantive offense, or - A greater offense and its lesser included offense. 2. Two main contexts - Inchoate offenses: solicitation and attempt may merge into the completed target offense; conspiracy does not merge. - Lesser included offenses: a defendant cannot be convicted of both a greater offense and its lesser included offense, but crimes with different victims do not merge.
cards.frontPrompt: In criminal law, what is the merger doctrine and in what two main contexts does it apply?
cards.cloze: Merger in criminal law limits {{c1::multiple convictions}} when one offense is essentially part of another. 1. General rule - Under the {{c2::merger doctrine}}, two or more offenses may merge, prohibiting the defendant from being convicted of both offenses. - Merger concerns the relationship between either: - An {{c3::inchoate offense}} and its completed {{c4::substantive offense}}, or - A greater offense and its {{c5::lesser included offense}}. 2. Two main contexts - {{c6::Inchoate offenses}}: solicitation and attempt may merge into the completed target offense; conspiracy does not merge. - {{c7::Lesser included offenses}}: a defendant cannot be convicted of both a greater offense and its lesser included offense, but crimes with different victims do not merge.
cards.easyContent: The merger doctrine prevents multiple convictions when one crime is essentially part of another, especially for certain inchoate crimes and lesser included offenses.
cards.mediumContent: Under the merger doctrine, two or more offenses may merge so that the defendant cannot be convicted of both. Merger arises in two main contexts: (1) certain inchoate offenses (solicitation and attempt) and the completed substantive offense, and (2) greater offenses and their lesser included offenses. Conspiracy does not merge, and crimes with different victims do not merge.
cards.hardContent: Merger limits multiple convictions when one crime is subsumed within another. It applies primarily in two contexts: (1) inchoate offenses, where solicitation and attempt may merge into the completed substantive offense (but conspiracy does not merge), and (2) lesser included offenses, where a defendant generally cannot be convicted of both a greater offense and its lesser included offense. Crimes involving different victims do not merge. Double jeopardy principles also often bar multiple punishments in these scenarios.
cards.mnemonic: Merges SA into big crime; C stays separate.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) general definition and structure of merger, (2) merger and inchoate offenses (solicitation/attempt vs. conspiracy), and (3) merger and lesser included offenses, including different-victim rule and double jeopardy note.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::merger doctrine}} bars convictions for both {{c2::solicitation or attempt}} and the {{c3::completed offense}}, and for {{c4::greater offenses and their lesser included offenses}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 008. Accomplice Liability
cards.backPlain: Accomplice liability holds a person responsible for a crime when they intentionally aid, counsel, or encourage the principal before or during the offense. The accomplice is liable not only for the target offense but also for other crimes that are probable or foreseeable results of the planned crime. There are several limits and defenses to accomplice liability, including effective withdrawal before the crime is committed, and statutory exceptions for members of a protected class and certain parties the statute is designed to regulate. Finally, accessory after the fact is a separate and typically lesser offense that applies to those who help a known felon avoid arrest, trial, or conviction after the crime has been completed, rather than to those who participated in the crime itself.
cards.frontPrompt: What is accomplice liability in general, and how do its elements, scope, defenses, and distinction from accessory after the fact fit together?
cards.cloze: Accomplice liability attaches when a person {{c1::intentionally aids, counsels, or encourages}} a principal {{c2::before or during}} the crime, and is liable for the target crime and other {{c3::probable or foreseeable}} crimes. It is limited by defenses such as {{c4::effective withdrawal}} and statutory exceptions, and it is distinct from {{c5::accessory after the fact}}, which punishes help given {{c6::after}} the crime to a {{c7::known felon}}.
cards.easyContent: Accomplice liability makes someone who intentionally helps commit a crime before or during it liable for that crime and foreseeable additional crimes, subject to limits like withdrawal and statutory exceptions, and is distinct from liability as an accessory after the fact.
cards.mediumContent: Accomplice liability covers those who intentionally aid, counsel, or encourage a principal before or during a crime and are thus liable for the crime and other probable or foreseeable crimes. Limits include effective withdrawal and statutory exceptions (e.g., protected-class members and certain regulated parties). Accessory after the fact is separate and applies to those who help a known felon avoid arrest, trial, or conviction after the crime.
cards.hardContent: Accomplice liability arises when a person intentionally aids, counsels, or encourages the principal before or during the commission of a crime, exposing them to liability for the target offense and other probable or foreseeable crimes that result. This liability is limited by defenses and exceptions such as effective withdrawal (which must occur before the crime and involve repudiation and efforts to counteract prior aid) and statutory exceptions for protected-class members and certain regulated parties. A distinct doctrine, accessory after the fact, punishes post-crime assistance to a known felon in evading arrest, trial, or conviction and is generally charged as a separate, lesser offense.
cards.mnemonic: AID + INTENT: Aid the crime, intend the crime.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) elements and scope of accomplice liability; (2) defenses and exceptions; (3) accessory after the fact as a distinct concept.
cards.clozeLite: {{c1::Accomplice liability}} applies to those who {{c2::intentionally aid, counsel, or encourage}} a principal {{c3::before or during}} a crime, making them liable for {{c4::the crime and other probable or foreseeable crimes}}, but subject to {{c5::withdrawal and statutory exceptions}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 009. Solicitation
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule: Solicitation is inciting, urging, or otherwise asking another to commit a crime with the intent that they commit the crime. 1.1 No affirmative response from the solicited party is required; the crime is complete upon the asking. 1.2 Solicitation merges with the target offense. 2. Merger and relationship to conspiracy: 2.1 Solicitation is complete when the defendant asks the solicitee to commit the felony. 2.2 If the solicitee agrees, the agreement gives rise to conspiracy, and the solicitation merges with the conspiracy (the only crime remaining is conspiracy). 2.3 It does not matter if the solicited party is convicted or if the solicited crime was impossible to commit. 3. Defenses: There are very few defenses that apply to solicitation. 3.1 Refusal by the solicitee is not a defense. 3.2 Impossibility and withdrawal are not defenses at common law. 3.3 Under the MPC, renunciation is a defense if the defendant prevents the commission of the crime, but at common law (followed by most jurisdictions) renunciation is not a defense.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the crime of solicitation, how does it merge with other offenses, and what defenses (if any) are available at common law and under the MPC?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule: {{c1::Solicitation}} is {{c2::inciting, urging, or otherwise asking another to commit a crime}} with the {{c3::intent that they commit the crime}}. 1.1 No {{c4::affirmative response}} from the solicited party is required; the crime is complete upon the asking. 1.2 Solicitation {{c5::merges with the target offense}}. 2. Merger and relationship to conspiracy: 2.1 Solicitation is complete when the defendant asks the {{c6::solicitee}} to commit the felony. 2.2 If the solicitee agrees, the agreement gives rise to {{c7::conspiracy}}, and the solicitation {{c8::merges with the conspiracy}} (the only crime remaining is conspiracy). 2.3 It does not matter if the solicited party is {{c9::convicted}} or if the solicited crime was {{c10::impossible to commit}}. 3. Defenses: There are very few defenses that apply to solicitation. 3.1 {{c11::Refusal by the solicitee}} is not a defense. 3.2 {{c12::Impossibility}} and {{c13::withdrawal}} are not defenses at common law. 3.3 Under the {{c14::MPC}}, {{c15::renunciation}} is a defense if the defendant prevents the commission of the crime, but at {{c16::common law}} (followed by most jurisdictions) renunciation is not a defense.
cards.easyContent: Solicitation occurs when someone asks or encourages another to commit a crime with the intent that the crime be committed; it is complete upon the asking and generally merges into the target offense or conspiracy.
cards.mediumContent: Solicitation is inciting, urging, or asking another to commit a crime with intent that the crime be committed. No affirmative response is required, and the offense is complete upon the asking. Solicitation merges into the completed target offense and, if the solicitee agrees, into conspiracy, leaving conspiracy as the charge. At common law, refusal, impossibility, and withdrawal are not defenses. Under the MPC, renunciation can be a defense if the defendant prevents the commission of the crime, but most jurisdictions follow the common law rule and do not recognize renunciation.
cards.hardContent: Solicitation consists of inciting, urging, or otherwise asking another to commit a crime with the specific intent that the other person commit the crime. No affirmative response by the solicited party is required; the crime is complete upon the asking. Solicitation merges with the target offense if the crime is completed. If the solicitee agrees, their agreement creates a conspiracy, and the solicitation merges into the conspiracy such that only conspiracy is charged; it is irrelevant whether the solicited party is actually convicted or whether the solicited crime was factually or legally impossible. Defenses are narrow: under common law, refusal by the solicitee, impossibility, and withdrawal are not defenses. Under the MPC, a complete and voluntary renunciation that results in preventing the commission of the crime is a defense, but most jurisdictions retain the common law approach and do not allow renunciation as a defense to solicitation.
cards.mnemonic: "Just Ask"—crime on the ask; agreement = conspiracy.
cards.clozeLite: Solicitation is {{c1::inciting, urging, or asking another}} to commit a crime with {{c2::intent that the crime be committed}}; it is {{c3::complete upon the asking}} and {{c4::merges into the target offense or conspiracy}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 010. Conspiracy
cards.backPlain: Conspiracy is an inchoate offense based on an agreement to commit a crime or achieve an unlawful objective. It generally requires: (1) an agreement between two or more people (which may be tacit and without each conspirator knowing all others), (2) intent to enter into the agreement, (3) intent to commit the target crime or unlawful objective, and in many jurisdictions (4) an overt act in furtherance (not required at common law). At common law, conspiracy is bilateral and requires at least two parties with genuine criminal intent; under the MPC, it can be unilateral, so one party with criminal intent may be guilty even if the other is feigning agreement. A conspiracy ends when the target offense is completed or when the conspirators abandon the plan. Impossibility is not a defense, and withdrawal generally does not defeat the conspiracy once formed, though it may limit liability for co-conspirators' subsequent crimes.
cards.frontPrompt: What is conspiracy, in broad terms, and how do its elements, common law vs. MPC approach, termination, and defenses fit together?
cards.cloze: Conspiracy is an {{c1::inchoate offense}} based on an {{c2::agreement}} to commit a crime or achieve an {{c3::unlawful objective}}. It generally requires: (1) an agreement between two or more people (which may be tacit and without each conspirator knowing all others), (2) intent to enter into the agreement, (3) intent to commit the target crime or unlawful objective, and in many jurisdictions (4) an {{c4::overt act}} in furtherance (not required at common law). At {{c5::common law}}, conspiracy is {{c6::bilateral}} and requires at least two parties with genuine criminal intent; under the {{c7::MPC}}, it can be {{c8::unilateral}} so one party with criminal intent may be guilty even if the other is feigning agreement. A conspiracy ends when the {{c9::target offense is completed}} or when the conspirators {{c10::abandon the plan}}. {{c11::Impossibility}} is not a defense, and {{c12::withdrawal}} generally does not defeat the conspiracy once formed, though it may limit liability for {{c13::co-conspirators' subsequent crimes}}.
cards.easyContent: Conspiracy is an agreement-based inchoate crime requiring agreement plus intent (and often an overt act), with different common law vs. MPC approaches, specific termination rules, and limited defenses (no impossibility; withdrawal mainly limits further liability).
cards.mediumContent: Conspiracy is an inchoate offense defined by an agreement to commit a crime or achieve an unlawful objective. Its core elements are an agreement, intent to agree, and intent to accomplish the unlawful goal, with many jurisdictions also requiring an overt act (though common law does not). Common law treats conspiracy as bilateral, requiring at least two parties with genuine criminal intent, whereas the MPC allows unilateral conspiracy where one culpable actor can conspire with a feigning party (e.g., an undercover officer). Conspiracy terminates upon completion of the target crime or abandonment of the plan. Impossibility is not a defense, and withdrawal generally does not undo the conspiracy but may shield from liability for co-conspirators' later crimes.
cards.hardContent: Conspiracy is an inchoate offense focused on group criminal agreements. It consists of: (1) an agreement—express or tacit—between two or more persons to commit a crime or achieve an unlawful objective, with no requirement that all conspirators know of each other; (2) intent to enter into the agreement; and (3) intent to commit the target crime or pursue the unlawful objective. Many modern jurisdictions also require an overt act in furtherance of the conspiracy, while at common law no overt act was needed. At common law, conspiracy is bilateral: at least two conspirators must have genuine criminal intent, so if one is feigning agreement, neither is guilty of conspiracy. Under the MPC, conspiracy can be unilateral so a single person with criminal intent can be guilty even if the other party is an undercover officer. Conspiracy terminates when the target offense is completed or when the conspirators abandon their plan. Impossibility is not a defense to conspiracy. Withdrawal generally cannot undo an already-formed conspiracy, but a timely and effective withdrawal can prevent liability for co-conspirators' subsequent substantive offenses.
cards.mnemonic: "AII + O": Agreement, Intent to agree, Intent to commit, plus Overt act.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) definition and elements (including overt act), (2) unilateral vs. bilateral (common law vs. MPC), and (3) termination and defenses (impossibility, withdrawal).
cards.clozeLite: Conspiracy is {{c1::an agreement to commit a crime}} requiring {{c2::intent to agree}} and {{c3::intent to achieve the unlawful goal}}, plus {{c4::an overt act in many jurisdictions}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 011. Co Conspirator Liability and Withdrawal
cards.backPlain: 1. Co-conspirator liability: 1.1 Each conspirator is liable for co-conspirators' crimes that are: 1.1.1 Foreseeable, and 1.1.2 Committed in furtherance of the conspiracy. 2. Withdrawal: 2.1 Under common law, one cannot withdraw from the conspiracy itself once the agreement is made. 2.2 Under the MPC, withdrawal from the conspiracy is possible if the withdrawing party thwarts the conspiracy (for example, by stopping it or notifying police). 3. Withdrawal from subsequent crimes: 3.1 Even if a conspirator cannot withdraw from the conspiracy itself at common law, one can withdraw from co-conspirators' subsequent crimes, including the target offense of the conspiracy. 3.2 An affirmative act is required: Withdrawal is effective when the withdrawing party makes an affirmative act that notifies his co-conspirators he is withdrawing. 3.3 The withdrawal must be timely: It must give enough time for co-conspirators to abandon plans for the target offense. 3.4 The withdrawing party must attempt to neutralize the effect of any assistance he provided to the original conspiracy.
cards.frontPrompt: For co-conspirator liability, when is a conspirator liable for the acts of others, and what is required to effectively withdraw from the conspiracy or from liability for subsequent crimes?
cards.cloze: 1. Co-conspirator liability: 1.1 Each conspirator is liable for co-conspirators' crimes that are: 1.1.1 {{c1::Foreseeable}}, and 1.1.2 Committed {{c2::in furtherance of the conspiracy}}. 2. Withdrawal: 2.1 Under {{c3::common law}}, one cannot withdraw from the {{c4::conspiracy itself}} once the agreement is made. 2.2 Under the {{c5::MPC}}, withdrawal from the conspiracy is possible if the withdrawing party {{c6::thwarts the conspiracy}} (for example, by stopping it or notifying police). 3. Withdrawal from subsequent crimes: 3.1 Even if a conspirator cannot withdraw from the conspiracy itself at common law, one can withdraw from co-conspirators' {{c7::subsequent crimes}}, including the target offense of the conspiracy. 3.2 An {{c8::affirmative act}} is required: Withdrawal is effective when the withdrawing party makes an affirmative act that {{c9::notifies his co-conspirators}} he is withdrawing. 3.3 The withdrawal must be {{c10::timely}}: It must give enough time for co-conspirators to abandon plans for the target offense. 3.4 The withdrawing party must attempt to {{c11::neutralize the effect of any assistance}} he provided to the original conspiracy.
cards.easyContent: Each conspirator is liable for other conspirators’ crimes that are foreseeable and in furtherance of the conspiracy, but withdrawal—especially if timely, affirmative, and aimed at neutralizing prior aid—can cut off liability for later crimes.
cards.mediumContent: Co-conspirator liability makes each conspirator liable for the crimes of other conspirators that are both foreseeable and committed in furtherance of the conspiracy. At common law, a conspirator cannot withdraw from the conspiracy itself once formed, but may withdraw from liability for later crimes by taking timely, affirmative steps that notify co-conspirators and attempt to neutralize prior assistance. Under the MPC, a conspirator can withdraw from the conspiracy itself by thwarting it, such as by stopping it or informing law enforcement.
cards.hardContent: Under co-conspirator liability, each conspirator is vicariously liable for the crimes of other conspirators so long as those crimes are foreseeable and committed in furtherance of the conspiracy’s objectives. At common law, a conspirator cannot withdraw from the conspiracy itself once there is an agreement, but can limit liability for co-conspirators’ subsequent crimes, including the target offense, by effectively withdrawing. Effective withdrawal requires an affirmative act that clearly notifies co-conspirators of the intent to withdraw, is timely enough to allow them to abandon their plans, and is accompanied by efforts to neutralize or undo any assistance already provided. Under the MPC, a conspirator may withdraw from the conspiracy itself if he thwarts the conspiracy, for example by stopping it or notifying the police, which can bar further liability.
cards.mnemonic: Co-conspirator: F+F crimes, withdraw with A-T-N (Affirm, Timely, Neutralize).
cards.clozeLite: Each {{c1::conspirator}} is liable for other conspirators’ crimes that are {{c2::foreseeable}} and {{c3::in furtherance of the conspiracy}}; withdrawal requires {{c4::timely, affirmative steps}} to {{c5::notify and neutralize prior aid}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 012. Attempt
cards.backPlain: Attempt is an inchoate offense. It generally requires: 1. Specific intent to commit a particular target crime. 2. An overt or substantial step toward committing that crime, beyond mere preparation (often framed at common law as being "dangerously close" to completion). Key defenses and limitations: - Legal impossibility is a defense. - Factual impossibility is not a defense. - Abandonment is not a defense at common law; under the majority rule, attempt liability attaches once the defendant, with specific intent, commits the requisite overt act, so later abandonment does not negate liability.
cards.frontPrompt: In criminal law, what are the core elements and key defenses for attempt?
cards.cloze: Attempt is an {{c1::inchoate offense}} that generally requires {{c2::specific intent}} to commit a crime and an {{c3::overt or substantial step}} beyond mere preparation (often framed as being {{c4::dangerously close}} to completion). Key defenses/limitations: {{c5::legal impossibility is a defense}}, {{c6::factual impossibility is not}}, and {{c7::abandonment is not a defense at common law}} once the {{c8::overt act with specific intent}} has occurred.
cards.easyContent: Attempt is an inchoate crime that requires specific intent to commit a target crime plus a substantial step beyond mere preparation. Legal impossibility is a defense; factual impossibility is not. Abandonment is not a defense at common law once the overt act is done.
cards.mediumContent: Attempt requires (1) specific intent to commit a particular crime and (2) an overt or substantial step beyond mere preparation, often described at common law as an act dangerously close to completion. Legal impossibility is a defense, but factual impossibility is not. Abandonment is not a defense at common law; under the majority rule, liability for attempt attaches once the defendant, with specific intent, commits the requisite overt act, so later abandonment does not erase liability.
cards.hardContent: Attempt is an inchoate offense where the defendant, with the specific intent to commit a particular crime, takes an overt or substantial step beyond mere preparation toward committing that crime, but does not succeed. Under the common law "dangerous proximity" standard, the act must be dangerously close to success. Legal impossibility is a defense to attempt, but factual impossibility is not. Abandonment is not a defense at common law; under the majority rule, liability for attempt arises once the defendant commits the overt act with the required specific intent, so any later abandonment does not defeat attempt liability.
cards.mnemonic: ISA: Intent, Step, Abandonment usually no defense.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into (1) definition and act requirement for attempt, (2) specific intent requirement, and (3) defenses: legal vs factual impossibility and abandonment.
cards.clozeLite: Attempt requires {{c1::specific intent}} plus {{c2::an overt or substantial step}} beyond preparation. {{c3::Legal impossibility is a defense}}, but {{c4::factual impossibility is not}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 013. Capacity Defense
cards.backPlain: Insanity: 1. General rule: 1.1 Legal insanity is a complete defense to all crimes, regardless of the mens rea or intent requirement. 1.2 Depending on the jurisdiction, one of four legal insanity tests is used to determine whether the defendant was so mentally ill when he committed the crime that he should be entitled to acquittal. 2. Four legal insanity tests (jurisdiction will specify which applies): 2.1 M'Naghten test – focuses on whether, due to mental disease or defect, the defendant lacked the ability to know the wrongfulness of his conduct or understand the nature and quality of his act. 2.2 Irresistible Impulse test – focuses on whether, due to mental illness, the defendant was unable to control his actions or conform his conduct to the law. 2.3 MPC test – combines cognitive and volitional components: whether, as a result of mental disease, the defendant lacked the capacity either to appreciate the criminality (or wrongfulness) of his conduct or to conform his conduct to the requirements of the law. 2.4 Durham test – asks whether the defendant's conduct was the product of a mental illness (i.e., he would not have acted but for his mental illness). 3. Note: 3.1 On the MBE, the question will indicate which insanity test applies.
cards.frontPrompt: In criminal law, what is the insanity defense and what are the four main insanity tests used by different jurisdictions?
cards.cloze: Insanity: 1. General rule: 1.1 {{c1::Legal insanity}} is a complete defense to {{c2::all crimes}}, regardless of the {{c3::mens rea or intent requirement}}. 1.2 Depending on the jurisdiction, one of {{c4::four legal insanity tests}} is used to determine whether the defendant was so mentally ill when he committed the crime that he should be entitled to acquittal. 2. Four legal insanity tests (jurisdiction will specify which applies): 2.1 {{c5::M'Naghten test}} – focuses on whether, due to mental disease or defect, the defendant lacked the ability to know the {{c6::wrongfulness}} of his conduct or understand the {{c7::nature and quality}} of his act. 2.2 {{c8::Irresistible Impulse test}} – focuses on whether, due to mental illness, the defendant was unable to {{c9::control his actions}} or {{c10::conform his conduct to the law}}. 2.3 {{c11::MPC test}} – combines cognitive and volitional components: whether, as a result of mental disease, the defendant lacked the capacity either to {{c12::appreciate the criminality (or wrongfulness) of his conduct}} or to {{c13::conform his conduct to the requirements of the law}}. 2.4 {{c14::Durham test}} – asks whether the defendant's conduct was the {{c15::product of a mental illness}} (i.e., he would not have acted {{c16::but for}} his mental illness). 3. Note: 3.1 On the {{c17::MBE}}, the question will indicate which insanity test applies.
cards.easyContent: Legal insanity is a complete defense to all crimes. Jurisdictions use one of four tests: M'Naghten, Irresistible Impulse, MPC, or Durham, and MBE questions tell you which test applies.
cards.mediumContent: Insanity is a complete defense to all crimes if, under the jurisdiction’s chosen test, the defendant’s mental disease or defect at the time of the offense shows he was legally insane. The four main tests are: (1) M'Naghten (cognitive—did not know wrongfulness or nature and quality of the act), (2) Irresistible Impulse (volitional—unable to control actions or conform to law), (3) MPC (combined cognitive/volitional—lacked capacity to appreciate criminality or conform conduct), and (4) Durham (conduct is the product of mental illness). The exam will specify which test to apply.
cards.hardContent: Legal insanity is a complete defense to all crimes, regardless of the mens rea requirement, when the defendant’s mental disease or defect at the time of the offense satisfies the jurisdiction’s insanity standard. Jurisdictions use one of four tests: (1) the M'Naghten test, focusing on whether, due to mental disease or defect, the defendant did not know right from wrong or lacked the ability to know the wrongfulness of his conduct or understand the nature and quality of his act; (2) the Irresistible Impulse test, focusing on whether, due to mental illness, the defendant acted because of an irresistible impulse and was unable to control his actions or conform his conduct to the law; (3) the MPC test, which combines both cognitive and volitional aspects by asking whether, as a result of mental disease, the defendant lacked the capacity either to appreciate the criminality (or wrongfulness) of his conduct or to conform his conduct to the requirements of the law; and (4) the Durham test, which asks whether the defendant’s conduct was the product of his mental illness—i.e., he would not have acted but for that illness. On the MBE, the question will state which test applies.
cards.mnemonic: Insanity tests = "MIMD": M'Naghten, Irresistible impulse, MPC, Durham.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into: (1) general rule for insanity as a defense (this parent gives overview), and separate children for (2) M'Naghten, (3) Irresistible Impulse, (4) MPC, and (5) Durham tests.
cards.clozeLite: Insanity is a {{c1::complete defense}} if, due to {{c2::mental disease or defect}}, defendant meets one test: {{c3::M'Naghten}}, {{c4::Irresistible Impulse}}, {{c5::MPC}}, or {{c6::Durham}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 014. Capacity Defense
cards.backPlain: Capacity-related doctrines in criminal law include: 1. Infancy: rules limiting criminal liability for very young offenders (categorical bar under a certain age and rebuttable presumption for ages 7–14). 2. Diminished capacity: a mental state defense based on a mental defect short of insanity that may negate the mens rea, usually for specific intent crimes. 3. Competency to stand trial and be sentenced: due process bars trying, convicting, or sentencing a defendant who, due to mental disease or defect, cannot understand the proceedings or assist counsel. 4. Competency for execution: a defendant may not be executed if, at the time of execution, he cannot understand the nature and purpose of the punishment.
cards.frontPrompt: What major capacity-related doctrines can limit criminal liability, trial/sentencing, or execution in criminal law?
cards.cloze: Capacity-related doctrines in criminal law include: 1. {{c1::Infancy}}: rules limiting criminal liability for very young offenders. 2. {{c2::Diminished capacity}}: a mental state defense based on a mental defect short of insanity. 3. {{c3::Competency to stand trial and be sentenced}}: due process limits on trying/sentencing those who cannot understand proceedings or assist counsel. 4. {{c4::Competency for execution}}: limits on executing those who cannot understand the nature and purpose of the punishment.
cards.easyContent: Capacity defenses in criminal law include infancy, diminished capacity, and due process-based competency rules for trial, sentencing, and execution.
cards.mediumContent: Criminal capacity doctrines cover: (1) infancy, which limits or bars liability for very young offenders; (2) diminished capacity, a mental defect defense short of insanity that may negate specific intent mens rea; and constitutional limits on punishment—(3) competency to stand trial or be sentenced, and (4) competency for execution—both of which require the defendant to understand the proceedings or punishment and, for trial, to be able to assist counsel.
cards.hardContent: Capacity doctrines in criminal law operate at different stages: (1) Infancy governs whether a child can be held criminally liable at all, using categorical and presumptive age cutoffs. (2) Diminished capacity addresses whether a mental defect short of insanity prevents formation of the required mens rea, usually for specific intent crimes. (3) Due process forbids trying, convicting, or sentencing a defendant who, due to mental disease or defect, cannot understand the nature of the proceedings or assist counsel. (4) At the execution stage, a defendant is ineligible for capital punishment if he cannot understand the nature and purpose of the punishment at the time of execution.
cards.mnemonic: KIDS DIM then COMP TRIAL, then COMP EXEC.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into four children: infancy, diminished capacity, competency to stand trial/sentencing, and competency for execution.
cards.clozeLite: Capacity doctrines include {{c1::infancy}}, {{c2::diminished capacity}}, {{c3::competency to stand trial or be sentenced}}, and {{c4::competency for execution}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 015. Capacity Defense
cards.backPlain: Intoxication: 1. Voluntary intoxication: 1.1 Only a defense to specific intent crimes. 1.2 Voluntary intoxication means the defendant chose to consume an intoxicant. 1.3 Alcoholics and addicts are considered voluntarily intoxicated. 1.4 Voluntary intoxication is not available as a defense if the defendant becomes intoxicated in order to commit the crime. 2. Involuntary intoxication: 2.1 A defense to all crimes. 2.2 Arises when the defendant was given an intoxicant without her knowledge or forced to consume an intoxicant. 2.3 Requirements: an intoxicant is taken involuntarily if taken: 2.3.1 Without knowledge of its nature, 2.3.2 Under direct duress imposed by another person, or 2.3.3 Pursuant to medical advice without notice of its intoxicating effect. 2.4 Involuntary intoxication may be treated as a mental illness if, because of the intoxication, the defendant satisfies the relevant jurisdiction's insanity test.
cards.frontPrompt: How do voluntary and involuntary intoxication operate as defenses in criminal law?
cards.cloze: Intoxication: 1. {{c1::Voluntary intoxication}}: 1.1 Only a defense to {{c2::specific intent crimes}}. 1.2 Voluntary intoxication means the defendant {{c3::chose to consume an intoxicant}}. 1.3 {{c4::Alcoholics and addicts}} are considered voluntarily intoxicated. 1.4 Voluntary intoxication is {{c5::not available}} as a defense if the defendant becomes intoxicated {{c6::in order to commit the crime}}. 2. {{c7::Involuntary intoxication}}: 2.1 A defense to {{c8::all crimes}}. 2.2 Arises when the defendant was given an intoxicant {{c9::without her knowledge}} or {{c10::forced to consume}} an intoxicant. 2.3 Requirements: an intoxicant is taken involuntarily if taken: 2.3.1 {{c11::Without knowledge of its nature}}, 2.3.2 Under {{c12::direct duress}} imposed by another person, or 2.3.3 Pursuant to {{c13::medical advice}} without notice of its intoxicating effect. 2.4 Involuntary intoxication may be treated as a {{c14::mental illness}} if, because of the intoxication, the defendant satisfies the relevant jurisdiction's {{c15::insanity test}}.
cards.easyContent: Voluntary intoxication can sometimes negate the specific intent required for specific intent crimes, but not for other crimes and not if the defendant got drunk to commit the crime. Involuntary intoxication—where the defendant did not knowingly or voluntarily take the intoxicant—is a defense to all crimes and can operate like insanity if it meets that test.
cards.mediumContent: Voluntary intoxication, where the defendant chooses to consume an intoxicant (including alcoholics and addicts), is a defense only to specific intent crimes and cannot be used if the defendant became intoxicated in order to commit the offense. Involuntary intoxication, which occurs when the defendant is drugged without knowledge, forced to ingest the substance, or takes it on medical advice without notice of its effects, is a defense to all crimes. If the involuntary intoxication results in a mental state that meets the jurisdiction’s insanity standard, it is treated like a mental illness for purposes of the insanity defense.
cards.hardContent: Voluntary intoxication exists when the defendant chooses to consume an intoxicant; even chronic alcoholics and addicts are treated as voluntarily intoxicated. It is only a defense to specific intent crimes, by potentially negating the required specific mens rea, and is unavailable where the defendant becomes intoxicated in order to commit the crime. Involuntary intoxication is a complete defense to all crimes when the intoxicant is taken without knowledge of its nature, under direct duress from another, or pursuant to medical advice without notice of its intoxicating effect. Where involuntary intoxication produces a mental condition that satisfies the applicable insanity test, the law treats it as a mental illness for purposes of an insanity defense.
cards.mnemonic: VI = Very limited (specific intent); II = Immunity if insanity-level.
cards.clozeLite: Voluntary intoxication is a defense only to {{c1::specific intent crimes}} and not if {{c2::intoxicated to commit the crime}}. {{c3::Involuntary intoxication}} is a defense to {{c4::all crimes}} and can operate like {{c5::insanity}} if that test is met.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 016. Justification Defense
cards.front: Self-Defense and Defense of Others – Overview
cards.backPlain: Justification defenses of self-defense and defense of others allow a defendant to use force, including in some cases deadly force, when certain conditions are met. 1. Non-deadly self-defense: A person who is not at fault may use proportionate non-deadly force when he reasonably believes it is necessary to protect himself from imminent unlawful force. There is generally no duty to retreat. 2. Deadly self-defense: A person who is not at fault may use deadly force when confronted with unlawful force and he reasonably believes he faces imminent death or great bodily harm. Under the majority rule, there is no duty to retreat before using deadly force. 3. Initial aggressor: An initial aggressor can regain the right to self-defense by effectively withdrawing and communicating that withdrawal, or when the victim unexpectedly escalates a minor confrontation into a deadly one. 4. Defense of others: The same basic rules apply as for self-defense. A defendant may use force to protect another when he reasonably believes the person he is protecting would be legally entitled to use that level of force in self-defense.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main justification rules governing self-defense (non-deadly and deadly), how can an initial aggressor regain self-defense, and how does defense of others relate to self-defense?
cards.cloze: Justification defenses of {{c1::self-defense}} and {{c2::defense of others}} allow a defendant to use {{c3::non-deadly}} or, in some circumstances, {{c4::deadly}} force when certain conditions are met. 1. {{c5::Non-deadly self-defense}}: A person who is {{c6::not at fault}} may use {{c7::proportionate non-deadly force}} when he {{c8::reasonably believes}} it is necessary to protect himself from {{c9::imminent unlawful force}}. There is generally {{c10::no duty to retreat}}. 2. {{c11::Deadly self-defense}}: A person who is not at fault may use deadly force when {{c12::confronted with unlawful force}} and he reasonably believes he faces {{c13::imminent death or great bodily harm}}. Under the {{c14::majority rule}}, there is {{c15::no duty to retreat}} before using deadly force. 3. {{c16::Initial aggressor}}: An initial aggressor can regain the right to self-defense by {{c17::effectively withdrawing and communicating that withdrawal}}, or when the victim {{c18::unexpectedly escalates a minor confrontation into a deadly one}}. 4. {{c19::Defense of others}}: The {{c20::same basic rules}} apply as for self-defense. A defendant may use force to protect another when he {{c21::reasonably believes}} the person he is protecting would be {{c22::legally entitled}} to use that level of force in self-defense.
cards.easyContent: Self-defense and defense of others are justification defenses that allow force, including deadly force, when strict requirements are met. Non-deadly force requires a reasonable belief in the need to repel imminent unlawful force with proportionate force and no duty to retreat. Deadly force requires being without fault, facing unlawful force, and reasonably believing in an imminent threat of death or great bodily harm, with no duty to retreat in most jurisdictions. Initial aggressors can sometimes regain self-defense, and defense of others applies the same standards based on reasonable belief.
cards.mediumContent: Self-defense allows non-deadly or deadly force when the defendant meets specific conditions regarding fault, unlawful force, reasonable belief, imminence, and proportionality. Non-deadly force is justified when a non-aggressor reasonably believes it is necessary to protect against imminent unlawful force, uses proportionate force, and need not retreat. Deadly force is justified when a non-aggressor is confronted with unlawful force and reasonably believes he faces imminent death or great bodily harm; the majority rule imposes no duty to retreat. An initial aggressor can regain self-defense by effectively withdrawing and clearly communicating it before the need for self-defense arises, or when the victim unexpectedly escalates a minor confrontation into a deadly one. Defense of others mirrors self-defense: a defendant may use force, including deadly force, when he reasonably believes the third person would be legally entitled to use that level of force in self-defense.
cards.hardContent: The justification defenses of self-defense and defense of others turn on structured requirements. For non-deadly self-defense, the defendant must not be the initial aggressor, must reasonably believe that non-deadly force is necessary to protect against imminent unlawful force, and must use force proportionate to the threat; there is generally no duty to retreat. For deadly self-defense, the defendant must be without fault, must be confronted with unlawful force, and must reasonably believe he faces imminent death or great bodily harm; under the majority rule, he has no duty to retreat before using deadly force. An initial aggressor may reclaim self-defense only if he effectively withdraws from the conflict and communicates that withdrawal before the need for self-defense arises, or if the victim unexpectedly escalates a minor dispute into a deadly altercation. Defense of others is governed by the same standards as self-defense: a defendant may use force, including deadly force if otherwise justified, when he reasonably believes that the person he protects would himself be legally entitled to use that level of force in self-defense.
cards.mnemonic: Self-defense = NURD: Not at fault, Unlawful force, Reasonable belief, Deadly threat.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into four children: (1) non-deadly self-defense, (2) deadly self-defense and duty to retreat, (3) initial aggressor rules, and (4) defense of others.
cards.clozeLite: Deadly self-defense requires {{c1::no fault}}, {{c2::unlawful force}}, and a {{c3::reasonable belief}} of {{c4::imminent death or great bodily harm}}, with {{c5::no duty to retreat (majority)}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.topic: Use of Force to Effectuate Arrest and Crime Prevention
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 017. Use of Force to Effectuate Arrest and Crime Prevention
cards.front: Use of Force to Effectuate Arrest and Crime Prevention – Overview
cards.backPlain: Use of force to make arrests and prevent crimes depends on: 1. Who is acting 1.1 Police 1.2 Private citizens 2. Level of force 2.1 Non-deadly force (NDF) 2.2 Deadly force (DF) 3. Purpose 3.1 Effectuating an arrest (police vs. citizen) 3.2 Preventing a crime (non-deadly vs. deadly; common-law vs. modern rules) At a high level: - Non-deadly force may be used as reasonably necessary to effectuate an arrest or prevent a serious breach of the peace. - Deadly force is tightly limited: generally to stop fleeing felons who pose a serious threat to life and to terminate or prevent dangerous, life‑threatening felonies (with broader allowances at common law than under modern law).
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main variables that govern when non-deadly or deadly force may be used to make an arrest or prevent a crime (consider police vs. citizens and common-law vs. modern rules)?
cards.cloze: Use of force to make arrests and prevent crimes depends on: 1. {{c1::Who is acting}} ({{c2::police}} vs. {{c3::private citizens}}) 2. {{c4::Level of force}} ({{c5::non-deadly}} vs. {{c6::deadly}}) 3. {{c7::Purpose}} ({{c8::effectuating an arrest}} vs. {{c9::preventing a crime}}, including {{c10::common-law}} vs. {{c11::modern}} crime‑prevention rules). Generally, {{c12::non-deadly force}} may be used as reasonably necessary to {{c13::effectuate an arrest}} or {{c14::prevent a serious breach of the peace}}, while {{c15::deadly force}} is limited to {{c16::fleeing felons who pose a serious threat to life}} and {{c17::dangerous, life‑threatening felonies}}.
cards.easyContent: Use of force rules vary by who is acting (police vs. citizen), the level of force (non-deadly vs. deadly), and whether the goal is arrest or crime prevention. Non-deadly force may reasonably aid arrest or peacekeeping; deadly force is reserved for dangerous, life‑threatening felonies and fleeing felons who pose serious danger.
cards.mediumContent: Use of force to arrest or prevent crime turns on: (1) actor (police vs. private citizen), (2) level of force (non-deadly vs. deadly), and (3) purpose (arrest vs. crime prevention, with different common-law and modern rules). Non-deadly force may be used as reasonably necessary to effectuate an arrest or prevent a serious breach of the peace. Deadly force is much more restricted: it is generally allowed only to stop fleeing felons who pose a serious danger to life and to terminate or prevent dangerous felonies that seriously threaten human life, with broader crime‑prevention authority at common law than under modern law.
cards.hardContent: The doctrine on use of force to effectuate arrests and prevent crimes is structured by: (1) the actor (police vs. private citizen), (2) the level of force (non-deadly vs. deadly), and (3) the purpose (arrest vs. crime prevention, including different standards for common-law vs. modern crime‑prevention rules). Across these contexts, non-deadly force may generally be used as reasonably necessary to make an arrest or prevent a serious breach of the peace. By contrast, deadly force is narrowly limited and typically requires both a felony and a significant threat to human life: police and citizens may use it to stop or prevent the escape of dangerous felons who threaten death or serious bodily harm, and deadly force for crime prevention is restricted under modern law to terminating or preventing dangerous, life‑threatening felonies (as opposed to the broader common-law allowance for any felony).
cards.mnemonic: Use force A-L-P: Actor, Level, Purpose.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) police use of force in arrest, (2) citizen’s arrest and use of force, and (3) crime‑prevention force (non-deadly and deadly; common law vs. modern).
cards.clozeLite: Use of force to arrest or prevent crime turns on {{c1::actor (police vs. citizen)}}, {{c2::level of force (non-deadly vs. deadly)}}, and {{c3::purpose (arrest vs. crime prevention, CL vs. modern)}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.topic: Defense of Dwelling or Other Property
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 018. Defense of Dwelling or Other Property
cards.front: Defense of Dwelling or Other Property
cards.backPlain: 1. Defense of dwelling 1.1 Non-deadly force: allowed to prevent or terminate an unlawful entry or attack on one's dwelling. 1.2 Deadly force: may be used if one reasonably believes 1.2.1 Force is necessary to prevent an attack on oneself or others by a person who made or attempted a violent entry; or 1.2.2 Force is necessary to prevent entry by a person who intends to commit a felony in the dwelling. 2. Defense of property (non-dwelling) 2.1 Deadly force is not allowed. 2.2 Non-deadly force may be used if reasonably necessary to defend against unlawful interference with possessions or trespass on property. 2.3 The need to use force must reasonably appear imminent; force is not permitted if a request to desist would be sufficient. 3. Recovery of property 3.1 Force is not allowed to regain property wrongfully taken, unless one is in immediate pursuit of the taker. 3.2 Example: D steals A's purse; A can only use reasonable force to recover the purse if she is immediately pursuing D.
cards.frontPrompt: When may a person use non-deadly or deadly force to defend a dwelling or other property, and under what conditions can force be used to recover property?
cards.cloze: 1. Defense of dwelling 1.1 {{c1::Non-deadly force}}: allowed to {{c2::prevent or terminate an unlawful entry or attack on one's dwelling}}. 1.2 {{c3::Deadly force}}: may be used if one reasonably believes 1.2.1 Force is necessary to {{c4::prevent an attack on oneself or others}} by a person who made or attempted a {{c5::violent entry}}; or 1.2.2 Force is necessary to {{c6::prevent entry by a person who intends to commit a felony in the dwelling}}. 2. Defense of property (non-dwelling) 2.1 {{c7::Deadly force is not allowed}}. 2.2 {{c8::Non-deadly force}} may be used if {{c9::reasonably necessary to defend against unlawful interference with possessions or trespass on property}}. 2.3 The need to use force must {{c10::reasonably appear imminent}}; force is not permitted if a {{c11::request to desist would be sufficient}}. 3. Recovery of property 3.1 Force is not allowed to regain property wrongfully taken, unless one is in {{c12::immediate pursuit}} of the taker. 3.2 Example: D steals A's purse; A can only use {{c13::reasonable force}} to recover the purse if she is {{c14::immediately pursuing}} D.
cards.easyContent: Non-deadly force may be used to stop unlawful entry into a dwelling or to protect property, but deadly force is limited to violent entries or felonious intrusions into a dwelling and is never allowed just to protect or recover property.
cards.mediumContent: To defend a dwelling, non-deadly force is allowed to prevent or end an unlawful entry or attack. Deadly force is permitted only when the defender reasonably believes it is necessary to prevent an attack by someone who made or attempted a violent entry, or to stop an entry by someone intending to commit a felony inside. For non-dwelling property, deadly force is never allowed; non-deadly force may be used when reasonably necessary to stop trespass or interference, and only when the need for force appears imminent and a request to desist would not suffice. Force to recover property is allowed only in immediate pursuit of the taker.
cards.hardContent: Defense of dwelling allows non-deadly force to prevent or terminate an unlawful entry or attack on the home. Deadly force in defense of dwelling is justified only if the occupant reasonably believes it is necessary either to prevent an attack on self or others by someone who made or attempted a violent entry, or to prevent entry by a person intending to commit a felony in the dwelling. For non-dwelling property, deadly force is not allowed merely to protect property. Non-deadly force may be used when reasonably necessary to defend against unlawful interference with possessions or trespass, but only when the need appears imminent; if asking the intruder to desist would be sufficient, force is not permitted. Force to recover property wrongfully taken is barred unless the owner is in immediate hot pursuit of the taker, in which case only reasonable non-deadly force may be used.
cards.mnemonic: HOME FELONY: Home Only, Murderous Entry or Felony, never for stuff.
cards.clozeLite: Deadly force to defend a {{c1::dwelling}} requires {{c2::violent entry or felony intent inside}} and a {{c3::reasonable belief}} it's necessary; {{c4::never for mere property}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 019. Necessity, Duress, and Consent
cards.backPlain: 1. Necessity 1.1 Necessity is a valid defense if the defendant believed his conduct was reasonably necessary to avoid an imminent and greater injury to society. 1.2 Objective standard: the defendant's commission of the crime must, in fact, be reasonably necessary; good faith alone is insufficient. 1.3 Exceptions: necessity is not available if either 1.3.1 The crime committed results in the death of another; or 1.3.2 The defendant caused the events giving rise to the necessity. 2. Duress 2.1 Duress is a valid defense to a crime the defendant committed under a reasonable belief that the crime was necessary to prevent death or serious bodily harm to the defendant or a member of the defendant's family. 2.2 Example: someone points a gun at the defendant and threatens to kill him if he does not rob a bank. 2.3 Exception: duress is not a defense to intentional homicide crimes. 3. Consent 3.1 Consent of the victim is generally not a defense, but may be available if it negates an element of the offense. 3.2 Consent is never available for certain offenses (e.g., statutory rape). 3.3 Requirements: to be valid, it must be established that 3.3.1 Consent was voluntarily and freely given; 3.3.2 The party was legally capable of consenting; and 3.3.3 No fraud was involved in obtaining consent.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the rules and key limitations for the defenses of necessity, duress, and consent in criminal law?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Necessity}} 1.1 Necessity is a valid defense if the defendant believed his conduct was {{c2::reasonably necessary to avoid an imminent and greater injury to society}}. 1.2 {{c3::Objective standard}}: the defendant's commission of the crime must, in fact, be reasonably necessary; {{c4::good faith alone is insufficient}}. 1.3 Exceptions: necessity is not available if either 1.3.1 The crime committed {{c5::results in the death of another}}; or 1.3.2 The defendant {{c6::caused the events giving rise to the necessity}}. 2. {{c7::Duress}} 2.1 Duress is a valid defense to a crime the defendant committed under a {{c8::reasonable belief}} that the crime was necessary to {{c9::prevent death or serious bodily harm}} to the defendant or a member of the defendant's family. 2.2 Example: someone points a gun at the defendant and threatens to kill him if he does not rob a bank. 2.3 Exception: duress is {{c10::not a defense to intentional homicide crimes}}. 3. {{c11::Consent}} 3.1 Consent of the victim is generally {{c12::not a defense}}, but may be available if it {{c13::negates an element of the offense}}. 3.2 Consent is {{c14::never available for certain offenses}} (e.g., statutory rape). 3.3 Requirements: to be valid, it must be established that 3.3.1 Consent was {{c15::voluntarily and freely given}}; 3.3.2 The party was {{c16::legally capable of consenting}}; and 3.3.3 {{c17::No fraud}} was involved in obtaining consent.
cards.easyContent: Necessity excuses a crime done to avoid a greater imminent harm, duress excuses crimes done under threat of death or serious harm (but not intentional homicide), and consent is rarely a defense except when valid consent negates an element of the offense.
cards.mediumContent: Necessity applies when the defendant reasonably and objectively had to break the law to avoid an imminent, greater societal harm; it is unavailable if the defendant caused the emergency or if the crime kills another. Duress applies when the defendant reasonably believes a crime is necessary to prevent death or serious bodily harm to self or family, but it cannot justify intentional homicide. Consent is generally no defense, but can be when valid consent negates an element of the crime; it requires voluntary, informed consent from a legally capable person, without fraud, and is never allowed for certain offenses like statutory rape.
