cards.hardContent: Necessity is a justification defense where the defendant believed, and it was objectively reasonable, that committing the offense was necessary to avert an imminent, greater injury to society. It is barred if the defendant caused the situation creating the necessity or if the crime results in the death of another. Duress is an excuse defense when the defendant, under a reasonable belief, commits a crime to prevent death or serious bodily harm to self or a family member, such as when threatened at gunpoint to rob a bank; however, duress is not a defense to intentional homicide offenses. Consent of the victim is generally not a defense, but may be when it negates an element of the crime (e.g., lack of consent). Valid consent must be voluntary and freely given, by a party legally capable of consenting, and must not be procured by fraud; it is categorically unavailable for certain crimes such as statutory rape.
cards.mnemonic: N-D-C: Necessity saves society, Duress saves self, Consent cancels crime element.
cards.clozeLite: Necessity {{c1::justifies breaking the law}} to avoid {{c2::imminent greater harm}}, but not {{c3::if D caused the emergency or killing results}}. Duress {{c4::never excuses intentional homicide}}. Consent must be {{c5::voluntary, informed, and legally valid}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 020. Entrapment
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule 1.1 Entrapment is an available defense to criminal liability if a law enforcement agent has induced the defendant to commit a crime. 2. Required elements 2.1 Criminal design originated with law enforcement: the criminal design is the idea or plan for the crime. 2.2 The defendant was not otherwise predisposed to commit the crime: 2.2.1 The defendant must have had no predisposition to commit the given crime prior to his contact with law enforcement. 2.2.2 Law enforcement providing an opportunity for a person to commit a crime is not, by itself, entrapment. 2.2.3 Example: an undercover officer buys drugs from a dealer; the officer merely provided an opportunity for the defendant to make a sale. Note: this is a very narrow defense and is rarely effective because it is negated by any predisposition on the defendant's part; as a result, it is unlikely to be a correct MBE answer.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the defense of entrapment, and what elements must a defendant show to establish it?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule 1.1 {{c1::Entrapment}} is an available defense to criminal liability if a {{c2::law enforcement agent has induced the defendant to commit a crime}}. 2. Required elements 2.1 {{c3::Criminal design originated with law enforcement}}: the criminal design is the {{c4::idea or plan for the crime}}. 2.2 The defendant was {{c5::not otherwise predisposed to commit the crime}}: 2.2.1 The defendant must have had {{c6::no predisposition to commit the given crime prior to his contact with law enforcement}}. 2.2.2 {{c7::Law enforcement providing an opportunity}} for a person to commit a crime is {{c8::not, by itself, entrapment}}. 2.2.3 Example: an {{c9::undercover officer}} buys drugs from a dealer; the officer merely provided an opportunity for the defendant to make a sale. Note: this is a {{c10::very narrow defense}} and is {{c11::rarely effective}} because it is negated by any predisposition on the defendant's part; as a result, it is {{c12::unlikely to be a correct MBE answer}}.
cards.easyContent: Entrapment occurs when law enforcement originates the criminal plan and induces the defendant, who was not otherwise predisposed, to commit the crime; merely providing an opportunity is not enough.
cards.mediumContent: Entrapment is a narrow defense where a law enforcement agent induces the defendant to commit a crime whose design or idea originated with law enforcement, and the defendant lacked predisposition to commit that offense before the contact. If the defendant was predisposed, or if police only provided an opportunity (like an undercover buy), there is no entrapment, making it an unlikely correct answer on the MBE.
cards.hardContent: Entrapment is an affirmative defense to criminal liability available when the government is the source of the criminal idea and induces the defendant to act despite his lack of predisposition. The criminal design must originate with law enforcement, meaning the idea or plan for the crime comes from the government, and the defendant must not have been predisposed to commit that type of offense before any government contact. Police merely affording an opportunity to commit a crime—such as an undercover officer purchasing contraband from a willing dealer—does not constitute entrapment. Because any evidence of predisposition defeats the claim, entrapment is a very narrow, rarely successful defense and is seldom the correct choice on MBE questions.
cards.mnemonic: "Gov’t plants the seed, D not the weed": criminal idea from gov’t, no predisposition.
cards.clozeLite: Entrapment requires that {{c1::law enforcement originate the criminal design}} and {{c2::induce the defendant}} who {{c3::lacked predisposition}} to commit the offense.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 021. Mistake of Law or Fact
cards.backPlain: 1. Mistake of law 1.1 Mistake of law is almost never a defense. 1.2 Lacking awareness or knowledge that an act constitutes a crime, even if reasonable, is not a defense to that crime. 1.3 Exceptions (rare): a mistake of law can be a defense where either 1.3.1 The defendant reasonably relied on an invalid statute or official interpretation; or 1.3.2 The mistake or ignorance negates an element of a crime requiring knowledge of the law. 2. Mistake of fact 2.1 Mistake of fact is available as a defense only if it negates a requisite intent element (i.e., mens rea) for the crime. Note: mistake includes ignorance. 3. Requisite mens rea element and availability of mistake of fact defense 3.1 Specific intent: any mistake of fact is a defense. 3.2 Malice and general intent: only a reasonable mistake of fact is a defense. 3.3 Strict liability (i.e., no intent): mistake of fact is never a defense.
cards.frontPrompt: How do mistake of law and mistake of fact operate as defenses, and how does the required mens rea affect the availability of a mistake-of-fact defense?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Mistake of law}} 1.1 Mistake of law is {{c2::almost never a defense}}. 1.2 Lacking awareness or knowledge that an act constitutes a crime, even if reasonable, is {{c3::not a defense}} to that crime. 1.3 Exceptions (rare): a mistake of law can be a defense where either 1.3.1 The defendant {{c4::reasonably relied on an invalid statute or official interpretation}}; or 1.3.2 The mistake or ignorance {{c5::negates an element of a crime requiring knowledge of the law}}. 2. {{c6::Mistake of fact}} 2.1 Mistake of fact is available as a defense only if it {{c7::negates a requisite intent element (mens rea)}} for the crime. Note: mistake includes ignorance. 3. Requisite mens rea element and availability of mistake of fact defense 3.1 {{c8::Specific intent}}: {{c9::any mistake of fact}} is a defense. 3.2 {{c10::Malice and general intent}}: only a {{c11::reasonable}} mistake of fact is a defense. 3.3 {{c12::Strict liability}} (i.e., no intent): {{c13::mistake of fact is never a defense}}.
cards.easyContent: Mistake of law almost never excuses crime, while mistake of fact can be a defense only when it negates mens rea—broadly for specific-intent crimes, more narrowly for general-intent crimes, and never for strict-liability offenses.
cards.mediumContent: Mistake of law is generally no defense; not knowing conduct is illegal does not excuse liability. Rare exceptions exist when the defendant reasonably relies on an invalid statute or official interpretation, or where the crime requires knowledge of the law and the mistake negates that element. Mistake of fact can be a defense only if it negates the required intent: for specific-intent crimes, any mistake (reasonable or not) suffices; for malice or general-intent crimes, only a reasonable mistake works; and for strict-liability crimes, no mistake-of-fact defense is available.
cards.hardContent: Mistake of law is almost never a defense to criminal liability; a defendant's lack of awareness that conduct is criminal, even if reasonable, does not excuse the offense. Limited exceptions arise when the defendant reasonably relies on an invalid statute or official interpretation, or when a statute makes knowledge of the law an element and the defendant's mistake or ignorance negates that element. By contrast, mistake of fact is potentially exculpatory, but only when it negates the crime’s mens rea. For specific-intent crimes, any factual mistake—whether reasonable or unreasonable—can defeat the specific intent. For malice and general-intent crimes, only a reasonable mistake of fact is a defense. For strict-liability offenses, which require no mental state, mistake of fact is never a defense, regardless of reasonableness.
cards.mnemonic: S-G-S: Specific-any; General-reasonable; Strict-none.
cards.clozeLite: Mistake of {{c1::law}} is almost never a defense. Mistake of {{c2::fact}} is a defense only if it {{c3::negates mens rea}}, and never for {{c4::strict-liability}} crimes.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 022. Assault and Battery
cards.backPlain: 1. Assault (two theories of assault at common law): 1.1 Assault as a threat (general intent crime): 1.1.1 Intentional creation of the victim's reasonable apprehension of imminent bodily harm; and 1.1.2 Words alone are usually insufficient. 1.2 Assault as an attempted battery (specific intent crime): 1.2.1 Specific intent crime because it involves attempt; and 1.2.2 Both assault as a threat and assault as an attempted battery constitute assault for MBE purposes unless instructed otherwise. 2. Battery (general intent crime): 2.1 An unlawful application of force to the person of another resulting in bodily injury or offensive touching (this is a completed assault); and 2.2 Under modern statutes, both assault and battery have aggravated counterparts, which usually arise when the assault or battery is carried out with the use of a weapon.
cards.frontPrompt: In criminal law, what are the two common-law theories of assault, and what is the definition of battery?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Assault}} (two theories of assault at common law): 1.1 Assault as a {{c2::threat}} ({{c3::general intent}} crime): 1.1.1 {{c4::Intentional creation of the victim's reasonable apprehension of imminent bodily harm}}; and 1.1.2 {{c5::Words alone are usually insufficient}}. 1.2 Assault as an {{c6::attempted battery}} ({{c7::specific intent}} crime): 1.2.1 Specific intent crime because it involves {{c8::attempt}}; and 1.2.2 Both assault as a threat and assault as an attempted battery constitute assault for {{c9::MBE purposes}} unless instructed otherwise. 2. {{c10::Battery}} (general intent crime): 2.1 An {{c11::unlawful application of force to the person of another resulting in bodily injury or offensive touching}} (this is a completed assault); and 2.2 Under modern statutes, both assault and battery have {{c12::aggravated}} counterparts, which usually arise when the assault or battery is carried out with the use of a {{c13::weapon}}.
cards.easyContent: Assault is either intentionally causing reasonable apprehension of imminent bodily harm or attempting a battery, and battery is the unlawful application of force resulting in bodily injury or offensive touching.
cards.mediumContent: Assault is a common-law crime that can be committed either by: (1) intentionally creating the victim's reasonable apprehension of imminent bodily harm (a general intent crime, and words alone are usually insufficient), or (2) attempting a battery (a specific intent crime because it is an attempt). Battery is the unlawful application of force to another person resulting in bodily injury or offensive touching and is a general intent crime.
cards.hardContent: At common law, assault has two forms: (1) assault as a threat, a general intent crime, which is the intentional creation of the victim's reasonable apprehension of imminent bodily harm, and words alone are usually insufficient; and (2) assault as an attempted battery, a specific intent crime because it involves an attempt. Both forms are treated as assault for MBE purposes unless the question specifies otherwise. Battery is a general intent crime defined as the unlawful application of force to the person of another resulting in bodily injury or offensive touching—a completed assault. Under modern statutes, both assault and battery have aggravated counterparts, usually when a weapon is used.
cards.mnemonic: T-A-B: Threat-assault, Attempted battery-assault, completed Battery.
cards.clozeLite: Common-law {{c1::assault}} is either {{c2::intentionally creating reasonable apprehension of imminent bodily harm}} or {{c3::attempting a battery}}. {{c4::Battery}} is the {{c5::unlawful application of force causing bodily injury or offensive touching}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 023. Rape
cards.backPlain: Rape (often now called sexual assault or sexual battery) generally involves non-consensual sexual intercourse or penetration. 1. Common law focused on unlawful carnal knowledge of a woman by a man not her husband and without effective consent. 2. Modern statutes have largely removed the marital requirement, often relabel the offense as sexual assault or sexual battery, and provide that even the slightest penetration completes the crime. 3. Lack of consent can be based on force or threats, incapacity to consent (e.g., unconsciousness or extreme intoxication), or certain frauds about the nature of the act—but mere deceit about collateral matters (like a promise to marry) is not enough without lack of contemporaneous consent or capacity.
cards.frontPrompt: At a high level, how do the elements of rape/sexual assault differ between common law and modern statutes, and what are the main ways lack of consent can be established?
cards.cloze: Rape (now often called {{c1::sexual assault or sexual battery}}) generally involves {{c2::non-consensual sexual intercourse or penetration}}. 1. At {{c3::common law}}, rape required unlawful carnal knowledge of a woman by a man not her husband and without effective consent. 2. {{c4::Modern statutes}} typically remove the {{c5::marital requirement}}, require only the {{c6::slightest penetration}}, and focus on {{c7::lack of consent or capacity}}. 3. Lack of consent is usually shown by {{c8::force or threats}}, {{c9::incapacity}} (e.g., unconsciousness, intoxication), or certain {{c10::frauds about the nature of the act}}, but not by mere {{c11::deceit about collateral matters}} such as a promise to marry.
cards.easyContent: Rape/sexual assault is non-consensual intercourse or penetration. Common law required unlawful carnal knowledge of a woman by a non-husband without consent. Modern statutes remove the marital requirement, require only slight penetration, and focus on lack of consent shown by force/threat, incapacity, or certain frauds—not just lies about collateral matters like a promise to marry.
cards.mediumContent: At common law, rape was unlawful carnal knowledge of a woman by a man other than her husband and without effective consent. Modern statutes typically call the offense sexual assault or sexual battery, abolish the marital-status element, and provide that the slightest penetration is sufficient. Lack of consent is generally established by (1) force or threat of immediate bodily harm, (2) incapacity (e.g., unconsciousness or intoxication), or (3) fraud about the nature of the act, but fraud alone—such as a mere promise to marry—is not rape unless it results in penetration without contemporaneous consent or capacity.
cards.hardContent: Rape, often termed sexual assault or sexual battery under modern statutes, consists of non-consensual sexual intercourse or penetration. Common-law rape required: (1) unlawful carnal knowledge; (2) of a woman; (3) by a man other than her husband; and (4) without effective consent. Modern statutes generally (a) relabel the offense as sexual assault or sexual battery, (b) treat the slightest penetration as sufficient to complete the offense, and (c) make marital status insignificant, abolishing it as an element in most jurisdictions. Lack of consent is found where: (1) penetration is accomplished by force or threat of immediate bodily harm; (2) the victim is incapable of consenting due to lack of capacity (e.g., unconsciousness, extreme intoxication, or similar conditions); or (3) the victim is fraudulently caused to believe the act is not intercourse. However, fraud or trickery alone does not constitute rape unless there is penetration without contemporaneous consent or capacity—for example, convincing someone to have intercourse based solely on a false promise of marriage is not rape absent lack of consent or capacity at the time of the act.
cards.mnemonic: Lack of consent in rape: FIC—Force, Incapacity, Confusion about intercourse.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into (1) common-law rape definition, (2) modern statutory changes to rape, and (3) lack-of-consent grounds and fraud distinctions.
cards.clozeLite: Common-law {{c1::rape}} required {{c2::unlawful carnal knowledge of a woman by a non-husband without effective consent}}. Modern statutes focus on {{c3::slight penetration}} and {{c4::lack of consent by force/threat, incapacity, or fraud about the nature of the act}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 024. False Imprisonment and Kidnapping
cards.backPlain: 1. False imprisonment: 1.1 The unlawful confinement of a person; 1.2 Without their consent; and 1.3 Consent cannot be obtained through coercion, threat, or deception. 2. Kidnapping: 2.1 The unlawful confinement of a person that involves either: 2.1.1 Some movement of the victim (asportation); or 2.1.2 Concealment of the victim in an unknown, hidden, or secret location. 2.1.3 Note: false imprisonment can become kidnapping if the victim is moved and/or concealed.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the elements of false imprisonment, and how does kidnapping differ from false imprisonment in criminal law?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::False imprisonment}}: 1.1 The {{c2::unlawful confinement}} of a person; 1.2 {{c3::Without their consent}}; and 1.3 Consent cannot be obtained through {{c4::coercion, threat, or deception}}. 2. {{c5::Kidnapping}}: 2.1 The unlawful confinement of a person that involves either: 2.1.1 Some {{c6::movement of the victim}} ({{c7::asportation}}); or 2.1.2 {{c8::Concealment}} of the victim in an unknown, hidden, or secret location. 2.1.3 Note: {{c9::false imprisonment can become kidnapping if the victim is moved and/or concealed}}.
cards.easyContent: False imprisonment is the unlawful confinement of a person without valid consent. Kidnapping adds either movement (asportation) or concealment in a hidden or unknown place.
cards.mediumContent: False imprisonment consists of unlawfully confining a person without their consent, where consent is invalid if obtained by coercion, threat, or deception. Kidnapping is unlawful confinement plus either movement of the victim (asportation) or concealment of the victim in an unknown, hidden, or secret place, so false imprisonment becomes kidnapping when the victim is moved or concealed.
cards.hardContent: False imprisonment is the unlawful confinement of a person without their consent, and consent is not valid if it is obtained through coercion, threat, or deception. Kidnapping builds on false imprisonment: it is unlawful confinement that additionally involves either some movement of the victim (asportation) or concealment of the victim in an unknown, hidden, or secret location. Thus, conduct that begins as false imprisonment can rise to kidnapping once the victim is moved or concealed.
cards.mnemonic: Kidnapping = False imprisonment plus "M or C": Movement or Concealment.
cards.clozeLite: False imprisonment is {{c1::unlawful confinement}} of a person {{c2::without valid consent}}. {{c3::Kidnapping}} is false imprisonment plus {{c4::movement (asportation)}} or {{c5::concealment in a hidden or unknown place}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 025. Murder
cards.backPlain: Common-law murder is the unlawful killing of another human being with malice aforethought, and the defendant must actually and proximately cause the victim’s death. Malice aforethought can be satisfied by four mental states: intent to kill, intent to inflict great bodily injury, depraved-heart recklessness, or felony murder (a killing during an inherently dangerous or statutorily enumerated felony). For felony murder, the only intent required is the intent to commit the underlying felony. Any act by the defendant that hastens the victim’s death is treated as a cause, even if death was already inevitable.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the basic definition of common-law murder, what mental states satisfy malice aforethought (including felony murder), and what causation is required?
cards.cloze: Common-law murder is the {{c1::unlawful killing of another human being with malice aforethought}}, and the defendant must {{c2::actually and proximately cause}} the victim’s death. Malice aforethought can be satisfied by four mental states: {{c3::intent to kill}}, {{c4::intent to inflict great bodily injury}}, {{c5::depraved-heart recklessness}}, or {{c6::felony murder}} (a killing during an {{c7::inherently dangerous or statutorily enumerated felony}}). For felony murder, the only intent required is the {{c8::intent to commit the underlying felony}}. Any act by the defendant that {{c9::hastens the victim’s death}} is treated as a cause, even if death was already inevitable.
cards.easyContent: Common-law murder is the unlawful killing of another human being with malice aforethought, proven by four possible mental states (including felony murder), plus actual and proximate causation of death.
cards.mediumContent: Common-law murder is the unlawful killing of another human being with malice aforethought. Malice aforethought is shown by intent to kill, intent to cause great bodily injury, depraved-heart recklessness, or felony murder (a killing during an inherently dangerous or statutorily enumerated felony, with only the intent to commit the underlying felony required). The defendant must actually and proximately cause the victim’s death, and any act that hastens death is sufficient causation.
cards.hardContent: At common law, murder is the unlawful killing of another human being with malice aforethought. Malice aforethought exists when there are no mitigating circumstances and the defendant kills with any of four mental states: (1) intent to kill; (2) intent to inflict great bodily injury; (3) depraved or malignant heart, meaning reckless indifference to an unjustifiable risk of human life; or (4) felony murder, where the killing occurs during the attempt or commission of an inherently dangerous or statutorily enumerated felony, and the only mens rea required is the intent to commit the underlying felony. Causation requires that the defendant’s act be both the actual and proximate cause of the victim’s death, and any act that hastens death, even if death was inevitable, satisfies causation.
cards.mnemonic: Malice = KBI-F: Kill, Bodily injury, Indifference, Felony.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into (1) definition and malice mental states and (2) felony murder details and causation.
cards.clozeLite: Common-law {{c1::murder}} is the unlawful {{c2::killing of another human being}} with {{c3::malice aforethought}} ({{c4::intent to kill, intent for great bodily injury, depraved-heart recklessness, or felony murder}}) plus {{c5::actual and proximate causation of death}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.topic: Statutory Modifications to Common Law Murder
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 026. Statutory Modifications to Common Law Murder
cards.front: Statutory Modifications to Common Law Murder
cards.backPlain: Most jurisdictions classify murder crimes into various degrees by statute. 1. First-degree murder (arises if a killing is either): 1.1 Deliberate and premeditated: 1.1.1 The defendant must have killed in a dispassionate manner; and 1.1.2 The defendant must have considered or reflected on the killing, even if only momentarily. 1.1.3 It is a specific intent crime, so voluntary intoxication and mistake of fact are valid defenses. 1.2 Felony murder: a killing during an enumerated felony. Many states list felonies that may serve as the basis for felony murder. 2. Second-degree murder: 2.1 A homicide that does not rise to first-degree murder. 2.2 Note: if first-degree murder is not mentioned as a possibility in an MBE question or in the answer choices, assume the question involves second-degree murder, which is often the default category on the MBE.
cards.frontPrompt: How do modern statutes classify murder into first and second degree, and what are the requirements for first-degree murder?
cards.cloze: Most jurisdictions classify murder crimes into various {{c1::degrees}} by statute. 1. {{c2::First-degree murder}} (arises if a killing is either): 1.1 {{c3::Deliberate and premeditated}}: 1.1.1 The defendant must have killed in a {{c4::dispassionate}} manner; and 1.1.2 The defendant must have {{c5::considered or reflected on the killing, even if only momentarily}}. 1.1.3 It is a {{c6::specific intent}} crime, so {{c7::voluntary intoxication}} and {{c8::mistake of fact}} are valid defenses. 1.2 {{c9::Felony murder}}: a killing during an {{c10::enumerated felony}}. Many states list felonies that may serve as the basis for felony murder. 2. {{c11::Second-degree murder}}: 2.1 A {{c12::homicide that does not rise to first-degree murder}}. 2.2 Note: if first-degree murder is not mentioned as a possibility in an MBE question or in the answer choices, assume the question involves {{c13::second-degree murder}}, which is often the {{c14::default category}} on the MBE.
cards.easyContent: Modern statutes usually classify murder by degree. First-degree murder is deliberate and premeditated or felony murder based on an enumerated felony; all other common-law murders are typically second-degree.
cards.mediumContent: Statutory schemes commonly divide murder into degrees. First-degree murder includes deliberate and premeditated killings—where the defendant kills in a dispassionate manner and has reflected on the decision, even briefly—and is a specific intent crime, so voluntary intoxication and mistake of fact can be defenses. First-degree also often includes felony murder based on listed felonies. Second-degree murder is any murder that does not qualify as first degree and functions as the default category when degree is not specified on the MBE.
cards.hardContent: Most jurisdictions classify murder into degrees by statute. First-degree murder includes: (1) deliberate and premeditated killings, where the defendant kills in a dispassionate manner and has considered or reflected on the killing, even momentarily; and (2) felony murder, where the killing occurs during the commission or attempt of an enumerated felony specified by statute. Because deliberate and premeditated murder is a specific intent crime, voluntary intoxication and mistake of fact may negate the required mens rea. Second-degree murder is any homicide that does not rise to first-degree murder, encompassing other killings with malice aforethought. On the MBE, if first-degree murder is not mentioned in the facts or answer choices, you generally assume the question is testing second-degree murder as the default.
cards.mnemonic: First degree = "DP + F": Deliberate & Premeditated or Felony murder.
cards.clozeLite: First-degree murder includes {{c1::deliberate and premeditated killings}} and {{c2::felony murder based on enumerated felonies}}, and is a {{c3::specific intent}} crime.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 027. Felony Murder
cards.backPlain: Felony murder is a homicide that occurs during the attempt or commission of certain qualifying felonies. The only intent required is the intent to commit the underlying felony. Qualifying felonies are typically inherently dangerous or specifically enumerated by statute, such as burglary, arson, rape, robbery, and kidnapping. Felony-murder liability is limited: the defendant must be guilty of an independent underlying felony, defenses to that felony carry over to felony murder, the death must be a foreseeable result of the felony and occur before the defendant reaches a place of temporary safety, and most jurisdictions do not impose liability for a co-felon killed by police or the victim.
cards.frontPrompt: What is felony murder in general terms, and what are the main types of qualifying felonies and key limitations on felony-murder liability?
cards.cloze: {{c1::Felony murder}} is a homicide that occurs during the attempt or commission of certain qualifying felonies. The only intent required is the {{c2::intent to commit the underlying felony}}. Qualifying felonies are typically {{c3::inherently dangerous or specifically enumerated by statute}}, such as {{c4::burglary, arson, rape, robbery, and kidnapping}}. Felony-murder liability is limited: the defendant must be {{c5::guilty of an independent underlying felony (merger doctrine)}}, {{c6::defenses to the felony apply to felony murder}}, the death must be a {{c7::foreseeable result that occurs before the defendant reaches a place of temporary safety}}, and {{c8::most jurisdictions do not impose liability for a co-felon killed by police or the victim}}.
cards.easyContent: Felony murder is a killing during the attempt or commission of a qualifying felony (usually inherently dangerous or statutorily listed), with only the intent to commit that felony, and subject to important limits like merger, foreseeability, timing, and co-felon death rules.
cards.mediumContent: Felony murder is a homicide that occurs during the attempt or commission of an inherently dangerous or statutorily enumerated felony, where the required mens rea is just the intent to commit the underlying felony. The felony must be independent of the killing, defenses to the felony are defenses to felony murder, and liability is limited by causation, timing (before reaching a place of temporary safety), and rules about co-felon deaths.
cards.hardContent: Felony murder is a killing that occurs during the attempt or commission of certain qualifying felonies. The mental state is satisfied by the intent required for the underlying felony itself. Qualifying felonies are typically inherently dangerous or those specifically enumerated in a statute, and common predicates include burglary, arson, rape, robbery, and kidnapping. Felony-murder liability is constrained: the defendant must actually be guilty of an underlying felony that does not merge into the homicide, any valid defense to that felony is also a defense to felony murder, the death must be a foreseeable (proximate) result that occurs before the defendant reaches a place of temporary safety, and most jurisdictions do not impose felony-murder liability for a co-felon killed by law enforcement or the original victim.
cards.mnemonic: BAARK: Burglary, Arson, Assault, Robbery, Kidnapping as common predicates.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) definition and mental state, (2) qualifying felonies, (3) limitations, including merger and co-felon death rule.
cards.clozeLite: Felony murder is a homicide during an {{c1::inherently dangerous or statutorily enumerated felony}}, with mens rea of {{c2::intent to commit the felony}} and limits like {{c3::merger}}, {{c4::foreseeability}}, and {{c5::timing before temporary safety}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 028. Voluntary Manslaughter
cards.backPlain: Voluntary manslaughter is a killing that would otherwise be murder but is mitigated when it results from either: (1) adequate provocation (a heat of passion killing), or (2) imperfect self-defense (in jurisdictions that recognize it). Adequate provocation requires both objective and subjective loss of self-control and that neither a reasonable person nor the defendant actually cooled off before the killing; when proven, it mitigates murder to voluntary manslaughter. Imperfect self-defense applies where the defendant kills while purporting to act in self-defense but either initiated the confrontation or unreasonably believed deadly force was necessary; in jurisdictions that recognize the doctrine, this mitigates murder to voluntary manslaughter.
cards.frontPrompt: What is voluntary manslaughter, and what are the two main doctrines that mitigate murder to voluntary manslaughter?
cards.cloze: Voluntary manslaughter is a {{c1::killing that would otherwise be murder}} but is mitigated when it results from either {{c2::adequate provocation (a heat of passion killing)}} or {{c3::imperfect self-defense}} (in jurisdictions that recognize it). Adequate provocation mitigates murder when strong provocation causes loss of self-control without sufficient cooling-off, and imperfect self-defense mitigates when the defendant kills while purporting to act in self-defense but either started the confrontation or unreasonably believed deadly force was necessary.
cards.easyContent: Voluntary manslaughter is a killing that would otherwise be murder but is mitigated if it occurs either in the heat of passion due to adequate provocation or under imperfect self-defense (where recognized).
cards.mediumContent: Voluntary manslaughter is a mitigated form of murder. It arises when: (1) the defendant kills in the heat of passion after adequate provocation, without sufficient cooling-off, or (2) the defendant kills while acting in imperfect self-defense—having started the confrontation or unreasonably believing deadly force was necessary—in a jurisdiction that recognizes imperfect self-defense. Both doctrines reduce what would be murder to voluntary manslaughter rather than providing a complete defense.
cards.hardContent: Voluntary manslaughter is a killing that would otherwise be murder but is reduced to manslaughter when either (1) adequate provocation (heat of passion) is shown, or (2) imperfect self-defense applies in jurisdictions that recognize it. Adequate provocation requires objective and subjective loss of self-control, no sufficient cooling-off period for a reasonable person, and that the defendant in fact did not cool off; it is not a complete defense but mitigates murder to voluntary manslaughter. Imperfect self-defense mitigates murder when the defendant kills while purporting to act in self-defense but either initiated the altercation or unreasonably believed deadly force was necessary; some jurisdictions do not recognize this doctrine.
cards.mnemonic: VOL MAN: Very Old Murder, Lessened by Anger or Not-great self-defense.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into two children: (1) definition of voluntary manslaughter and adequate provocation elements, (2) imperfect self-defense rule and limits.
cards.clozeLite: Voluntary manslaughter is {{c1::a mitigated form of murder}} when there is {{c2::adequate provocation (heat of passion)}} or {{c3::imperfect self-defense}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 029. Involuntary Manslaughter
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule: Involuntary manslaughter is a killing committed with criminal negligence or during the commission of an unlawful act not constituting felony murder. 2. Criminal negligence: 2.1 Arises if the defendant is grossly negligent. 2.2 Example: The defendant is texting while driving and hits and kills a pedestrian in a crosswalk. 3. Commission of an unlawful act: 3.1 A killing caused by an unlawful act may give rise to involuntary manslaughter. 3.2 Misdemeanors: A killing resulting from a misdemeanor will give rise to involuntary manslaughter if either: 3.2.1 The act was inherently wrongful (i.e., malum in se), or 3.2.2 Death was a foreseeable or natural consequence of the misdemeanor act (i.e., malum prohibitum). 3.3 Felonies: Any killing caused during the commission of a felony not giving rise to felony murder will be at least involuntary manslaughter. 4. Exam note: If MBE questions simply state "manslaughter" without distinguishing between voluntary and involuntary manslaughter, both types must be considered.
cards.frontPrompt: What is involuntary manslaughter, and how do criminal negligence and unlawful acts (misdemeanors and non-felony-murder felonies) give rise to it?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule: {{c1::Involuntary manslaughter}} is a killing committed with {{c2::criminal negligence}} or during the commission of an {{c3::unlawful act not constituting felony murder}}. 2. Criminal negligence: 2.1 Arises if the defendant is {{c4::grossly negligent}}. 2.2 Example: The defendant is {{c5::texting while driving}} and hits and kills a pedestrian in a crosswalk. 3. Commission of an unlawful act: 3.1 A killing caused by an {{c6::unlawful act}} may give rise to involuntary manslaughter. 3.2 Misdemeanors: A killing resulting from a misdemeanor will give rise to involuntary manslaughter if either: 3.2.1 The act was {{c7::inherently wrongful (malum in se)}}, or 3.2.2 Death was a {{c8::foreseeable or natural consequence}} of the misdemeanor act ({{c9::malum prohibitum}}). 3.3 Felonies: Any killing caused during the commission of a {{c10::felony not giving rise to felony murder}} will be at least involuntary manslaughter. 4. Exam note: If MBE questions simply state {{c11::"manslaughter"}} without distinguishing between voluntary and involuntary manslaughter, {{c12::both types must be considered}}.
cards.easyContent: Involuntary manslaughter is an unintentional killing caused by criminal negligence or by committing an unlawful act that does not qualify for felony murder.
cards.mediumContent: Involuntary manslaughter is a killing committed either with criminal negligence—gross negligence by the defendant—or during an unlawful act that is not felony murder. For misdemeanors, the killing qualifies if the act is inherently wrongful (malum in se) or if death is a foreseeable or natural consequence of a malum prohibitum misdemeanor; any killing during a non–felony-murder felony is at least involuntary manslaughter.
cards.hardContent: Involuntary manslaughter is a killing committed without an intent to kill, either through criminal negligence or during the commission of an unlawful act that does not constitute felony murder. Criminal negligence arises when the defendant is grossly negligent, such as texting while driving and killing a pedestrian. A killing caused by an unlawful act may also support involuntary manslaughter: for misdemeanors, liability arises if the act is inherently wrongful (malum in se) or if death is a foreseeable or natural consequence of a malum prohibitum offense; for felonies that do not qualify for felony murder, any resulting killing will be at least involuntary manslaughter. On exams, if a question uses the term "manslaughter" without specifying voluntary or involuntary, both must be analyzed.
cards.mnemonic: Involuntary = Intentless killing from Negligence or Non-felony-murder crime (INN).
cards.clozeLite: Involuntary manslaughter is an {{c1::unintentional killing}} caused by {{c2::criminal (gross) negligence}} or by {{c3::an unlawful act not qualifying for felony murder}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 030. Larceny
cards.backPlain: Common-law larceny is a specific intent property crime. It consists of a trespassory taking and carrying away (asportation) of another's tangible personal property, without the owner's consent, and with the intent to permanently dispossess the owner. The core elements are: - Taking: Obtaining control or possession; if the defendant already has possession, the offense is generally embezzlement, not larceny. - Carrying away: Any slight movement satisfies asportation. - Without consent: Against the victim's free will; consent obtained by fraud or duress is invalid and distinguishes larceny from larceny by trick. - Specific intent to permanently dispossess: Must exist at the time of the taking, and includes taking for an unreasonable period of time. The continuing trespass doctrine allows a later-formed intent to keep initially borrowed property to ripen into larceny. Larceny can also arise when a defendant finds and keeps lost or misplaced property if the true owner is known or reasonably ascertainable. No larceny occurs with truly abandoned property.
cards.frontPrompt: What is common-law larceny, and what are its main elements and special applications (including continuing trespass and found property)?
cards.cloze: Common-law {{c1::larceny}} is a {{c2::specific intent}} crime consisting of a {{c3::trespassory taking and carrying away}} (asportation) of another's {{c4::tangible personal property}}, {{c5::without the owner's consent}}, and with the {{c6::intent to permanently dispossess}} the owner. Special applications include the {{c7::continuing trespass doctrine}} (later-formed intent to keep borrowed property can become larceny) and {{c8::larceny of found property}} when the {{c9::true owner is known or reasonably ascertainable}} and the finder decides to keep it (but not for {{c10::abandoned property}}).
cards.easyContent: Common-law larceny is the trespassory taking and carrying away of another's tangible personal property without consent and with specific intent to permanently dispossess, including via continuing trespass and in some found-property situations.
cards.mediumContent: Common-law larceny requires: (1) a trespassory taking and carrying away (any movement) of another's tangible personal property; (2) without the owner's consent, with fraud or duress negating consent; and (3) specific intent to permanently dispossess at the time of the taking, including for an unreasonable time. If the defendant already has possession, the offense is generally embezzlement, not larceny. Under the continuing trespass doctrine, a later decision to keep initially borrowed property can ripen into larceny. Larceny can also arise when the defendant keeps lost or misplaced property whose true owner is known or reasonably ascertainable, but not when the property is truly abandoned.
cards.hardContent: Common-law larceny is a specific intent property crime defined as the trespassory taking and carrying away of another's tangible personal property, without the owner's consent, and with the intent to permanently dispossess the owner. The "taking" element requires obtaining control or possession; if the defendant already has lawful possession at the time of the misappropriation, the offense is generally embezzlement, not larceny. The "carrying away" (asportation) requirement is minimal—any slight movement will suffice. The taking must be without consent—against the victim's free will. Consent obtained by fraud or duress is invalid, and this trespassory requirement distinguishes larceny from larceny by trick. Larceny is a specific intent crime: the intent to permanently deprive must exist at the time of the taking, and it includes taking for an unreasonable period of time. Under the continuing trespass doctrine, if one initially borrows property intending to return it but later decides to keep it, larceny arises when the intent to keep is formed. Larceny can also occur when a defendant finds and keeps lost or misplaced property if the true owner is known or reasonably ascertainable and the defendant decides to keep it. However, there is no larceny with respect to truly abandoned property.
cards.mnemonic: Larceny = TCPP: Trespassory Taking, Carrying away, Personal Property, Permanently deprive.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) core elements of larceny, (2) specific intent and continuing trespass, (3) larceny and found property.
cards.clozeLite: Common-law {{c1::larceny}} is the {{c2::trespassory taking and carrying away}} of another's {{c3::tangible personal property}} {{c4::without consent}} and with {{c5::intent to permanently dispossess}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 031. Embezzlement
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule: Embezzlement is the fraudulent conversion of another's personal property by one in lawful possession. 2. Required elements: 2.1 Fraudulent conversion: The defendant uses another's property beyond the scope of, or inconsistent with, the defendant's possessory rights. 2.2 By one in lawful possession: The defendant must have lawful possession at the time of conversion. 3. Distinguished from larceny: Both involve obtaining property through misappropriation, but the circumstances of the taking differ. 3.1 Embezzlement: Conversion of property already in the defendant's rightful possession. 3.2 Larceny: Taking property not in the defendant's possession (a trespassory taking). 4. Special issues refuting embezzlement: 4.1 Intent to restore: If the defendant takes property with the intent to restore the exact property, no embezzlement has occurred; it must be the exact same property—substituting different monetary bills of equal value does not suffice. 4.2 Claim of right: Like larceny, embezzlement will not arise if the misappropriation is made under a claim of right to the property (i.e., the defendant believes the property belongs to him).
cards.frontPrompt: What is embezzlement, how does it differ from larceny, and what intent-related issues can negate embezzlement?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule: {{c1::Embezzlement}} is the {{c2::fraudulent conversion}} of another's personal property by one in {{c3::lawful possession}}. 2. Required elements: 2.1 {{c4::Fraudulent conversion}}: The defendant uses another's property beyond the scope of, or inconsistent with, the defendant's possessory rights. 2.2 By one in {{c5::lawful possession}}: The defendant must have lawful possession at the time of conversion. 3. Distinguished from larceny: Both involve obtaining property through misappropriation, but the circumstances of the taking differ. 3.1 {{c6::Embezzlement}}: Conversion of property already in the defendant's {{c7::rightful possession}}. 3.2 {{c8::Larceny}}: Taking property {{c9::not in the defendant's possession}} (a {{c10::trespassory taking}}). 4. Special issues refuting embezzlement: 4.1 {{c11::Intent to restore}}: If the defendant takes property with the intent to restore the exact property, no embezzlement has occurred; it must be the exact same property—substituting different monetary bills of equal value does not suffice. 4.2 {{c12::Claim of right}}: Like larceny, embezzlement will not arise if the misappropriation is made under a claim of right to the property (i.e., the defendant believes the property belongs to him).
cards.easyContent: Embezzlement is the fraudulent conversion of another's property by someone who already has lawful possession of it.
cards.mediumContent: Embezzlement occurs when a person who is in lawful possession of another's personal property fraudulently converts it—uses it beyond or inconsistent with their authority. It differs from larceny because larceny involves a trespassory taking, while embezzlement involves misuse of property already in the defendant's possession. There is no embezzlement if the defendant intends to restore the exact same property or acts under a bona fide claim of right.
cards.hardContent: Embezzlement is the fraudulent conversion of another's personal property by a person in lawful possession of that property. Fraudulent conversion means using the property in a way that exceeds or contradicts the defendant's authorized possessory rights. The key distinction from larceny is that in embezzlement the defendant already has lawful possession, whereas larceny involves taking property not in the defendant's possession (a trespassory taking). Embezzlement will not lie if the defendant intends to restore the exact same property taken—merely substituting equivalent monetary bills is insufficient—and, as with larceny, a genuine claim of right (a belief that the property belongs to the defendant) negates the crime.
cards.mnemonic: Embezzlement: Entrusted Employee Empties property he Possesses.
cards.clozeLite: Embezzlement is {{c1::fraudulent conversion}} of {{c2::another's personal property}} by {{c3::one in lawful possession}}, differing from larceny's {{c4::trespassory taking}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.topic: False Pretenses and Larceny by Trick
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 032. False Pretenses and Larceny by Trick
cards.front: False Pretenses and Larceny by Trick
cards.backPlain: 1. False pretenses – general rule: 1.1 Obtaining title to another's property. 1.2 By using false statements. 1.3 About a past or existing fact. 1.4 With intent to defraud. 2. Required elements of false pretenses: 2.1 Obtaining title: the defendant obtains ownership, not mere possession. 2.2 By false statements: there must be an intentional false statement. 2.3 Of past or existing fact: a misrepresentation regarding a future event is not sufficient. 2.4 Intent to defraud: the defendant must have the intent to steal, and the victim must be deceived or act in reliance on the false statement in passing title to the defendant. 3. Larceny by trick – general rule: 3.1 Obtaining possession. 3.2 Of another's personal property. 3.3 By using false statements of past or existing fact. 4. Possession vs. ownership as distinguishing factor: 4.1 In larceny by trick, the defendant acquires possession only. 4.2 In false pretenses, the defendant acquires title (ownership).
cards.frontPrompt: What are the elements of false pretenses, and how does it differ from larceny by trick in criminal law?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::False pretenses}} – general rule: 1.1 Obtaining {{c2::title}} to another's property. 1.2 By using {{c3::false statements}}. 1.3 About a {{c4::past or existing fact}}. 1.4 With {{c5::intent to defraud}}. 2. Required elements of {{c1::false pretenses}}: 2.1 Obtaining title: the defendant obtains {{c6::ownership, not mere possession}}. 2.2 By false statements: there must be an {{c7::intentional false statement}}. 2.3 Of past or existing fact: a misrepresentation regarding a {{c8::future event is not sufficient}}. 2.4 Intent to defraud: the defendant must have the intent to steal, and the victim must be {{c9::deceived or act in reliance on the false statement in passing title}} to the defendant. 3. {{c10::Larceny by trick}} – general rule: 3.1 Obtaining {{c11::possession}}. 3.2 Of another's {{c12::personal property}}. 3.3 By using false statements of {{c4::past or existing fact}}. 4. {{c13::Possession vs. ownership}} as distinguishing factor: 4.1 In larceny by trick, the defendant acquires {{c14::possession only}}. 4.2 In false pretenses, the defendant acquires {{c15::title (ownership)}}.
cards.easyContent: False pretenses occurs when the defendant uses a false statement about a past or existing fact to obtain title to another’s property with intent to defraud, while larceny by trick uses similar deception to obtain only possession.
cards.mediumContent: False pretenses requires an intentional false statement about a past or existing fact that causes the victim, in reliance, to pass title to the defendant, who has intent to defraud. Larceny by trick instead involves obtaining only possession of another’s personal property through false statements of past or existing fact. The key distinction is that false pretenses transfers title, whereas larceny by trick transfers only possession.
cards.hardContent: False pretenses consists of: (1) obtaining title to another’s property; (2) by an intentional false statement; (3) about a past or existing fact (a misrepresentation about a future event is not enough); and (4) with intent to defraud, such that the victim is deceived or relies on the misrepresentation in passing title to the defendant. Larceny by trick, in contrast, involves: (1) obtaining possession; (2) of another’s personal property; (3) by using false statements of past or existing fact. The distinguishing factor is that in larceny by trick the defendant acquires possession only, whereas in false pretenses the defendant acquires title (ownership).
cards.mnemonic: False PreTenses = Transfer of Title; Trick = temporary take (possession).
cards.clozeLite: In {{c1::false pretenses}}, the defendant’s fraud causes the victim to transfer {{c2::title}}; in {{c3::larceny by trick}}, fraud yields only {{c4::possession}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 033. Receipt of Stolen Property
cards.backPlain: 1. Receipt of stolen property – general rule: 1.1 Receiving possession and control of personal property. 1.2 That is known to have been illegally obtained by another. 1.3 With the intent to permanently deprive the owner of her interest in it. 2. Required elements: 2.1 Receipt of possession and control: physical possession is not required; the defendant can have possession or control by designating the property's location or arranging to sell it for the original thief. 2.2 Stolen personal property: the property must have been stolen at the time the defendant receives it. 2.3 Knowledge it was illegally obtained by another: the defendant must know or have reason to know the property is stolen. 2.4 Intent to permanently deprive the owner of his interest. 2.5 Police sting situations: if the police and the true property owner know of or arranged the defendant's receipt of the property, it is not truly stolen; however, the defendant can be convicted of attempted receipt of stolen property if she intended to receive the property believing it to be stolen.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the elements of the crime of receipt of stolen property, including how police sting situations affect liability?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Receipt of stolen property}} – general rule: 1.1 Receiving {{c2::possession and control}} of personal property. 1.2 That is {{c3::known to have been illegally obtained by another}}. 1.3 With the {{c4::intent to permanently deprive}} the owner of her interest in it. 2. Required elements: 2.1 Receipt of possession and control: {{c5::physical possession is not required}}; the defendant can have possession or control by designating the property's location or arranging to sell it for the original thief. 2.2 {{c6::Stolen personal property}}: the property must have been stolen at the time the defendant receives it. 2.3 {{c7::Knowledge}} it was illegally obtained by another: the defendant must {{c8::know or have reason to know}} the property is stolen. 2.4 {{c4::Intent to permanently deprive}} the owner of his interest. 2.5 {{c9::Police sting situations}}: if the police and the true property owner know of or arranged the defendant's receipt of the property, it is not truly stolen; however, the defendant can be convicted of {{c10::attempted receipt of stolen property}} if she intended to receive the property believing it to be stolen.
cards.easyContent: Receipt of stolen property occurs when a defendant receives possession or control of property she knows (or has reason to know) is stolen, with intent to permanently deprive the owner, and can support attempt liability in sting operations.
cards.mediumContent: The crime of receipt of stolen property requires: (1) receipt of possession or control of personal property, which can occur without physical handling if the defendant designates its location or arranges a sale; (2) the property must be stolen when received; (3) the defendant must know or have reason to know it was illegally obtained by another; and (4) intent to permanently deprive the owner. In police sting situations where the property is no longer truly stolen, the defendant may be guilty of attempted receipt if she believes it to be stolen and intends to receive it.
cards.hardContent: Receipt of stolen property is committed when the defendant: (1) receives possession and control of personal property (physical possession is not required; control can be exercised by designating the property's location or arranging to sell it for the original thief); (2) the property is in fact stolen at the time of receipt; (3) the defendant knows or has reason to know the property was illegally obtained by another; and (4) acts with intent to permanently deprive the owner of his interest. In police sting situations, if law enforcement and the true owner have recovered the property and arrange the defendant's "receipt," it is no longer legally stolen, but the defendant may still be liable for attempted receipt of stolen property if she believed the property to be stolen and intended to receive it.
cards.mnemonic: RKS: Receipt/control, Knows stolen, Separates owner permanently.
cards.clozeLite: Receipt of stolen property requires {{c1::receiving possession or control of personal property}}, {{c2::that is stolen when received}}, {{c3::knowing or having reason to know it was illegally obtained}}, and {{c4::intent to permanently deprive the owner}}; in a {{c5::police sting}}, liability is for {{c6::attempted receipt}} if the defendant believes it is stolen.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 034. Forgery
cards.backPlain: 1. Forgery – general rule: 1.1 Creating or altering a written document with purported legal significance to be false, with the intent to defraud. 2. Required elements: 2.1 Creating or altering: 2.1.1 For example: drafting, adding to, or deleting from a document's contents. 2.1.2 Also includes offering a forged document as genuine, even if the defendant did not create the forged document. 2.2 Document with purported legal significance: 2.2.1 A document that carries legal value (e.g., a check or contract), not something like a painting. 2.3 To be false: 2.3.1 Modifying the document into something it is not. 2.3.2 Changing its legal significance, not just making it inaccurate. 2.4 With intent to defraud: 2.4.1 Forgery is a specific intent crime. 2.4.2 Actually defrauding somebody is not required; the mere intent to defraud is sufficient.
cards.frontPrompt: What is forgery in criminal law, and what elements must be shown to establish it?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Forgery}} – general rule: 1.1 {{c2::Creating or altering}} a written document with {{c3::purported legal significance}} to be false, with the {{c4::intent to defraud}}. 2. Required elements: 2.1 {{c2::Creating or altering}}: 2.1.1 For example: {{c5::drafting, adding to, or deleting from a document's contents}}. 2.1.2 Also includes {{c6::offering a forged document as genuine}} even if the defendant did not create the forged document. 2.2 Document with {{c3::purported legal significance}}: 2.2.1 A document that carries {{c7::legal value}} (e.g., a check or contract), not something like a painting. 2.3 To be {{c8::false}}: 2.3.1 {{c9::Modifying the document into something it is not}}. 2.3.2 {{c10::Changing its legal significance}}, not just making it inaccurate. 2.4 With {{c4::intent to defraud}}: 2.4.1 Forgery is a {{c11::specific intent}} crime. 2.4.2 Actually defrauding somebody is not required; the {{c12::mere intent to defraud is sufficient}}.
cards.easyContent: Forgery is creating, altering, or offering as genuine a false document with legal significance, with specific intent to defraud, even if no one is actually defrauded.
cards.mediumContent: Forgery requires (1) creating, altering, or offering as genuine a written document; (2) the document must have purported legal significance, such as a check or contract; (3) the document must be rendered false by modifying it into something it is not, thereby changing its legal significance; and (4) the defendant must act with specific intent to defraud, although no actual loss or successful fraud is necessary.
cards.hardContent: Forgery consists of: (1) creating or altering a written document with purported legal significance, or offering such a forged document as genuine; (2) the document must carry legal value (for example, a check or contract, not mere artwork); (3) the act must render the document false by modifying it into something it is not and changing its legal significance, not merely making it factually inaccurate; and (4) the defendant must act with specific intent to defraud—actual defrauding of a victim is not required, as the intent to defraud alone is sufficient.
cards.mnemonic: FALSe: Fake Alteration of Legal-Significant document with intent to defraud.
cards.clozeLite: Forgery is {{c1::creating, altering, or offering as genuine}} a {{c2::false written document}} with {{c3::purported legal significance}} and {{c4::specific intent to defraud}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 035. Robbery and Extortion
cards.backPlain: 1. Robbery – general rule: 1.1 Wrongful taking. 1.2 Of another's personal property. 1.3 From his person or presence. 1.4 By force or threat of injury. 1.5 With the intent to permanently deprive. 2. Robbery requirements and notes: 2.1 Robbery is assault or battery plus larceny. 2.2 Victim's person or presence is interpreted broadly. 2.3 Force or threat of injury: a small amount of force or threat will suffice; the threat of injury must be to the victim, a member of her family, or a person in her presence; and the victim must give up the property because she feels threatened or harmed; threats of future harm are insufficient. 2.4 Larceny vs. robbery: robbery requires force or threats to obtain the victim's property, whereas larceny does not. For example, a pickpocket commits larceny if the victim does not notice the act, but commits robbery if the victim notices and is confronted by force or threat. 3. Extortion – general rule: 3.1 Obtaining property through threats of future harm or exposing information. 3.2 Extortion vs. robbery: extortion does not require a taking from the victim's person or presence. 3.3 Extortion involves threats of future, rather than immediate, harm.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the elements of robbery and extortion, and how do these crimes differ from each other and from larceny?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Robbery}} – general rule: 1.1 {{c2::Wrongful taking}}. 1.2 Of another's {{c3::personal property}}. 1.3 From his {{c4::person or presence}}. 1.4 By {{c5::force or threat of injury}}. 1.5 With the {{c6::intent to permanently deprive}}. 2. Robbery requirements and notes: 2.1 Robbery is {{c7::assault or battery plus larceny}}. 2.2 Victim's {{c4::person or presence}} is interpreted {{c8::broadly}}. 2.3 Force or threat of injury: a {{c9::small amount of force or threat}} will suffice; the threat of injury must be to the {{c10::victim, a member of her family, or a person in her presence}}; and the victim must give up the property because she feels threatened or harmed; {{c11::threats of future harm are insufficient}}. 2.4 Larceny vs. robbery: robbery requires {{c5::force or threats}} to obtain the victim's property, whereas {{c12::larceny}} does not. For example, a {{c13::pickpocket}} commits larceny if the victim does not notice the act, but commits robbery if the victim notices and is confronted by force or threat. 3. {{c14::Extortion}} – general rule: 3.1 Obtaining property through {{c15::threats of future harm or exposing information}}. 3.2 Extortion vs. robbery: extortion does {{c16::not require a taking from the victim's person or presence}}. 3.3 Extortion involves threats of {{c17::future, rather than immediate, harm}}.
cards.easyContent: Robbery is larceny from a person or their presence by force or threat of immediate injury, with intent to permanently deprive, whereas extortion obtains property by threats of future harm or exposure and does not require a taking from the victim’s person.
cards.mediumContent: Robbery requires a wrongful taking of another’s personal property, from their person or presence, by force or threat of immediate injury, with intent to permanently deprive, and can be viewed as assault or battery plus larceny. The threat must cause the victim to surrender property due to fear of present harm. Extortion, in contrast, consists of obtaining property through threats of future harm or exposing information and does not require that the property be taken from the victim’s person or presence.
cards.hardContent: Robbery is defined as a wrongful taking of another's personal property from the victim's person or presence, by force or threat of immediate injury, with intent to permanently deprive the owner. Robbery is essentially assault or battery plus larceny, and the victim's person or presence is interpreted broadly. Only a small amount of force or threat is required, but the threat must be directed at the victim, a family member, or someone in the victim’s presence, and must cause the victim to give up property due to fear of present harm; threats of future harm are insufficient for robbery. Extortion, by contrast, involves obtaining property by threats of future harm or exposure of information, does not require a taking from the victim’s person or presence, and centers on threats of future rather than immediate harm.
cards.mnemonic: ROBBERY = RIF (Immediate Force); EXTORTION = FX (Future eXposure)
cards.clozeLite: {{c1::Robbery}} is larceny from a {{c2::person or their presence}} by {{c3::force or threat of immediate injury}}. {{c4::Extortion}} uses {{c5::threats of future harm or exposure}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 036. Burglary
cards.backPlain: Common law burglary is defined as a trespassory breaking and entering of the dwelling house of another at nighttime with intent to commit a felony therein. The key elements are: (1) trespassory breaking; (2) entering; (3) of the dwelling house; (4) of another; (5) at nighttime; and (6) with intent to commit a felony inside at the time of the breaking and entering. Modern burglary statutes generally broaden this definition by: (1) eliminating the breaking requirement; (2) eliminating the nighttime requirement; (3) expanding covered structures beyond dwellings; and (4) broadening the intended offense to include misdemeanors such as theft. On the MBE, apply modern statutory rules unless the question specifically instructs you to apply the common law definition.
cards.frontPrompt: What is common law burglary, what are its core elements, and in what general ways do modern burglary statutes modify that definition?
cards.cloze: Common law {{c1::burglary}} is defined as a {{c2::trespassory breaking and entering}} of the {{c3::dwelling house}} of {{c4::another}} {{c5::at nighttime}} with {{c6::intent to commit a felony therein}}. Modern {{c7::burglary statutes}} often {{c8::eliminate the breaking and nighttime requirements}}, {{c9::extend the crime to non-dwellings}}, and {{c10::broaden the intended offense to include misdemeanors such as theft}}. On the {{c11::MBE}}, apply {{c7::modern statutory rules}} unless directed to use the {{c12::common law}} definition.
cards.easyContent: Common law burglary is a trespassory breaking and entering of the dwelling of another at nighttime with intent to commit a felony inside. Modern statutes typically relax the breaking and nighttime requirements, expand beyond dwellings, and broaden the intended crime (e.g., to theft).
cards.mediumContent: At common law, burglary requires: (1) trespassory breaking; (2) entering; (3) the dwelling house; (4) of another; (5) at nighttime; (6) with intent to commit a felony therein, formed at the time of breaking and entering. Modern statutes often eliminate the breaking and nighttime requirements, extend burglary to non-dwellings, and broaden the intended offense to include misdemeanors such as theft. On the MBE, apply modern statutory rules unless instructed to use the common law definition.
cards.hardContent: Common law burglary is defined as a trespassory breaking and entering of the dwelling house of another at nighttime with intent to commit a felony therein. The core elements are: (1) a trespassory breaking (actual or constructive); (2) an entry; (3) into a dwelling house (used for sleeping); (4) of another (based on occupancy, not ownership); (5) occurring at nighttime; and (6) with intent to commit a felony inside, formed at the time of the breaking and entering. Modern burglary statutes generally broaden this definition by dispensing with the breaking requirement, eliminating the nighttime element, applying burglary to non-dwelling structures, and broadening the intended offense to include misdemeanors such as theft. On the MBE, modern statutory rules govern unless the question explicitly calls for the common law definition.
cards.mnemonic: For common law burglary, think "BEND F": Breaking, Entering, at Night, Dwelling of another, Felony intent.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into: (1) common law definition and elements; (2) breaking and entering nuances; (3) modern statutory modifications.
cards.clozeLite: Common law {{c1::burglary}} is a {{c2::trespassory breaking and entering}} of the {{c3::dwelling of another}} {{c4::at nighttime}} with {{c5::intent to commit a felony}} inside.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 037. Arson
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule: Arson is the malicious burning of the dwelling house of another. 1.1 Malicious: 1.1.1 Requires intent or extreme recklessness. 1.2 Burning: 1.2.1 Requires some damage to the structure caused by fire. 1.2.2 Damage from smoke, water, or explosions is not sufficient at common law. 1.3 Dwelling house: 1.3.1 A structure where someone lives. 1.3.2 Dwelling-house requirement is a common law limitation. 1.3.3 On the MBE, modern statutes may define arson to include burning a non-residential structure. 1.4 Of another: 1.4.1 Another person's dwelling. 1.4.2 At common law, there is no arson if you own the dwelling but do not reside there. 1.5 Damage required: 1.5.1 There must be charring or more substantial damage. 1.5.2 Mere discoloration, blackening, or other lesser damage is insufficient.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the elements of common law arson, including the required mental state, type of property, and degree of damage?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule: {{c1::Arson}} is the {{c2::malicious}} {{c3::burning}} of the {{c4::dwelling house}} {{c5::of another}}. 1.1 Malicious: 1.1.1 Requires {{c6::intent or extreme recklessness}}. 1.2 Burning: 1.2.1 Requires some {{c7::damage to the structure caused by fire}}. 1.2.2 Damage from {{c8::smoke, water, or explosions}} is not sufficient at {{c9::common law}}. 1.3 Dwelling house: 1.3.1 A structure where someone {{c10::lives}}. 1.3.2 Dwelling-house requirement is a {{c11::common law}} limitation. 1.3.3 On the {{c12::MBE}}, modern statutes may define arson to include burning a {{c13::non-residential structure}}. 1.4 Of another: 1.4.1 Another person's {{c14::dwelling}}. 1.4.2 At common law, there is no arson if you {{c15::own the dwelling but do not reside there}}. 1.5 Damage required: 1.5.1 There must be {{c16::charring or more substantial damage}}. 1.5.2 Mere {{c17::discoloration or blackening}} is insufficient.
cards.easyContent: Common law arson is the malicious burning of the dwelling house of another, requiring at least charring to the structure caused by fire.
cards.mediumContent: Common law arson is the malicious burning of the dwelling house of another. Malice means intent or extreme recklessness. There must be actual fire damage (at least charring) to the structure, and at common law the structure must be a dwelling of another; mere smoke or water damage is not enough. Modern statutes, as tested on the MBE, may extend arson to non-residential structures.
cards.hardContent: Arson at common law is the malicious burning of the dwelling house of another. Malicious means the defendant acted with intent to burn or with extreme recklessness. Burning requires some physical damage to the structure itself caused by fire; damage from smoke, water, or explosions alone is not sufficient at common law. The property must be a dwelling house—a structure where someone lives—which is a common law limitation; on the MBE, modern statutes may define arson more broadly to include non-residential structures. The dwelling must be that of another; at common law there is no arson if the defendant owns the dwelling but does not reside there. There must be at least charring or more substantial damage; mere discoloration, blackening, or other trivial damage is insufficient.
cards.mnemonic: MBD-C: Malicious Burning of Dwelling, Charring needed.
cards.clozeLite: Common law arson is the {{c1::malicious burning}} of the {{c2::dwelling house}} {{c3::of another}}, requiring {{c4::actual fire damage (at least charring)}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.topic: Mens Rea – Specific Intent vs. General Intent
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 002-1. Mens Rea – Specific vs. General Intent
cards.front: Mens Rea – Specific Intent vs. General Intent
cards.backPlain: Specific intent and general intent are the two main common law intent categories: 1. Specific intent 1.1 Definition: The defendant must have a specific intent or objective to commit the given crime. 1.2 Proof: Specific intent must always be affirmatively proven; it is never merely inferred from the act alone. 1.3 Defenses: Mistake of fact (even if unreasonable, depending on the crime) and voluntary intoxication are recognized defenses to specific intent crimes. 2. General intent 2.1 Definition: The defendant must be aware of his actions and any attendant circumstances; a general intent to do the proscribed act is sufficient. 2.2 Proof: General intent may be inferred from the defendant’s conduct and the circumstances surrounding the act. 2.3 Scope: Most crimes are general intent crimes at common law. The classification of the offense as specific or general intent affects what the prosecution must prove and which defenses (like mistake of fact or voluntary intoxication) may be raised.
cards.frontPrompt: How do specific intent and general intent differ at common law, and what are the key proof and defense implications of each?
cards.cloze: Under common law: 1. {{c1::Specific intent}} 1.1 The defendant must have a {{c2::specific intent or objective to commit the given crime}}. 1.2 Specific intent must always be {{c3::affirmatively proven}}; it is {{c4::never merely inferred from the act alone}}. 1.3 {{c5::Mistake of fact}} and {{c6::voluntary intoxication}} are recognized defenses to specific intent crimes. 2. {{c7::General intent}} 2.1 The defendant must be {{c8::aware of his actions and any attendant circumstances}}; a general intent to do the proscribed act is sufficient. 2.2 General intent may be {{c9::inferred from the defendant’s conduct and the surrounding circumstances}}. 2.3 {{c10::Most crimes are general intent crimes}} at common law. The classification as {{c11::specific vs. general intent}} controls what the prosecution must prove and which {{c12::defenses (especially mistake of fact and voluntary intoxication)}} are available.
cards.easyContent: Specific intent requires a particular objective to commit the crime and must be proven; mistake of fact and voluntary intoxication can be defenses. General intent requires awareness of one’s acts and circumstances, can be inferred from conduct, and covers most common law crimes.
cards.mediumContent: Specific intent crimes require proof that the defendant had a particular objective to commit the crime; this mental state must be affirmatively shown, and defenses like mistake of fact and voluntary intoxication are available. General intent crimes require only that the defendant intended to perform the proscribed act (with awareness of circumstances); this intent may be inferred from conduct, and most crimes fall into this category.
cards.hardContent: At common law, specific intent and general intent are distinct mental-state categories: • Specific intent: The defendant must have a specific intent or objective to commit the charged crime. This mental state must be affirmatively proven and is not merely inferred from the act itself. Because of this heightened mental-state requirement, defenses such as mistake of fact (often even if unreasonable, depending on the crime) and voluntary intoxication are available to negate specific intent. • General intent: The defendant must be aware of his actions and attendant circumstances and intend to perform the proscribed act, but need not have any further special objective. General intent may be inferred from the defendant’s conduct and the surrounding circumstances, and most common law crimes are general intent offenses. Whether a crime is classified as specific or general intent determines both the prosecution’s burden of proof as to mental state and the availability of defenses like mistake of fact and voluntary intoxication.
cards.mnemonic: Specific = special objective; General = just doing the act.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::specific intent}} crime needs a {{c2::particular objective}} and allows {{c3::mistake of fact}} and {{c4::voluntary intoxication}} as defenses; {{c5::general intent}} needs only intent to do the act, often {{c6::inferred from conduct}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 002-2. Mens Rea – Malice
cards.backPlain: Malice is a common law mental state used for a limited set of serious offenses: 1. Definition of malice 1.1 The defendant acts with reckless disregard of, or undertakes an obvious risk from which, a harmful result is expected. 1.2 Malice involves a higher level of blameworthiness than ordinary negligence; the defendant is aware of a very serious risk and proceeds anyway. 2. Crimes requiring malice 2.1 Malice applies to: • Arson; and • Common law murder. 3. Effect on proof 3.1 The prosecution must prove that the defendant either intended the harmful result or, at minimum, acted with reckless disregard of an obvious and unjustifiable risk of that result. Understanding malice is crucial for distinguishing malice crimes (like murder and arson) from lesser general intent or negligence-based offenses.
cards.frontPrompt: What is malice as a common law mens rea, and to which crimes does it apply?
cards.cloze: Under common law, {{c1::malice}} is a mental state in which the defendant {{c2::acts with reckless disregard of, or undertakes an obvious risk from which, a harmful result is expected}}. Malice applies to the crimes of {{c3::arson}} and {{c4::common law murder}}. The prosecution must show that the defendant either {{c5::intended the harmful result}} or at least {{c6::consciously disregarded an obvious and serious risk}} of that result.
cards.easyContent: Malice is a mental state where the defendant recklessly disregards an obvious risk of a harmful result. At common law, malice is required for arson and common law murder.
cards.mediumContent: Malice at common law means the defendant acts with reckless disregard of, or undertakes an obvious risk from which, a harmful result is expected. This heightened mental state is used primarily for arson and common law murder, requiring proof that the defendant intentionally or recklessly risked causing the forbidden harm.
cards.hardContent: Malice is a heightened common law mental state. A defendant acts with malice when he acts with reckless disregard of, or undertakes an obvious risk from which, a harmful result is expected. This involves conscious awareness of a serious risk and proceeding despite that risk, making it more blameworthy than negligence. Common law uses malice primarily for two crimes: (1) arson, and (2) common law murder. For these offenses, the prosecution must prove that the defendant either intended the harmful result or, at minimum, acted with reckless disregard of an obvious and unjustifiable risk that the result would occur.
