Recognizing malice helps distinguish malice offenses (murder and arson) from lesser offenses that require only general intent or negligence.
cards.mnemonic: Malice: Mindfully Accepting Likely Injury, Causing Evil.
cards.clozeLite: Common law {{c1::malice}} is {{c2::reckless disregard of an obvious risk}} of {{c3::a harmful result}}, used for {{c4::arson}} and {{c5::common law murder}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 002-3. Mens Rea – Strict Liability
cards.backPlain: Strict liability crimes are offenses that do not require proof of any mens rea as to one or more elements of the crime: 1. Definition 1.1 No intent or awareness is required for strict liability crimes as to the strict-liability element(s); there is effectively no mens rea requirement for those elements. 2. Common examples 2.1 Strict liability commonly arises with: • Statutory rape; • Regulatory or public welfare offenses (e.g., food and drug regulations, environmental violations); • Certain morality crimes. 3. Consequences 3.1 The prosecution need only prove the prohibited act and any required circumstances; it need not show that the defendant knew, intended, or was reckless as to the strict-liability element. 3.2 Traditional mens rea defenses (like mistake of fact or intoxication) typically do not negate liability for the strict-liability elements. Because strict liability dispenses with mens rea, courts often construe strict liability narrowly and look for clear legislative intent to impose it.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a strict liability crime at common law, and in what types of offenses does strict liability most often appear?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::strict liability}} crime is one in which {{c2::no intent or awareness is required}} as to one or more elements of the offense—there is effectively {{c3::no mens rea requirement}} for those elements. Strict liability is commonly found in: • {{c4::Statutory rape}}; • {{c5::Regulatory or public welfare offenses}} (e.g., safety, food, or environmental regulations); • Certain {{c6::morality crimes}}. For these elements, the prosecution need only prove the {{c7::prohibited act and circumstances}}, not any particular mental state.
cards.easyContent: Strict liability crimes require no proof of intent or awareness as to the strict-liability elements. They are common in statutory rape, regulatory/public welfare offenses, and some morality crimes.
cards.mediumContent: In strict liability offenses, the prosecution does not need to prove any mens rea as to the strict-liability element; it is enough that the defendant committed the prohibited act under the required circumstances. These offenses often include statutory rape, regulatory/public welfare offenses, and some morality crimes, and traditional mens rea defenses generally do not apply.
cards.hardContent: Strict liability crimes are offenses where the law dispenses with any mens rea requirement for one or more elements of the crime. The defendant can be convicted even if he lacked knowledge, intent, or recklessness concerning those elements. The prosecution’s burden is limited to proving that the defendant committed the prohibited act under the required circumstances. Strict liability commonly arises in: • Statutory rape (where the defendant’s mistake about the victim’s age generally is no defense); • Regulatory or public welfare offenses, such as violations of food and drug laws, environmental regulations, or safety codes; • Certain morality offenses. Because strict liability imposes criminal liability without fault, courts often demand clear legislative intent to construe an offense as strict liability, and traditional mens rea-based defenses (like mistake of fact or intoxication) typically cannot negate the strict-liability elements.
cards.mnemonic: Strict liability: statute sticks without state of mind.
cards.clozeLite: In {{c1::strict liability}} crimes, no {{c2::mens rea}} is required for the {{c3::strict-liability element}}, often in {{c4::statutory rape}} and {{c5::public welfare}} offenses.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 002-4. Mens Rea – Vicarious Liability
cards.backPlain: Vicarious liability imposes criminal liability on one person for another’s criminal conduct, even if the person held liable is personally without fault as to the offense elements: 1. Definition 1.1 A person without fault is held liable for another's criminal conduct (e.g., an employer for an employee’s regulatory offense committed within the scope of employment). 2. Typical context 2.1 Vicarious liability often arises in: • Employment relationships (employers for employees); • Business or corporate associations (corporations for acts of officers or agents); • Certain statutory or regulatory schemes that spread responsibility to those in control. 3. Relationship to mens rea 3.1 Although the liable person may lack personal mens rea for the underlying offense, the law imputes liability based on the relationship and control over the actual wrongdoer. 3.2 Vicarious liability is sometimes paired with strict liability offenses, further reducing the prosecution’s burden regarding mental state. On the bar exam, recognize that vicarious liability can attach to relatively blameless supervisors, employers, or entities based solely on their relationship to the direct offender.
cards.frontPrompt: What is vicarious criminal liability, and in what kinds of relationships does it most commonly arise?
cards.cloze: In criminal law, {{c1::vicarious liability}} is liability imposed on {{c2::one person for another’s criminal conduct}}, even though the person held liable may be {{c3::personally without fault}}. It most often arises in: • {{c4::Employment relationships}} (employers for employees); • {{c5::Business or corporate associations}} (corporations for acts of officers or agents); • Certain {{c6::statutory or regulatory schemes}} that spread responsibility to those in control. The law {{c7::imputes liability based on the relationship and control}} rather than on the liable person’s own mens rea.
cards.easyContent: Vicarious liability makes one person (like an employer or corporation) criminally liable for another’s offense, even if the liable person is personally without fault. It often arises in employment and business contexts.
cards.mediumContent: Vicarious criminal liability occurs when the law holds someone liable for another’s criminal act, typically because of a special relationship and control (e.g., employer–employee, corporation–agent). The liable person may lack personal mens rea for the offense, but liability is imputed due to the relationship, commonly in regulatory or business settings.
cards.hardContent: Vicarious liability in criminal law allows the state to hold one person criminally responsible for another’s conduct. A person without personal fault—such as an employer, supervisor, or corporation—may be held liable for an employee’s or agent’s criminal acts committed within the scope of the relationship. This form of liability commonly arises in: • Employment relationships (e.g., an employer liable for an employee’s regulatory violation during work); • Business and corporate settings (e.g., a corporation liable for officers’ or agents’ actions); • Statutory or regulatory schemes that impose responsibility on those in positions of control. Vicarious liability relaxes the usual mens rea requirement for the person held liable by imputing another’s conduct to them based on the relationship, and is often combined with strict liability offenses to further reduce the prosecution’s burden.
cards.mnemonic: VICARIOUS: Victim Isn’t Charged; Another Responsible In Ongoing Union/Service.
cards.clozeLite: Vicarious criminal liability {{c1::imputes liability for another’s act}} based on a {{c2::special relationship and control}} (e.g., {{c3::employer–employee or corporation–agent}}), often in {{c4::regulatory or business settings}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 004-1. Major Crimes – General Intent Crimes
cards.frontPrompt: What is a general intent crime in criminal law, and which major common law crimes are general intent?
cards.backPlain: General intent crimes require that the defendant be aware of his actions and any attendant circumstances; the necessary intent may be inferred from the doing of the act itself. Major common law general intent crimes: - Battery. - Rape. - Kidnapping. - False imprisonment.
cards.cloze: {{c1::General intent crimes}} require that the defendant be {{c2::aware of his actions and any attendant circumstances}}, and the necessary intent may be {{c3::inferred from the doing of the act itself}}. Major common law general intent crimes: - {{c4::Battery}}. - {{c5::Rape}}. - {{c6::Kidnapping}}. - {{c7::False imprisonment}}.
cards.easyContent: General intent crimes require awareness of the act and circumstances, and the intent can be inferred. Classic examples are battery, rape, kidnapping, and false imprisonment.
cards.mediumContent: A general intent crime is one where the defendant must be aware of the nature of his conduct and the attendant circumstances, but no further specific objective is required. The intent element may be inferred from the doing of the proscribed act. The major common law general intent crimes are battery, rape, kidnapping, and false imprisonment.
cards.hardContent: General intent crimes require that the defendant be aware of his actions and any attendant circumstances, but do not require a further purpose or objective beyond committing the act itself. The requisite mental state can often be inferred from the commission of the proscribed act. The principal common law general intent crimes tested on the bar are: - Battery. - Rape. - Kidnapping. - False imprisonment.
cards.mnemonic: BRKF: Battery, Rape, Kidnapping, False imprisonment are general intent.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::general intent crime}} requires {{c2::awareness of conduct and circumstances}}, and includes {{c3::battery, rape, kidnapping, and false imprisonment}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 004-2. Major Crimes – Specific Intent (FIAT) Crimes
cards.frontPrompt: What is a specific intent crime, what does FIAT stand for, and which major crimes fall into this category?
cards.backPlain: Specific intent crimes require that the defendant have a specific intent or objective to commit the particular crime or bring about a particular result. Mnemonic: FIAT – First-degree murder, Inchoate crimes, Assault, Theft. Major common law specific intent crimes: - Attempt (inchoate). - Conspiracy (inchoate). - Solicitation (inchoate). - Larceny and robbery (theft). - Burglary. - Forgery. - False pretenses. - Embezzlement. - Assault. - First-degree murder.
cards.cloze: {{c1::Specific intent crimes}} require that the defendant have a {{c2::specific intent or objective}} to commit the crime or bring about a particular result. Mnemonic: {{c3::FIAT}} – {{c4::First-degree murder, Inchoate crimes, Assault, Theft}}. Major common law specific intent crimes: - {{c5::Attempt}} (inchoate). - {{c6::Conspiracy}} (inchoate). - {{c7::Solicitation}} (inchoate). - {{c8::Larceny and robbery}} (theft). - {{c9::Burglary}}. - {{c10::Forgery}}. - {{c11::False pretenses}}. - {{c12::Embezzlement}}. - {{c13::Assault}}. - {{c14::First-degree murder}}.
cards.easyContent: Specific intent crimes require a particular objective or purpose. Remember FIAT: First-degree murder, Inchoate crimes (attempt, conspiracy, solicitation), Assault, and Theft (larceny/robbery and related property crimes, plus burglary and similar offenses).
cards.mediumContent: A specific intent crime requires that the defendant not only engage in the proscribed conduct, but also do so with a particular purpose or objective. The FIAT mnemonic captures the main categories: First-degree murder, Inchoate crimes, Assault, and Theft. Specific intent crimes include attempt, conspiracy, solicitation, larceny and robbery, burglary, forgery, false pretenses, embezzlement, assault, and first-degree murder.
cards.hardContent: Specific intent crimes require that the defendant have a particular purpose or objective in mind beyond merely doing the act—for example, to permanently deprive another of property or to kill with premeditation. Use the FIAT mnemonic: - F – First-degree murder. - I – Inchoate crimes (attempt, conspiracy, solicitation). - A – Assault. - T – Theft and related property crimes. Bar-tested specific intent crimes include: - Attempt. - Conspiracy. - Solicitation. - Larceny and robbery. - Burglary. - Forgery. - False pretenses. - Embezzlement. - Assault. - First-degree murder.
cards.mnemonic: FIAT – First-degree murder, Inchoate crimes, Assault, Theft.
cards.clozeLite: Specific intent crimes require {{c1::a particular purpose or objective}}. Remember {{c2::FIAT}}: {{c3::First-degree murder}}, {{c4::Inchoate crimes}}, {{c5::Assault}}, and {{c6::Theft}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 004-3. Major Crimes – Malice Crimes
cards.frontPrompt: What is the malice mens rea in criminal law, and which major common law crimes are malice crimes?
cards.backPlain: Malice crimes require a reckless disregard of, or the undertaking of an obvious risk from which a harmful result is expected. Major common law malice crimes: - Common law murder (malice aforethought). - Arson.
cards.cloze: {{c1::Malice crimes}} require a {{c2::reckless disregard of, or undertaking an obvious risk from which a harmful result is expected}}. Major common law malice crimes: - {{c3::Common law murder}} ({{c4::malice aforethought}}). - {{c5::Arson}}.
cards.easyContent: Malice crimes involve reckless disregard of an obvious, high risk of harm. The classic malice crimes are common law murder (malice aforethought) and arson.
cards.mediumContent: For malice crimes, the defendant must act with a reckless disregard of, or undertake an obvious and unjustifiable risk from which a harmful result is expected. The major common law malice crimes are common law murder, which requires malice aforethought, and arson.
cards.hardContent: Malice is a mens rea that lies between specific intent and recklessness. For malice crimes, the prosecution must show that the defendant acted with a reckless disregard of a high risk to human life or property, or undertook an obvious risk from which a harmful result was expected. The principal malice crimes are: - Common law murder (malice aforethought) – killing with any of the four traditional malice mental states. - Arson – malicious burning of the dwelling of another (or, in modern statutes, various structures).
cards.mnemonic: Malice MA: Murder and Arson need reckless disregard.
cards.clozeLite: For {{c1::malice crimes}}, D acts with {{c2::reckless disregard of an obvious, unjustifiable risk}}; main ones are {{c3::common law murder}} and {{c4::arson}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 004-4. Major Crimes – Strict Liability Crimes
cards.frontPrompt: What is a strict liability crime in criminal law, and what are common examples of strict liability offenses?
cards.backPlain: Strict liability crimes do not require proof of any mens rea as to one or more elements of the offense; the prosecution need only prove the voluntary act (and any attendant circumstances). Common strict liability offenses: - Statutory rape. - Regulatory crimes. - Administrative crimes. - Morality crimes (e.g., bigamy, polygamy).
cards.cloze: {{c1::Strict liability crimes}} do {{c2::not require proof of any mens rea}} as to one or more elements of the offense; the prosecution need only prove the {{c3::voluntary act and any required attendant circumstances}}. Common strict liability offenses: - {{c4::Statutory rape}}. - {{c5::Regulatory crimes}}. - {{c6::Administrative crimes}}. - {{c7::Morality crimes}} (e.g., {{c8::bigamy, polygamy}}).
cards.easyContent: Strict liability crimes have no mens rea requirement for key elements; just doing the prohibited act is enough. Examples include statutory rape, many regulatory or administrative offenses, and certain morality crimes like bigamy or polygamy.
cards.mediumContent: A strict liability crime dispenses with the need to prove any mental state for one or more elements of the offense. The prosecution only needs to show that the defendant voluntarily engaged in the prohibited conduct under the required circumstances. Bar-tested examples include statutory rape, regulatory and administrative offenses, and morality crimes such as bigamy and polygamy.
cards.hardContent: Strict liability offenses are crimes where the legislature has eliminated the mens rea requirement for one or more material elements, typically in the interest of public welfare or morality. The prosecution need only establish that the defendant voluntarily committed the prohibited act (and any required attendant circumstances); mistake, even if reasonable, is generally no defense. Common categories of strict liability crimes include: - Statutory rape. - Regulatory crimes (e.g., certain health and safety regulations). - Administrative crimes. - Morality crimes, such as bigamy and polygamy.
cards.mnemonic: STRICT: State Removes INTent, Crime Tied to act
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::strict liability crime}} {{c2::dispenses with any mens rea}} for {{c3::one or more elements}}; examples include {{c4::statutory rape}} and {{c5::regulatory or morality offenses}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 005-1. Concurrence – Act and Mens Rea
cards.backPlain: 1. Concurrence requirement 1.1 The defendant's criminal act and the requisite intent (mens rea) for the crime must occur simultaneously. 1.2 If the harmful act occurs before the intent forms, there is no concurrence for that offense. Example: • The defendant plans to murder the victim at her home. On the way, he accidentally runs over the victim with his car and kills her. • He is not guilty of murder based on the car incident because his homicidal intent did not concur with the act that caused her death (no concurrence).
cards.frontPrompt: What is the concurrence requirement in criminal law, and how does the car accident example illustrate a lack of concurrence?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Concurrence requirement}} 1.1 The defendant's {{c2::criminal act}} and the requisite {{c3::intent (mens rea)}} for the crime must {{c4::occur simultaneously}}. 1.2 If the {{c5::harmful act}} occurs {{c6::before}} the intent forms, there is {{c7::no concurrence}} for that offense. Example: • The defendant plans to murder the victim at her home, but {{c8::accidentally runs over and kills}} her with his car before he can carry out the plan. • He is not guilty of murder based on the car incident because his homicidal intent did not {{c9::concur with the act that caused her death}}.
cards.easyContent: Concurrence means the guilty act and guilty mind must exist at the same time. If the harmful act happens before the intent forms, there is no concurrence for that crime.
cards.mediumContent: The concurrence requirement demands that the defendant’s criminal act and the required mens rea occur simultaneously for the charged offense. If the act causing the harm is accidental and occurs before the defendant forms the intent (e.g., accidentally running over someone you later decide you wanted to kill), there is no concurrence for that offense.
cards.hardContent: Concurrence is the temporal requirement that the actus reus and the specific mens rea for a crime coincide. The defendant must possess the requisite intent at the time he commits the criminal act that causes the prohibited result. If the harmful act precedes the formation of intent, there is no concurrence for that offense. For example, if a defendant accidentally runs over and kills a victim, and only later forms a plan or desire to kill that person, he cannot be convicted of murder based on the earlier accident because his homicidal intent did not concur with the act that caused the death.
cards.mnemonic: Concurrence = Coinciding Crime and Culpability (act + mens rea at the same time).
cards.clozeLite: Concurrence requires {{c1::actus reus}} and {{c2::mens rea}} to {{c3::exist simultaneously}} for the {{c4::charged offense}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 005-2. Causation – Cause-in-Fact (Actual Cause)
cards.backPlain: 2. Causation requirement – Cause-in-fact 2.1 The defendant's conduct must be a cause-in-fact of the result. 2.2 Basic test: But for the defendant's conduct, the result would not have occurred. 2.3 Homicide and manslaughter rule: 2.3.1 In homicide and manslaughter, any act by the defendant that hastens the victim's death is a cause-in-fact, even if death was already inevitable. Note: Cause-in-fact is sometimes called "actual cause" and is usually established with "but-for" analysis, plus the hastening-death rule in homicide.
cards.frontPrompt: In criminal law, how is cause-in-fact (actual cause) established, and what special rule applies in homicide and manslaughter when the defendant hastens an inevitable death?
cards.cloze: 2. {{c1::Causation requirement – Cause-in-fact}} 2.1 The defendant's conduct must be a {{c2::cause-in-fact}} of the result. 2.2 Basic test: {{c3::But for}} the defendant's conduct, the result would not have occurred. 2.3 {{c4::Homicide and manslaughter rule}}: 2.3.1 Any act by the defendant that {{c5::hastens the victim's death}} is a cause-in-fact, even if death was already {{c6::inevitable}}. Note: Cause-in-fact is also called {{c7::actual cause}}.
cards.easyContent: Cause-in-fact (actual cause) usually means that but for the defendant’s conduct, the result would not have happened. In homicide, any act that speeds up an otherwise inevitable death is still a cause-in-fact.
cards.mediumContent: To prove cause-in-fact, the prosecution must show that but for the defendant’s conduct, the result would not have occurred. In homicide and manslaughter cases, any act by the defendant that hastens the victim’s death is treated as a cause-in-fact, even if the victim was going to die anyway.
cards.hardContent: Cause-in-fact (actual cause) requires a factual link between the defendant’s conduct and the prohibited result. The standard test is that but for the defendant’s conduct, the result would not have occurred when and how it did. In homicide and manslaughter, courts apply a broad causation rule: any act by the defendant that hastens or accelerates the victim’s death qualifies as a cause-in-fact, even if the victim’s death was inevitable due to preexisting conditions or other causes. Thus, a defendant cannot escape liability merely by arguing the victim was doomed to die anyway.
cards.mnemonic: BUT-HAD: But for, Hastening A Death counts.
cards.clozeLite: Cause-in-fact uses the {{c1::"but for" test}}; in {{c2::homicide and manslaughter}}, any act that {{c3::hastens death}} is still {{c4::actual cause}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.topic: Causation – Proximate Cause, Superseding and Intervening Acts
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 005-3. Causation – Proximate Cause, Superseding and Intervening Acts
cards.front: Causation – Proximate Cause, Superseding and Intervening Acts
cards.backPlain: 2. Causation requirement – Proximate cause and intervening acts 2.1 Proximate cause 2.1.1 The actual result must be the natural and probable consequence of the defendant's conduct, even if it did not occur exactly as expected. 2.2 Superseding factors 2.2.1 Superseding factors break the chain of causation and relieve the defendant of liability for the result. 2.3 Intervening acts and foreseeability 2.3.1 Intervening acts must be entirely unforeseeable to be superseding and shield the defendant from liability. 2.3.2 Foreseeable intervening events (such as the victim's refusal of medical treatment or ordinary third-party medical negligence) do not break the causal chain; the defendant remains liable. Note: Causation issues, including proximate cause and intervening acts, frequently arise in homicide cases on the MBE.
cards.frontPrompt: In criminal law, what is proximate cause, and how do superseding and intervening acts—especially foreseeable ones like medical negligence or refusal of treatment—affect the chain of causation?
cards.cloze: 2. {{c1::Proximate cause and intervening acts}} 2.1 {{c2::Proximate cause}}: The actual result must be the {{c3::natural and probable consequence}} of the defendant's conduct, even if it does not occur {{c4::exactly as expected}}. 2.2 {{c5::Superseding factors}} 2.2.1 Superseding factors {{c6::break the chain of causation}} and relieve the defendant of liability for the result. 2.3 {{c7::Intervening acts and foreseeability}} 2.3.1 Intervening acts must be {{c8::entirely unforeseeable}} to be superseding and shield the defendant from liability. 2.3.2 Foreseeable intervening events—such as the victim's {{c9::refusal of medical treatment}} or {{c10::ordinary third-party medical negligence}}—are considered {{c11::foreseeable}} and therefore {{c12::do not break}} the causal chain; the defendant remains liable.
cards.easyContent: Proximate cause means the result is a natural and probable consequence of the defendant’s conduct. Only unforeseeable intervening acts are superseding and break causation; foreseeable events like medical negligence or a victim’s refusal of treatment do not.
cards.mediumContent: For proximate cause, the result must be a natural and probable consequence of the defendant’s conduct, even if the precise manner is unexpected. Superseding factors are intervening events that are so unforeseeable that they break the chain of causation and relieve the defendant of liability. Intervening acts must be entirely unforeseeable to be superseding; foreseeable events such as a victim’s refusal of medical care or ordinary medical negligence do not break causation, so the defendant remains liable.
cards.hardContent: Proximate cause limits liability to consequences that are sufficiently connected to the defendant’s conduct: the actual result must be a natural and probable consequence of that conduct, even if the precise manner in which it occurs is unusual. The causal chain may be broken by a superseding intervening event—an extraordinary, unforeseeable occurrence that becomes the primary cause of the result. Intervening acts only qualify as superseding if they are entirely unforeseeable. By contrast, foreseeable developments—such as a victim’s refusal of medical treatment, or ordinary third-party medical negligence in treating the injuries inflicted by the defendant—are not superseding and do not break the chain of causation; the defendant remains liable for the ultimate result. These proximate cause and intervening-act issues frequently arise in homicide questions on the MBE.
cards.mnemonic: Proximate cause sticks unless an extraordinary, unforeseeable act snaps the chain.
cards.clozeLite: Proximate cause requires that the result be a {{c1::natural and probable consequence}} of D's conduct; only {{c2::entirely unforeseeable intervening acts}} are {{c3::superseding}} and break causation.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 007-1. Merger – General Rule and Contexts
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule - Under the merger doctrine, two or more offenses may merge, prohibiting the defendant from being convicted of both offenses. 2. Relationships where merger arises - Merger concerns the relationship between either: - An inchoate offense and its completed substantive offense, or - An offense and its lesser included offense. 3. Purpose/Effect - Prevents multiple convictions when one crime is essentially part of another (e.g., attempt and the completed crime; robbery and felony murder based on that robbery).
cards.frontPrompt: What is the merger doctrine in criminal law, and between what types of offenses does it operate?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule - Under the {{c1::merger doctrine}}, two or more offenses may merge, prohibiting the defendant from being {{c2::convicted of both offenses}}. 2. Relationships where merger arises - Merger concerns the relationship between either: - An {{c3::inchoate offense}} and its completed {{c4::substantive offense}}, or - An offense and its {{c5::lesser included offense}}. 3. Purpose/Effect - Prevents {{c6::multiple convictions}} when one crime is essentially {{c7::part of another}}.
cards.easyContent: The merger doctrine prevents a defendant from being convicted of both when one crime is essentially part of another, typically between inchoate crimes and completed crimes, or greater crimes and their lesser included offenses.
cards.mediumContent: Under the merger doctrine, two or more offenses may merge, so the defendant cannot be convicted of both. It applies to the relationship between (1) an inchoate offense and its completed substantive offense and (2) an offense and its lesser included offense. The idea is that you should not be punished twice for what is essentially one criminal act.
cards.hardContent: The merger doctrine limits multiple convictions when one charged offense is subsumed within another. As a general rule, two or more offenses may merge, prohibiting the defendant from being convicted of both. Merger arises in two main relationships: (1) between an inchoate offense and its completed substantive offense and (2) between an offense and its lesser included offense. The doctrine prevents double-counting of liability for the same criminal conduct, while still allowing full punishment for the completed or greater offense.
cards.mnemonic: Merger: inchoate and lesser melt into the greater.
cards.clozeLite: Under the {{c1::merger doctrine}}, an {{c2::inchoate offense}} merges into its {{c3::completed substantive offense}}, and a {{c4::lesser included offense}} merges into the {{c5::greater offense}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.topic: Merger – Inchoate Offenses (Solicitation, Attempt, and Conspiracy)
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 007-2. Merger – Inchoate Offenses (Solicitation, Attempt, and Conspiracy)
cards.backPlain: 1. Inchoate offenses covered by merger - Merger only applies to solicitation and attempt. 2. Effect of merger for inchoate crimes - A defendant cannot be convicted of both solicitation or attempt and the completed target offense. - Example: The defendant completes a burglary after attempting it. The defendant cannot be convicted of both attempt and burglary. 3. Conspiracy as an exception - Merger does not apply to conspiracy. - The defendant can be convicted of both conspiracy to commit a given crime and the completed crime itself. - Rationale: conspiracy punishes the group agreement/danger, which is distinct from committing the substantive offense.
cards.frontPrompt: How does the merger doctrine apply to inchoate offenses, and what is the exception for conspiracy?
cards.cloze: 1. Inchoate offenses covered by merger - Merger only applies to {{c1::solicitation}} and {{c2::attempt}}. 2. Effect of merger for inchoate crimes - A defendant cannot be convicted of both solicitation or attempt and the {{c3::completed target offense}}. - Example: The defendant completes a burglary after attempting it. The defendant cannot be convicted of both {{c4::attempt}} and {{c5::burglary}}. 3. Conspiracy as an exception - Merger does {{c6::not}} apply to {{c7::conspiracy}}. - The defendant can be convicted of both {{c8::conspiracy to commit a given crime}} and the {{c9::completed crime itself}}. - Rationale: conspiracy punishes the {{c10::agreement and group danger}}, which is distinct from the substantive offense.
cards.easyContent: Merger applies to solicitation and attempt, so you cannot be convicted of both those inchoate crimes and the completed target offense. Conspiracy is different: it does not merge, so you can be convicted of both conspiracy and the completed crime.
cards.mediumContent: For inchoate crimes, the merger doctrine applies only to solicitation and attempt: once the target offense is completed, a defendant cannot be convicted of both the inchoate crime and the completed crime (e.g., attempt and burglary). Conspiracy is the major exception—conspiracy does not merge with the completed offense, so a defendant may be convicted of both conspiracy to commit a crime and the completed crime itself.
cards.hardContent: In the inchoate-offense context, merger distinguishes between solicitation and attempt, which merge, and conspiracy, which does not. Merger applies to solicitation and attempt, so a defendant cannot be convicted of both solicitation or attempt and the completed target offense; the completed substantive crime "swallows" the inchoate charge (e.g., attempt merges into completed burglary). However, conspiracy is a separate offense that does not merge; the defendant may be convicted of both conspiracy to commit a given crime and the completed crime. This reflects the distinct societal danger of group criminal agreements beyond the completed act itself.
cards.mnemonic: Merger: SA sink in, C stands alone.
cards.clozeLite: Under merger, {{c1::solicitation and attempt}} merge into the {{c2::completed target offense}}, but {{c3::conspiracy does not merge}} so D can be convicted of {{c4::both conspiracy and the completed crime}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.topic: Merger – Lesser Included Offenses and Double Jeopardy
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 007-3. Merger – Lesser Included Offenses and Double Jeopardy
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule for lesser included offenses - A defendant cannot be convicted of a target crime and a lesser included offense. 2. Definition of lesser included offense - A lesser included offense consists of the same, but not all, elements as the greater crime. 3. Example - The defendant robs the victim, and during the robbery the defendant’s accomplice kills the victim. - The defendant can be convicted of felony murder but not the lesser included robbery offense. 4. Relationship to double jeopardy - This merger result is also barred by double jeopardy, which prohibits multiple punishments for the same offense. 5. Different-victim rule - Crimes with different victims never merge.
cards.frontPrompt: How does the merger doctrine apply to lesser included offenses, and what are the rules about double jeopardy and different victims?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule for lesser included offenses - A defendant cannot be convicted of a {{c1::target crime}} and a {{c2::lesser included offense}}. 2. Definition of lesser included offense - A lesser included offense consists of the {{c3::same, but not all, elements}} as the {{c4::greater crime}}. 3. Example - The defendant robs the victim, and during the robbery the defendant’s accomplice kills the victim. - The defendant can be convicted of {{c5::felony murder}} but not the lesser included {{c6::robbery}} offense. 4. Relationship to double jeopardy - This merger result is also barred by {{c7::double jeopardy}}, which prohibits {{c8::multiple punishments for the same offense}}. 5. Different-victim rule - Crimes with {{c9::different victims}} never merge.
cards.easyContent: A defendant cannot be convicted of both a greater crime and its lesser included offense, because the lesser offense’s elements are all contained within the greater offense. Double jeopardy also bars this, but crimes involving different victims never merge.
cards.mediumContent: For lesser included offenses, merger prevents a defendant from being convicted of both the greater offense and its lesser included offense. A lesser included offense has the same, but not all, elements as the greater crime. For example, robbery can be a lesser included offense of felony murder based on that robbery, so the defendant can be convicted of felony murder but not robbery. Double jeopardy principles also bar such multiple punishments. However, crimes with different victims never merge.
cards.hardContent: In the lesser-included-offense context, merger bars multiple convictions where one offense is entirely subsumed within another. A defendant cannot be convicted of both a target (greater) crime and its lesser included offense. A lesser included offense is defined as one that consists of the same, but not all, elements as the greater crime. For instance, if a defendant commits a robbery and the accomplice kills the victim during the robbery, the defendant may be convicted of felony murder but not also of the underlying robbery as a separate offense. This result is independently supported by double jeopardy, which prohibits multiple punishments for the same offense. However, crimes involving different victims do not merge, even when otherwise related.
cards.mnemonic: LIO MERGE: Lesser Included Offense MERGEs—unless different victims.
cards.clozeLite: Merger bars conviction of both {{c1::a greater offense and its lesser included offense}}; {{c2::different victims}} means the crimes {{c3::never merge}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 008-1. Accomplice Liability – Elements and Scope
cards.backPlain: 1. Elements of accomplice liability: 1.1 Conduct: The defendant must {{aid, counsel, or encourage}} the principal. 1.1.1 Assistance must occur {{before or during}} the commission of the crime (not merely after). 1.2 Mental state: The defendant must act with the intent: 1.2.1 To {{assist the principal}}, and 1.2.2 That the principal {{commit the crime}}. 2. Scope of accomplice liability: 2.1 An accomplice is liable for: 2.1.1 The crimes he committed or counseled, and 2.1.2 Any other crimes that are {{probable or foreseeable results}} of the planned crime. 2.2 The additional crimes must be natural and probable consequences of the intended crime, not bizarre or highly extraordinary acts by the principal.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the elements required for accomplice liability, and for what crimes is an accomplice liable under the scope of accomplice liability?
cards.cloze: 1. Elements of accomplice liability: 1.1 Conduct: The defendant must {{c1::aid, counsel, or encourage}} the principal {{c2::before or during}} the commission of the crime. 1.2 Mental state: The defendant must intend {{c3::to assist the principal}} and {{c4::that the principal commit the crime}}. 2. Scope of accomplice liability: 2.1 An accomplice is liable for the crimes he {{c5::committed or counseled}} and for any other crimes that are {{c6::probable or foreseeable results}} of the planned crime. 2.2 The additional crimes must be {{c7::natural and probable consequences}} of the intended offense, not bizarre or extraordinary acts by the principal.
cards.easyContent: Accomplice liability requires aiding, counseling, or encouraging the principal before or during the crime, with intent both to help and that the crime be committed. The accomplice is liable for the intended crime and any other crimes that are natural, probable, or foreseeable results.
cards.mediumContent: A person is an accomplice if they aid, counsel, or encourage the principal before or during the crime and do so with intent both to assist and that the principal commit the crime. The accomplice is liable for the crime they intended and for additional crimes that are natural, probable, or foreseeable consequences of the planned offense, but not for bizarre or extraordinary deviations by the principal.
cards.hardContent: To be liable as an accomplice, the defendant must (1) aid, counsel, or encourage the principal before or during the offense, and (2) do so with the intent to assist the principal and that the principal commit the crime. This makes the accomplice liable both for the target offense and for any other crimes that are natural, probable, and foreseeable results of the planned conduct. However, the scope does not extend to highly unusual, unexpected, or bizarre acts by the principal that are not natural and probable consequences of the intended crime.
cards.mnemonic: AID + INTENT + FORESEEABLE: Aid before/during, intend help and crime, liable for foreseeable results.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::accomplice}} {{c2::aids, counsels, or encourages}} the principal {{c3::before or during the crime}} with {{c4::intent to assist and that the crime be committed}}, and is liable for {{c5::intended and foreseeable crimes}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 008-2. Accomplice Liability – Defenses and Exceptions
cards.backPlain: 3. Defenses and exceptions to accomplice liability: 3.1 Withdrawal (renunciation): 3.1.1 An accomplice can avoid liability by effectively withdrawing from the crime before the principal commits it. 3.1.2 Effective withdrawal generally requires the accomplice to: (a) Repudiate prior aid or encouragement. (b) Do all that is possible to counteract or neutralize the prior assistance. (c) Withdraw before the chain of events is in motion and unstoppable. 3.2 Member of a protected class: 3.2.1 A person who is a member of the class the statute is designed to protect cannot be held liable as an accomplice to a violation of that statute. 3.2.2 Example: A minor victim in a statutory rape case is not liable as an accomplice to statutory rape. 3.3 Parties not provided for in the statute: 3.3.1 A party whom the statute is clearly designed to regulate or target is not treated as an accomplice to the other regulated party. 3.3.2 Example: The purchaser of illegal drugs is not an accomplice to the seller under a statute aimed at criminalizing the sale.
cards.frontPrompt: What defenses and exceptions limit accomplice liability, including withdrawal, members of a protected class, and parties not provided for in the statute?
cards.cloze: 3. Defenses and exceptions to accomplice liability: 3.1 {{c1::Withdrawal (renunciation)}}: 3.1.1 An accomplice can avoid liability by withdrawing {{c2::before the principal commits the crime}}. 3.1.2 Effective withdrawal generally requires the accomplice to {{c3::repudiate prior aid or encouragement}}, {{c4::do all that is possible to counteract or neutralize}} the prior assistance, and {{c5::withdraw before the chain of events is in motion and unstoppable}}. 3.2 {{c6::Member of a protected class}}: 3.2.1 A person in the class the statute is designed to protect is {{c7::not liable as an accomplice}} to violations of that statute. 3.2.2 Example: {{c8::A minor victim in statutory rape is not an accomplice to statutory rape}}. 3.3 {{c9::Parties not provided for in the statute}}: 3.3.1 A party the statute is clearly designed to regulate is {{c10::not treated as an accomplice}} to the other regulated party. 3.3.2 Example: {{c11::A purchaser of illegal drugs is not an accomplice to the seller}} under a statute criminalizing sale.
cards.easyContent: Accomplice liability is limited by defenses and exceptions: an accomplice can avoid liability by effectively withdrawing before the crime (repudiating and counteracting prior aid), and by statutory rules that protect certain classes (like minor victims) or regulate one party (like drug buyers) without making them accomplices to the other party.
cards.mediumContent: Defenses and exceptions to accomplice liability include: (1) withdrawal before the crime, which generally requires repudiating prior aid or encouragement, doing what is reasonably possible to neutralize that aid, and acting before the chain of events is unstoppable; (2) protected-class members, who cannot be accomplices to the very offense meant to protect them (e.g., minor victims of statutory rape); and (3) parties not provided for in the statute, such as purchasers under drug-sale statutes, who are not treated as accomplices to the regulated counterparty.
cards.hardContent: Accomplice liability can be avoided through effective withdrawal if, before the principal commits the crime, the accomplice repudiates prior aid or encouragement and takes all reasonably possible steps to counteract or neutralize their earlier assistance, ensuring withdrawal occurs before the chain of events becomes inevitable. In addition, certain statutory exceptions bar accomplice liability: (1) members of the class a statute is designed to protect (such as minor victims in statutory rape cases) cannot be treated as accomplices to violations of that statute; and (2) parties the statute clearly contemplates and regulates, such as purchasers under statutes criminalizing the sale of drugs, are not treated as accomplices to the other regulated party.
cards.mnemonic: DEFENSES = WD-PN: Withdrawal, Protected, Not-listed.
cards.clozeLite: Accomplice liability is limited by {{c1::effective withdrawal}} and by {{c2::statutory exceptions}} for {{c3::protected-class members}} and {{c4::parties not provided for in the statute}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.topic: Accessory After the Fact – Distinct from Accomplice Liability
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 008-3. Accessory After the Fact – Distinct from Accomplice Liability
cards.front: Accessory After the Fact vs. Accomplice Liability
cards.backPlain: 4. Accessory after the fact (distinct from accomplice liability): 4.1 Timing: Accessory after the fact liability arises {{after}} the crime is complete, not before or during it. 4.2 Conduct: It involves helping a {{known felon}} avoid or escape arrest, trial, conviction, or punishment. 4.3 Separate offense: Being an accessory after the fact gives rise to a separate, typically lesser charge, often labeled obstruction of justice or a similar offense. 4.4 Distinction from accomplice liability: 4.4.1 Accomplices help bring about the crime and are liable for the crime itself and foreseeable additional crimes. 4.4.2 Accessories after the fact do not participate in committing the crime, but only assist the felon afterwards and are punished for that separate post-crime assistance.
cards.frontPrompt: What is an accessory after the fact, and how does accessory-after-the-fact liability differ from accomplice liability?
cards.cloze: 4. Accessory after the fact: 4.1 {{c1::Timing}}: Liability as an accessory after the fact arises {{c2::after the crime is complete}}, not before or during. 4.2 {{c3::Conduct}}: It involves helping a {{c4::known felon}} avoid or escape {{c5::arrest, trial, conviction, or punishment}}. 4.3 {{c6::Separate offense}}: It is charged as a {{c7::separate, typically lesser offense}}, often called {{c8::obstruction of justice}} or a similar crime. 4.4 Distinction: {{c9::Accomplices}} help bring about the crime and are liable for the crime itself and foreseeable additional crimes, while {{c10::accessories after the fact}} only assist {{c11::after the crime}} and are punished for that post-crime assistance.
cards.easyContent: An accessory after the fact is someone who, after a crime is complete, helps a known felon avoid arrest, trial, conviction, or punishment. This is a separate, usually lesser offense and is different from accomplice liability, which covers help given before or during the crime.
cards.mediumContent: Accessory-after-the-fact liability applies to a person who, knowing a felony has been committed, helps the felon avoid or escape arrest, trial, conviction, or punishment. It is a separate and typically lesser offense (often obstruction of justice), distinct from accomplice liability, which punishes those who help commit the crime itself and can extend to foreseeable additional crimes.
cards.hardContent: Accessory after the fact is a distinct doctrine from accomplice liability. It arises only after the underlying crime has been completed, and it targets those who, with knowledge of the felony, assist the felon in evading arrest, trial, conviction, or punishment. This conduct is charged as a separate, usually lesser offense, frequently styled obstruction of justice or a similar crime. By contrast, accomplice liability covers those who aid, counsel, or encourage the commission of the offense before or during its perpetration and subjects them to liability for the crime itself and other foreseeable resulting offenses.
cards.mnemonic: AFTER = Accessory acts After the Felony, for Escape from Responsibility.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::accessory after the fact}} {{c2::knows a felony was committed}} and {{c3::helps the felon avoid arrest or punishment}}, a {{c4::separate, lesser offense}} from {{c5::accomplice liability}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 010. Conspiracy – Definition and Elements
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule: Conspiracy is an agreement between two or more people to commit a crime or achieve an unlawful objective. 2. Required elements: (a) Agreement: • There must be an agreement between two or more people. • An express agreement is not required; a tacit understanding is sufficient. • The parties do not need to know of each other's existence. (b) Intent to enter into the agreement. (c) Intent to commit the target crime or pursue the unlawful objective. (d) Overt act (modern majority): • In many jurisdictions, there must be an overt act in furtherance of the conspiracy. • At common law, an overt act was not required; the agreement plus the required intents sufficed.
cards.frontPrompt: What is conspiracy, and what are its required elements, including the role of an overt act at common law and in modern jurisdictions?
cards.cloze: Conspiracy is an {{c1::agreement}} between {{c2::two or more people}} to commit a crime or achieve an {{c3::unlawful objective}}. Required elements: • An {{c4::agreement}} between two or more people, which may be {{c5::tacit}} and does not require that all conspirators {{c6::know of each other's existence}}. • {{c7::Intent to enter into the agreement}}. • {{c8::Intent to commit the target crime}} or pursue the {{c9::unlawful objective}}. • In many jurisdictions, an {{c10::overt act}} in furtherance of the conspiracy is required, but an overt act is {{c11::not required at common law}}.
cards.easyContent: Conspiracy is an agreement between two or more people to commit a crime, requiring an agreement (which can be tacit), intent to agree, intent to commit the unlawful objective, and in many jurisdictions an overt act (though common law did not require one).
cards.mediumContent: Conspiracy is defined as an agreement between two or more persons to commit a crime or achieve an unlawful objective. The elements are: (1) an agreement, which can be express or tacit and does not require that each conspirator know all others; (2) intent to enter into the agreement; (3) intent to accomplish the target crime or unlawful goal; and (4) in many modern jurisdictions, an overt act in furtherance of the conspiracy. At common law, the overt act element was not required.
cards.hardContent: Conspiracy is an inchoate offense whose actus reus is an agreement between two or more persons to commit a crime or achieve an unlawful objective. The agreement need not be formal or explicit; a tacit understanding inferred from conduct suffices, and conspirators need not know every other member of the conspiracy. The mens rea consists of (1) intent to enter into the agreement and (2) intent that the target crime be committed or that the unlawful objective be achieved. Many modern jurisdictions add a further actus reus requirement: an overt act in furtherance of the conspiracy, which may be minimal (e.g., buying supplies). At common law, however, the conspiracy was complete upon the agreement and requisite intents, with no overt act required.
cards.mnemonic: "AII + (maybe O)": Agreement, Intent to agree, Intent to commit, and maybe Overt act.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child 1 of 3 for conspiracy: focuses on definition and elements (including overt act).
cards.clozeLite: Conspiracy is an {{c1::agreement between two or more persons}} with {{c2::intent to agree}} and {{c3::intent to accomplish the unlawful objective}}, plus in many modern jurisdictions {{c4::an overt act}} ({{c5::not required at common law}}).

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.topic: Conspiracy – Common Law Bilateral vs. MPC Unilateral
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 010. Conspiracy – Common Law vs. MPC
cards.front: Conspiracy – Common Law Bilateral vs. MPC Unilateral
cards.backPlain: 1. Bilateral v. unilateral theories: (a) Common law (bilateral): • Conspiracy is bilateral. • At least two parties must have genuine criminal intent for a conspiracy to exist. • If one "conspirator" is feigning agreement (e.g., an undercover police officer), there is no conspiracy under strict common law. (b) MPC (unilateral): • Conspiracy can be unilateral. • One party with criminal intent may be convicted of conspiracy even if the other is feigning agreement (such as an undercover officer). 2. Exam tip: • Unless otherwise instructed, apply the common law bilateral rule on the bar exam.
cards.frontPrompt: How does conspiracy differ under the common law bilateral approach versus the MPC unilateral approach, especially when one party is feigning agreement?
cards.cloze: Under {{c1::common law}}, conspiracy is {{c2::bilateral}}, requiring that {{c3::at least two parties have genuine criminal intent}}. If one party is {{c4::feigning agreement}} (e.g., an undercover officer), there is {{c5::no conspiracy}} under strict common law. Under the {{c6::MPC}}, conspiracy can be {{c7::unilateral}}, so {{c8::one party with criminal intent}} may be convicted even if the other is {{c9::feigning agreement}}. On the bar exam, unless otherwise instructed, apply the {{c10::common law bilateral rule}}.
cards.easyContent: At common law, conspiracy is bilateral and needs at least two genuine criminals; if one is just pretending (like an undercover officer), there is no conspiracy. Under the MPC, conspiracy can be unilateral, so one person with criminal intent can be guilty even if the other is feigning agreement. Default to the common law rule on the exam.
cards.mediumContent: Common law requires a bilateral conspiracy: at least two parties must truly intend to commit the crime for a conspiracy to exist. If one "conspirator" is actually an undercover officer or otherwise feigning agreement, common law would not find a conspiracy. The MPC adopts a unilateral approach: a single person with the requisite criminal intent can be guilty of conspiracy even if the supposed co-conspirator is merely pretending. On the bar exam, you should generally apply the common law bilateral rule unless told otherwise.
cards.hardContent: The bilateral theory of conspiracy, followed at traditional common law, requires that two or more persons actually share the criminal objective; at least two must possess genuine criminal intent. Consequently, where one alleged conspirator is feigning agreement—such as an undercover officer or an informant—no conspiracy exists under strict bilateral doctrine. In contrast, the MPC adopts a unilateral theory: it focuses on the culpability of the individual defendant. A defendant who believes he is agreeing with another to commit a crime and has the requisite intent may be convicted of conspiracy even if the other party is an undercover officer or otherwise lacks criminal intent. For bar exam purposes, absent explicit statutory or MPC direction, apply the common law bilateral requirement.
cards.mnemonic: CL: both bad; MPC: mind of one.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child 2 of 3 for conspiracy: focuses on common law bilateral vs. MPC unilateral approaches.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::common law}} conspiracy is {{c2::bilateral}} and needs {{c3::two genuine criminals}}; under the {{c4::MPC}} it is {{c5::unilateral}} so {{c6::one culpable mind}} is enough.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 010. Conspiracy – Termination and Defenses
cards.backPlain: 1. Termination of conspiracy: (a) Completion of target crime: • A conspiracy ends upon completion of the target offense. (b) Abandonment of the plan: • A conspiracy also terminates when the conspirators abandon the plan. 2. Defenses to conspiracy: (a) Impossibility: • Impossibility is not a defense to conspiracy. (b) Withdrawal: • Withdrawal is generally not a defense to the conspiracy itself once the agreement is made; the crime of conspiracy is complete at that point (and, if required, once the overt act occurs). • However, a timely and effective withdrawal may be a defense to liability for co-conspirators' subsequent substantive crimes committed in furtherance of the conspiracy.
cards.frontPrompt: When does a conspiracy terminate, and how do impossibility and withdrawal operate as (non-)defenses to conspiracy and related liability?
cards.cloze: A conspiracy terminates when the {{c1::target crime is completed}} or when the conspirators {{c2::abandon the plan}}. {{c3::Impossibility}} is {{c4::not a defense}} to conspiracy. {{c5::Withdrawal}} is generally {{c6::not a defense}} to the conspiracy itself once the agreement (and any required overt act) has occurred, but a {{c7::timely and effective withdrawal}} may protect the defendant from liability for {{c8::co-conspirators' subsequent substantive crimes}} committed in furtherance of the conspiracy.
cards.easyContent: A conspiracy ends when the target crime is completed or the conspirators abandon their plan. Impossibility is not a defense to conspiracy. Withdrawal usually does not erase the conspiracy but, if timely and effective, can prevent liability for later crimes by co-conspirators.
cards.mediumContent: Conspiracy terminates when the target offense is completed or when the conspirators abandon the scheme. Impossibility—whether factual or legal—is not a defense to the charge of conspiracy. Once the agreement (and any required overt act) occurs, the conspiracy is complete, so withdrawal is generally not a defense to the conspiracy itself. However, if a conspirator withdraws in a timely and effective manner, that may shield the defendant from liability for substantive offenses later committed by co-conspirators in furtherance of the conspiracy.
cards.hardContent: For temporal and liability purposes, conspiracy ends either when the target crime is successfully completed or when the conspirators truly abandon their plan. Impossibility does not excuse conspiratorial liability; the law punishes the agreement and danger of group criminality even if, unknown to the parties, the crime cannot be completed. Once the elements of conspiracy are satisfied—the agreement plus the requisite intents, and, in overt-act jurisdictions, the overt act—the crime of conspiracy is complete, and subsequent withdrawal cannot undo it. Nevertheless, a conspirator who effectively withdraws (often by communicating withdrawal to co-conspirators and, in some jurisdictions, taking affirmative steps to thwart the crime) before further crimes are committed may avoid vicarious liability for those later substantive offenses. Thus, withdrawal functions primarily to cut off liability for co-conspirators' subsequent crimes, not to negate the conspiracy itself.
cards.mnemonic: TIDW: Termination, Impossibility no defense, Withdrawal limits later crimes.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child 3 of 3 for conspiracy: focuses on termination and defenses (impossibility, withdrawal).
cards.clozeLite: Conspiracy {{c1::terminates}} when the {{c2::target offense is completed}} or {{c3::the conspirators abandon the scheme}}; {{c4::impossibility is not a defense}} and {{c5::withdrawal doesn’t undo the conspiracy itself}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 012. Attempt – Definition and Act Requirement
cards.backPlain: 1. General definition of attempt: - Attempt is an act, done with the specific intent to commit a crime, that constitutes an overt or substantial step toward committing the crime but falls short of completing the crime. - An incomplete act that would be a crime if completed can constitute attempt. 2. Overt act / substantial step requirement: - The defendant must commit an act beyond mere preparation and take a substantial step toward committing the target crime. - Under the common law "dangerous proximity" standard, attempt requires an act that is dangerously close to success.
cards.frontPrompt: In criminal law, how is attempt defined, and what is required for the overt act or substantial step toward the target crime?
cards.cloze: 1. General definition of {{c1::attempt}}: - Attempt is an act, done with the {{c2::specific intent}} to commit a crime, that constitutes an {{c3::overt or substantial step}} toward committing the crime but {{c4::falls short of completion}}. - An {{c5::incomplete act that would be a crime if completed}} can constitute attempt. 2. Overt act / substantial step requirement: - The defendant must commit an act beyond {{c6::mere preparation}} and take a {{c7::substantial step}} toward committing the target crime. - Under the common law {{c8::"dangerous proximity"}} standard, attempt requires an act that is {{c9::dangerously close to success}}.
cards.easyContent: Attempt is when a defendant, with specific intent, takes an overt or substantial step beyond mere preparation toward committing a crime but does not complete it. At common law, the act must be dangerously close to success.
cards.mediumContent: Attempt occurs when a defendant, with specific intent to commit a particular crime, performs an overt or substantial step toward the crime that goes beyond mere preparation and falls short of completion. Under the common law "dangerous proximity" test, the act must be dangerously close to success.
cards.hardContent: Attempt is an inchoate offense where the defendant, with the specific intent to commit a particular crime, engages in conduct that constitutes an overt or substantial step beyond mere preparation and falls short of completion. An incomplete act that would be criminal if completed can suffice. Under the common law "dangerous proximity" standard, the defendant's conduct must be dangerously close to consummating the offense.
cards.mnemonic: Step Not Done: specific intent + substantial step, crime not done.
cards.clozeLite: Attempt is when D, with {{c1::specific intent}}, takes a {{c2::substantial step beyond mere preparation}} that is {{c3::dangerously close to success}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 012. Attempt – Specific Intent Requirement
cards.backPlain: Specific intent for attempt: - The defendant must specifically intend to commit a particular target crime. - Attempt liability thus requires a higher mens rea than some completed offenses (e.g., recklessness or negligence is not enough for attempt).
cards.frontPrompt: What mens rea is required for attempt in criminal law?
cards.cloze: Specific intent for {{c1::attempt}}: - The defendant must {{c2::specifically intend}} to commit a {{c3::particular target crime}}. - Attempt generally requires a {{c4::higher mens rea}} than some completed offenses; {{c5::recklessness or negligence}} alone is not enough for attempt liability.
cards.easyContent: Attempt always requires a specific intent to commit the target crime; lesser mental states like recklessness or negligence are not enough.
cards.mediumContent: For attempt, the defendant must specifically intend to bring about the completed offense. This specific intent standard is stricter than the mental states for some substantive crimes, so recklessness or negligence alone cannot support attempt liability.
cards.hardContent: Attempt is a specific-intent offense: the defendant must have the conscious objective to commit a particular target crime. This requirement is generally stricter than the mens rea for many completed offenses (which may be satisfied by recklessness or negligence), so those lesser mental states do not suffice for attempt liability.
cards.mnemonic: Attempt aims at a target crime: you must intend that very offense.
cards.clozeLite: Attempt is a {{c1::specific-intent offense}}: D must {{c2::intend to bring about the completed offense}}; {{c3::recklessness or negligence}} is not enough.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 012. Attempt – Defenses: Impossibility and Abandonment
cards.backPlain: Defenses to attempt: 1. Legal impossibility: - Legal impossibility is a defense to attempt. - This occurs when, even if the defendant did everything he intended to do, his conduct would not constitute a crime. 2. Factual impossibility: - Factual impossibility is not a defense to attempt. - This occurs when external or factual circumstances prevent completion of the crime (e.g., the pickpocket reaches into an empty pocket). 3. Abandonment: - At common law, abandonment is not a defense to attempt. - Under the majority rule, liability for attempt arises once the defendant commits an overt act concurrently with the specific intent to commit the crime; the defendant is liable for attempt before he can abandon the crime.
cards.frontPrompt: In attempt law, how do legal impossibility, factual impossibility, and abandonment operate as defenses?
cards.cloze: Defenses to {{c1::attempt}}: 1. {{c2::Legal impossibility}}: - Legal impossibility {{c3::is a defense}} to attempt. - It applies when, even if the defendant did everything he intended, his conduct {{c4::would not be a crime}}. 2. {{c5::Factual impossibility}}: - Factual impossibility {{c6::is not a defense}} to attempt. - It applies when {{c7::external or factual circumstances}} (e.g., an {{c8::empty pocket}} for a pickpocket) prevent completion. 3. {{c9::Abandonment}}: - At {{c10::common law}}, abandonment {{c11::is not a defense}} to attempt. - Under the {{c12::majority rule}}, attempt liability arises once the defendant commits an {{c13::overt act concurrently with the specific intent}} to commit the crime; he is liable for attempt {{c14::before he can abandon}} the crime.
cards.easyContent: Legal impossibility is a defense to attempt, because the completed act would not be a crime. Factual impossibility is not a defense. Abandonment is not a defense at common law, and under the majority rule the defendant is already liable for attempt once he has the specific intent and takes the overt act, even if he then abandons.
cards.mediumContent: For attempt, legal impossibility is a defense when the defendant's intended conduct, even if fully carried out, would not be criminal. Factual impossibility—where some unknown factual circumstance makes completion impossible—is not a defense. Abandonment is not a defense at common law; under the majority rule, attempt liability attaches as soon as the defendant, with specific intent, commits the requisite overt act, so any later abandonment does not negate liability.
cards.hardContent: In attempt law, legal impossibility is a valid defense: if the defendant's plan, even if fully executed, would not constitute a crime (because the law does not actually prohibit that conduct), he cannot be convicted of attempt. By contrast, factual impossibility—where some unknown external or factual circumstance, such as an empty pocket or already-dead victim, makes completion of the offense impossible—does not bar attempt liability. Abandonment likewise is not a defense at common law; under the majority view, once the defendant, with specific intent, commits an overt act that is a substantial step toward the offense, attempt liability is fixed, and any subsequent decision to abandon the plan does not eliminate that liability.
cards.mnemonic: LIFA: Legal Is Free; Factual and Abandonment still Attach.
cards.clozeLite: In attempt, {{c1::legal impossibility}} is a defense, {{c2::factual impossibility}} is not, and {{c3::abandonment}} is no defense under the {{c4::common-law/majority rule}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 013-1. Insanity Defense – General Rule
cards.backPlain: Insanity – General Rule: 1. Scope of the defense: 1.1 Legal insanity is a complete defense to all crimes, regardless of the mens rea or intent requirement. 1.2 If the defendant is found legally insane under the applicable test, he is entitled to acquittal (usually followed by commitment proceedings). 2. Jurisdictional tests: 2.1 Jurisdictions adopt one of several insanity tests to determine whether the defendant was so mentally ill at the time of the offense that he should be excused. 2.2 The four main tests are: M'Naghten, Irresistible Impulse, MPC, and Durham. 2.3 On the MBE, the question will expressly state which insanity test applies.
cards.frontPrompt: In criminal law, what is the general rule about insanity as a defense and how does it relate to the various insanity tests?
cards.cloze: Insanity – General Rule: 1. Scope of the defense: 1.1 {{c1::Legal insanity}} is a {{c2::complete defense}} to {{c3::all crimes}}, regardless of the {{c4::mens rea or intent requirement}}. 1.2 If the defendant is found legally insane under the applicable test, he is {{c5::entitled to acquittal}} (typically followed by {{c6::commitment proceedings}}). 2. Jurisdictional tests: 2.1 Jurisdictions adopt one of several {{c7::insanity tests}} to determine whether the defendant was so mentally ill at the time of the offense that he should be excused. 2.2 The four main tests are: {{c8::M'Naghten}}, {{c9::Irresistible Impulse}}, {{c10::MPC}}, and {{c11::Durham}}. 2.3 On the {{c12::MBE}}, the question will expressly state which {{c13::insanity test}} applies.
cards.easyContent: Legal insanity is a complete defense to all crimes. A defendant who meets the jurisdiction’s insanity test is acquitted, and the exam will tell you which insanity test to use.
cards.mediumContent: Insanity is a complete defense to all crimes, regardless of the required mens rea, if the defendant was legally insane at the time of the offense under the jurisdiction’s chosen insanity test. The four main tests are M'Naghten, Irresistible Impulse, MPC, and Durham. On the MBE, the problem will expressly specify which test to apply.
cards.hardContent: Legal insanity operates as a complete defense to all crimes, regardless of the mental state otherwise required, when the defendant’s mental disease or defect at the time of the offense satisfies the jurisdiction’s insanity standard. Jurisdictions choose among several tests—M'Naghten, Irresistible Impulse, MPC, or Durham—to decide whether the defendant was so mentally ill that he should be excused from criminal liability. If the defendant is found legally insane under the applicable test, he is entitled to acquittal (typically followed by civil commitment or similar proceedings). On the MBE, the question will always specify which insanity test governs.
cards.mnemonic: Insanity is a complete shield: meet the test, walk free.
cards.clozeLite: Insanity is a {{c1::complete defense}} to all crimes if D was {{c2::legally insane}} under the {{c3::jurisdiction’s insanity test}} (e.g., {{c4::M'Naghten, II, MPC, Durham}}).

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 013-2. Insanity Defense – M'Naghten Test
cards.backPlain: M'Naghten Test (Cognitive Test): 1. Core idea: 1.1 The defendant does not know right from wrong. 2. Rule statement: 2.1 Due to a mental disease or defect, at the time of the offense the defendant lacked the ability to know the wrongfulness of his conduct or understand the nature and quality of his act. 2.2 This focuses on the defendant’s cognitive capacity (ability to understand what he is doing and that it is wrong).
cards.frontPrompt: Under the M'Naghten test for insanity, when is a defendant considered legally insane?
cards.cloze: M'Naghten Test (Cognitive Test): 1. Core idea: 1.1 The defendant {{c1::does not know right from wrong}}. 2. Rule statement: 2.1 Due to a {{c2::mental disease or defect}}, at the time of the offense the defendant lacked the ability to know the {{c3::wrongfulness}} of his conduct or understand the {{c4::nature and quality}} of his act. 2.2 This test focuses on the defendant’s {{c5::cognitive capacity}} (ability to understand what he is doing and that it is wrong).
cards.easyContent: Under M'Naghten, a defendant is insane if, because of mental disease or defect, he did not know right from wrong or did not understand what he was doing.
cards.mediumContent: The M'Naghten insanity test is purely cognitive. A defendant is legally insane if, due to mental disease or defect at the time of the offense, he lacked the ability either to know the wrongfulness of his conduct or to understand the nature and quality of his act.
cards.hardContent: Under the M'Naghten test, a defendant is legally insane if, at the time of the offense and due to a mental disease or defect, he lacked the ability to know the wrongfulness of his conduct or to understand the nature and quality of his act—essentially, he did not know right from wrong or what he was doing. The emphasis is on cognitive impairment, not on inability to control behavior.
cards.mnemonic: M'Naghten: Mind Not right—No sense of Wrong or What.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::M'Naghten}} insanity test is {{c2::purely cognitive}}: D must lack ability to {{c3::know wrongfulness}} or {{c4::understand nature and quality}} of the act.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 013-3. Insanity Defense – Irresistible Impulse Test
cards.backPlain: Irresistible Impulse Test (Volitional Test): 1. Core idea: 1.1 The defendant acted due to an irresistible impulse. 2. Rule statement: 2.1 Due to a mental illness, the defendant was unable to control his actions or conform his conduct to the law. 2.2 This focuses on the defendant’s volitional capacity (ability to control behavior), even if he may know his conduct is wrong.
cards.frontPrompt: Under the Irresistible Impulse test for insanity, when is a defendant considered legally insane?
cards.cloze: Irresistible Impulse Test (Volitional Test): 1. Core idea: 1.1 The defendant acted due to an {{c1::irresistible impulse}}. 2. Rule statement: 2.1 Due to a {{c2::mental illness}}, the defendant was unable to {{c3::control his actions}} or {{c4::conform his conduct to the law}}. 2.2 This test focuses on the defendant’s {{c5::volitional capacity}} (ability to control behavior), even if he may know his conduct is wrong.
cards.easyContent: Under the Irresistible Impulse test, a defendant is insane if, because of mental illness, he couldn’t control his actions or conform his conduct to the law, even if he knew it was wrong.
cards.mediumContent: The Irresistible Impulse insanity test is volitional. A defendant is legally insane if, due to mental illness, he acted because of an irresistible impulse and was unable to control his actions or conform his conduct to the law.
cards.hardContent: Under the Irresistible Impulse test, a defendant is legally insane if, at the time of the offense and because of a mental illness, he acted under an irresistible impulse such that he was unable to control his actions or conform his conduct to the requirements of the law. This test targets volitional incapacity—the inability to control behavior—even where the defendant may cognitively understand that his conduct is wrong.
cards.mnemonic: Irresistible Impulse: "Knows, but can’t go slow"—no control.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::Irresistible Impulse}} insanity test is {{c2::volitional}}: due to mental illness, D {{c3::cannot control his actions}} or {{c4::conform conduct to the law}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 013-4. Insanity Defense – MPC Test
cards.backPlain: MPC Test (Combined Cognitive/Volitional Test): 1. Core idea: 1.1 The MPC standard combines elements of M'Naghten and Irresistible Impulse. 2. Rule statement: 2.1 As a result of the defendant's mental disease, the defendant lacked the capacity either to appreciate the criminality (or wrongfulness) of his conduct or to conform his conduct to the requirements of the law. 2.2 This test looks at both cognitive capacity (appreciating criminality/wrongfulness) and volitional capacity (conforming conduct).
cards.frontPrompt: Under the MPC insanity test, when is a defendant considered legally insane?
cards.cloze: MPC Test (Combined Cognitive/Volitional Test): 1. Core idea: 1.1 The MPC standard is a combination of {{c1::M'Naghten}} and {{c2::Irresistible Impulse}}. 2. Rule statement: 2.1 As a result of the defendant's {{c3::mental disease}}, the defendant lacked the capacity either to {{c4::appreciate the criminality (or wrongfulness) of his conduct}} or to {{c5::conform his conduct to the requirements of the law}}. 2.2 This test examines both {{c6::cognitive}} capacity and {{c7::volitional}} capacity.
cards.easyContent: Under the MPC test, a defendant is insane if, because of mental disease, he lacks capacity either to appreciate the criminality of his conduct or to conform his conduct to the law.
cards.mediumContent: The MPC insanity test combines cognitive and volitional aspects. A defendant is legally insane if, as a result of mental disease, he lacked the capacity either to appreciate the criminality (or wrongfulness) of his conduct or to conform his conduct to the requirements of the law.
cards.hardContent: Under the MPC insanity standard, a defendant is legally insane if, at the time of the offense and as a result of a mental disease, he lacked the capacity either to appreciate the criminality (or wrongfulness) of his conduct (cognitive prong) or to conform his conduct to the requirements of the law (volitional prong). This test blends the M'Naghten focus on understanding with the Irresistible Impulse focus on self-control.
cards.mnemonic: MPC: Mind or Performance Control – no insight or control.
cards.clozeLite: Under the {{c1::MPC insanity test}}, D is insane if due to {{c2::mental disease}} he lacks capacity to {{c3::appreciate criminality}} or {{c4::conform conduct to law}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 013-5. Insanity Defense – Durham Test
cards.backPlain: Durham Test (Product Test): 1. Core idea: 1.1 The defendant’s conduct was the product of a mental illness. 2. Rule statement: 2.1 But for his mental illness, the defendant would not have acted. 2.2 The defendant's conduct must be the product of a mental illness to qualify as legally insane under this test.
cards.frontPrompt: Under the Durham test for insanity, when is a defendant considered legally insane?
cards.cloze: Durham Test (Product Test): 1. Core idea: 1.1 The defendant’s conduct was the {{c1::product}} of a {{c2::mental illness}}. 2. Rule statement: 2.1 {{c3::But for}} his mental illness, the defendant would not have acted. 2.2 The defendant's conduct must be the {{c4::product of a mental illness}} to qualify as legally insane under this test.
cards.easyContent: Under the Durham test, a defendant is insane if his conduct was the product of mental illness—he would not have acted but for that illness.
cards.mediumContent: The Durham insanity test is a "product" test. A defendant is legally insane if his criminal conduct was the product of his mental illness—he would not have committed the act but for that illness.
cards.hardContent: Under the Durham test, a defendant is legally insane if his criminal conduct was the product of his mental illness—i.e., he would not have acted but for that illness. This approach focuses on causal connection between the mental illness and the criminal act and is broader than the traditional cognitive or volitional tests.
cards.mnemonic: Durham = Did it due to disorder.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::Durham insanity test}} is a {{c2::product test}}: D is insane if his crime was the {{c3::product of mental illness}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 014-1. Capacity Defense – Infancy
cards.front: Infancy Defense – Criminal Capacity by Age
cards.backPlain: Infancy as a defense to criminal liability: 1. Under 7 years old: - No criminal liability. - The child is conclusively presumed incapable of committing a crime. 2. Ages 7–14 years: - Rebuttable presumption against criminal liability. - The prosecution may rebut by showing that the child understood the wrongfulness of his conduct and had sufficient capacity to form the required mens rea.
cards.frontPrompt: How does the infancy defense limit criminal liability for children under 7 and for those ages 7–14?
