cards.cloze: Breaking (common law): - {{c1::Breaking must be trespassory}}. - {{c2::Actual breaking}}: {{c3::opening or enlarging an opening}} (e.g., opening an unlocked door or raising a window). - {{c4::Constructive breaking}}: entry by {{c5::threat, force, fraud, or duress}}. - {{c6::Fraud negates any apparent consent}} the victim may have given. - No trespassory breaking: entering with {{c7::valid consent}} or through a {{c8::wide open door}} is not a breaking. - Under many {{c9::modern statutes}}, {{c10::breaking is not required}}. Entering: - Entering is satisfied when {{c11::any portion of the body or the instrument used for the breaking}} passes inside the structure. Dwelling and "of another": - {{c12::Dwelling}}: a structure used for {{c13::sleeping purposes}}. - "{{c14::Of another}}": {{c15::occupancy}} is sufficient; {{c16::ownership is irrelevant}}.
cards.easyContent: Breaking can be actual (opening or enlarging an opening) or constructive (entry by threat, force, fraud, or duress), but must be trespassory—no valid consent or wide-open entry. Entering is any part of the body or an instrument crossing the threshold into a dwelling (used for sleeping) of another, with occupancy controlling rather than ownership.
cards.mediumContent: Common law burglary requires a trespassory breaking and entering. Breaking can be actual (opening or enlarging an entry, such as opening an unlocked door) or constructive (entry by threat, force, fraud, or duress, with fraud vitiating consent). Entering through a wide open door or with valid consent is not a breaking, and modern statutes often dispense with breaking altogether. Entry is satisfied when any part of the body or an instrument crosses into the structure. The structure must be a dwelling (used for sleeping), and it must be of another, with occupancy, not ownership, determining that element.
cards.hardContent: For common law burglary, the breaking must be trespassory. Actual breaking involves physically opening or enlarging an opening into the structure, such as opening an unlocked door or raising a window. Constructive breaking is satisfied by entry obtained through threat, force, fraud, or duress; in particular, fraud renders any apparent consent invalid so that the entry is trespassory. Entering with valid consent or through a wide open door is not a breaking. Many modern burglary statutes no longer require a breaking at all. Entering is met when any portion of the defendant’s body or an instrument used for the breaking intrudes into the structure. The place entered must be a dwelling, meaning a structure used for sleeping, and it must be “of another,” which is determined by occupancy rather than ownership—an occupant’s possessory interest is sufficient.
cards.mnemonic: ABCED: Actual Break, Constructive (threat, fraud), Entry, Dwelling of Another.
cards.clozeLite: Common law burglary requires {{c1::trespassory breaking and entering}} into a {{c2::dwelling used for sleeping}} {{c3::of another, based on occupancy}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Law
cards.topic: Burglary – Modern Statutory Modifications and Exam Focus
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Law 036-3. Burglary – Modern Statutory Modifications and Exam Focus
cards.front: Burglary – Modern Statutory Modifications and Exam Focus
cards.backPlain: Modern burglary statutes typically broaden the common law definition of burglary in several ways: 1. Breaking requirement: - Many modern statutes do not require a breaking; unauthorized entry is sufficient. 2. Nighttime requirement: - Nighttime is often eliminated as an element under modern statutes. 3. Covered structures: - Modern statutes often expand burglary to include structures beyond dwellings, such as stores or other buildings not used for sleeping. 4. Intended offense: - Modern statutes frequently broaden the intended offense beyond felonies to include misdemeanors, especially theft-related offenses. - The intended crime still need not be completed. Exam note: - On the MBE, apply modern statutory rules for burglary unless the question specifically instructs you to apply the common law definition.
cards.frontPrompt: How do modern burglary statutes differ from the common law definition with respect to breaking, nighttime, covered structures, and the intended offense, and what rule should you apply on the MBE?
cards.cloze: Modern {{c1::burglary statutes}} typically broaden the {{c2::common law}} definition: 1. {{c3::Breaking requirement}}: - Many modern statutes {{c4::do not require a breaking}}; {{c5::unauthorized entry}} is sufficient. 2. {{c6::Nighttime requirement}}: - {{c7::Nighttime}} is often {{c8::eliminated as an element}}. 3. {{c9::Covered structures}}: - Statutes commonly extend burglary to {{c10::non-dwelling structures}} (e.g., stores or other buildings) beyond {{c11::dwellings used for sleeping}}. 4. {{c12::Intended offense}}: - The intended offense is broadened beyond {{c13::felonies}} to include {{c14::misdemeanors, especially theft}}. - The intended crime {{c15::need not be completed}}. Exam note: - On the {{c16::MBE}}, apply {{c1::modern statutory rules}} for burglary unless the question specifically directs you to use the {{c2::common law}} definition.
cards.easyContent: Modern burglary statutes usually drop the breaking and nighttime requirements, cover non-dwelling structures, and allow burglary to be based on intent to commit misdemeanors like theft. On the MBE, apply these modern rules unless told to use the common law definition.
cards.mediumContent: Modern burglary statutes generally: (1) eliminate the need for a trespassory breaking, making unauthorized entry enough; (2) remove the nighttime requirement; (3) extend burglary to non-dwellings such as commercial buildings; and (4) broaden the intended offense beyond felonies to include misdemeanors, particularly theft. The crime still does not require completion of the intended offense. On the MBE, treat burglary under these modern statutory modifications unless a question expressly calls for the common law rule.
cards.hardContent: Compared to the narrow common law definition, modern burglary statutes significantly broaden the offense. Many statutes no longer require a trespassory breaking; unauthorized entry into the premises is sufficient. The common law nighttime element is frequently eliminated altogether. The class of protected structures expands from dwellings—structures used for sleeping—to a wide range of buildings, including stores, offices, and other non-dwelling premises. Modern statutes also broaden the required mens rea by allowing burglary to be predicated on intent to commit misdemeanors such as theft, not just felonies, while still not requiring actual commission of the underlying offense. For bar exam purposes, especially on the MBE, you generally apply these modern statutory features unless a question expressly instructs you to analyze burglary under the common law definition.
cards.mnemonic: Modern burglary: "EASY"—Entry Anytime, Structures, Your theft intent.
cards.clozeLite: Modern burglary statutes {{c1::drop breaking and nighttime}}, {{c2::cover non-dwellings}}, and {{c3::allow intent to commit misdemeanors like theft}}; {{c4::apply modern rules on the MBE}}.
